annotation.annotation:
Ciliated protozoa contain two nuclei, a germline nucleus and a somatic nucleus. - The somatic nucleus is active but not passed on after fertilization. - The germline nucleus is transcriptionally inert in the mother cell but is transmitted to progeny. The new somatic nucleus is created from this germline nucleus ((Nowacki 2009)).
In Paramecium tetraurelia creating the new somatic nucleus requires widespread deletion of repetitive sequences and tens of thousands of internal eliminated sequences (IES) to create the compact somatic nucleus in the progeny ((Nowacki 2009)).
Elimination of DNA appears to depend on whether it was present in the maternal somatic nucleus, with DNA present in the maternal somatic nucleus being retained in the progeny somatic nucleus. This process appears to be controlled by interactions between homologous short and long noncoding RNAs ((Nowacki 2009)).
DNA in the somatic nucleus is transcribed into sense and antisense noncoding RNAs during both vegetative growth and sexual reproduction ((LepA re 2008)).

RNA transcripts derived from DNA sequences in the maternal somatic nucleus are necessary but not necessarily sufficient to cause retention of this sequence in the progeny somatic nucleus ((LepA re 2008)).
For example: introduction of an IE sequence into the maternal somatic nucleus is able to maintain the presence of that IES in the somatic nucleus of the progeny in some cases ((Duharcourt 1995), (Duharcourt 1998)). However degradation of IES RNA transcripts during the vegetal growth stage prevented maintenance of that IES in progeny somatic nuclei, showing long noncoding transcripts from the maternal somatic nuclei were necessary for maintenance of the DNA in progeny ((LepA re 2008)).
Paramecium expresses a complex population of ~25 nuc germline Scan RNAs (scnRNAs) during early meiosis which have homology to all types of germline sequences. Knockdown of scnRNAs allows retention of sequences normally deleted from the progeny somatic nucleus ((LepA re 2008)).
ScnRNA : Maternal ncRNA model ScnRNAs signal sequences to be deleted while maternal RNAs signal sequences to be maintained. Hypothesised that maternal somatic RNAs deplete homologous germline scnRNAs, preventing excision of these sequences in progeny somatic nuclei. Whereas undepleted scnRNAs do cause excision of target DNA sequences ((LepA re 2008), (LepA re 2008), (Nowacki 2009)).
Non-mendelian epigenetic inheritance, independent from the germline ((Nowacki 2009)).
See Nowacki and Landweber 2009 reivew: Epigenetic inheritance in ciliates, for a wider overview of the field.

Together with the noncoding RNA BC040587 and the tumor suppressor gene LSAMP (limbic system-associated membrane protein), TUSC7 is present in the focal region of chr3q13.31 (osteo3q13.31), which is the most altered region in osteosarcomas (Mo 2013). Putative p53 response element ~ 1500kb upstream (Mo 2013).

Expression of TUSC7, LSAMP and BC040587 correlated with osteo3q13.31 copy number alterations (Mo 2013). Downregulated in colorectal cancers (CRCs) (Du 2013, Mo 2013). Low expression in CRCs correlated with larger tumor size, higher tumor stage, and more distant metastasis and poor disease-free survival(Du 2013). Inhibits CRC tumor cell growth in vivo and in vitro (Mo 2013). Expression predictive of disease free survival for CRC patients (Du 2013).

Depletion of LOC285194 by siRNA promoted proliferation of normal osteoblasts (with a mild increase in the G1 population) by cell-cycle transcripts (Cyclin D1, VEGF, and VEGFR1 up-regulation, and cyclin A2 and cyclin B1 suppression) as well as regulation of apoptotic genes (such as suppression of BCL2 and BimEL pro-apoptotic genes) (Mo 2013). Genetic deletions of LOC285194 or BC040587 in tumor DNA were also associated with dramatic decrease in survival of osteosarcoma patients (Mo 2013). TUSC7, LSAMP and BC040587 are proposed to be cooperatively acting tumor suppressors (Mo 2013). In CRC, TUSC7 is a p53 regulated tumor suppressor, acting partially through repression of miR-211, a promoter of cell growth. Exon 4 contains the active region for growth inhibition, and contains two miR-211 binding sites (Mo (2013).

~280 nucleotides, dimeric Alu sequence ((Kuryshev 2001)).
Same genetic locus has been targeted independently to create Alu derived BC200 and G22 genes in different primate lineages ((Kuryshev 2001), (Ludwig 2005)).

Transcribed in lorisiform brain ((Ludwig 2005)).
Localised to dendrites in a transgenic mouse ((Khanam 2006)).
Binds to poly(A) binding protein (PABP) and the SRP9/14 heterodimer ((Khanam 2006)).

Found in strepsirhini primates (Lemurs and Lorises) ((Kuryshev 2001)). However, G22 appears under selection only in lorisiformes (Galago moholi) ((Ludwig 2005)).
BC200, BC1 and G22 likely form a family of independently exapted repetitive elements which have evolved to carry out similar functions in different mammalian species ((Muddashetty 2002), (Khanam 2006)).
Galago moholi G22 can be found in REGION: 8494..8776 of AF314807. L13, (version in lemurs) can be found in REGION: 6983..7295 of AF314807.
contains an 815-nt (#1) or 752-nt (#2) long inverted repeat and stem-loop structure (Villegas 2007) covalently linked to the 5' end of the mitochondrial 16S RNA

Expressed in normal proliferating cells and tumor cells but not in resting cells (Villegas 2007). Expression inhibited by mitochondrial disruption (Burzio 2009). E6 and E7 oncogenes induce the expression of SncmtRNA-2 (Villota 2012) Detectable in Urine (Rivas 2012).

The transcript exits the organelle and localizes to the cytoplasm and the nucleus, where it can be found associated with chromatin and nucleoli (Landerer 2011). knockdown of SncmtRNA-1 induces inhibition of proliferation in SiHa and HeLa cells (Villota 2012)

Several isoforms of ~1.4, ~2 and ~3kb identified ((Uhde 2010)). Has splice variants, multiple alternative promoters ((Chodroff 2010)).
Intergenic, transcription start site contains a HeK4me3 locus ((Chodroff 2010)).

Expressed in specific regions of embryonic and post-natal mouse brain (see (Chodroff 2010) and (Uhde 2010) for details).
Expression in embryonic brain includes in â€œ ventral midbrain where dopaminergic neurons are formedâ€� ((Uhde 2010)). So Rmst may be a marker for developing dopaminergic neurons ((Uhde 2010)).
2kb transcript also expressed in adult brain, eye and lowly expressed in muscle and ovary ((Uhde 2010)).
Transcript found to be highly unstable with a half-life <2 hr in N2A (neuroblastoma) cells ((Clark 2012)).
DLG2AS: DLG2 antisense RNA PSZA11q14: putative schizophrenia associated gene from 11q14

Anti-sense to DLG2 intron.
~4.5kb and ~7kb unspliced transcripts differ in 3' position.
Contains a number of repeat sequences.
Despite its position in an intron, promoter elements could be identified upstream of the Dlg2as start site.

Expression downregulated in multiple brain regions in some patients with schizophrenia (by PCR).
Expression identified in a number of brain areas (by northern blot).
Near ubiquitous expression was identified in different brain areas and tissues (by PCR).
Some care must be taken interpreting the RT-PCR expression results as they appear to have been carried out with random hexamers and therefore may not differentiate between Dlg2as levels and detectable levels Dlg2 intron/ Dlg2 pre-mRNA. However the northern blot analysis does confirm expression of discrete transcripts from this intronic locus in different brain areas.
Sequence shows less than 50% homology with mouse.

Genbank accession: AF525782.1 for Dlg2as is incorrectly listed as an mRNA but is actually a ~10kb genomic clone containing Dlg2as.
Exact start and stop not defined but: Longer isoform (~7kb) appears to end around: chr11:84,604,583 (hg19) Shorter isoform (~4.5kb) around: chr11:84,602,058 (hg19)
Located at 6p21.2, consists of 3 exons, and contains SNP associated with esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) risk in eastern and southern Chinese populations ((Wu 2013)).

Found in both the nucleus and cytoplasm. Expressed in esophageal tissue. rs11752942A>G SNP results in higher expression levels, due to miRNA-149 being able to bind to the exon containing the SNP, negatively regulating its expression levels ((Wu 2013)).

ESCC cell poliferation and tumor growth inhibited by transcript binding miRNA-149. Transcript with rs11752942GG genotype could contribute to G2 phase arrest, suggesting a role in the cell cycle ((Wu 2013)).
mascRNA (MALAT1-associated small cytoplasmic RNA)

mascRNA is a conserved, 61 nucleotide, tRNA-like sequence at the 3' end of Malat1 that is cleaved off the full length transcript and processed to generate a short tRNA-like ncRNA.
Mature mascRNA undergoes a post-transcriptional CCA addition and folds into a tRNA like structure but could not be amino acylated.

mascRNA was cleaved off Malat1 in a wide variety of human tissues.
mascRNA is cleaved off Malat1 by RNaseP in the nucleus before further processing by RNaseZ and then exported to the cytoplasm.
Conserved in mammals and back to reptiles and amphibians. More highly conserved than most of Malat1.
RNCR3: Retinal noncoding RNA 3

Intergenic, four exon transcript in mouse.
Gene contains a highly expressed, brain specific microRNA (mir124a-1) in an exon ((Lagos-Quintana 2002)).

Dynamic expression in mouse retinal development ((Blackshaw 2004)).
Expressed throughout adult mouse brain with enriched expression in hippocampus subfields, Purkinje neurons of the cerebellum and the mitral layer of the olfactory bulb ((Mercer 2010)).
Up-regulated during differentiation of GABAergic neurons in culture but downregulated during oligodendrocyte differentiation ((Mercer 2010)).
LncRNA is conserved in mammals and overlaps the LOC157627 noncoding Refseq gene in humans ((Mercer 2010)).
Oct4, Nanog transcription factors are reported to bind to locus ((Guttman 2009)).
FENDRR was downregulated in gastric cancer cell lines and cancerous tissues, as compared with normal gastric epithelial cells and adjacent noncancerous tissue samples (Xu 2014).

Essential for proper heart and body wall development in the mouse (Grote 2013). FENDRR overexpression suppressed invasion and migration by gastric cancer cells in vitro by downregulating FN1 and MMP2/MMP9 expression (Xu 2014). Knockout of this lncRNA exhibits peri- and postnatal lethal phenotype (Sauvageau 2014). Located in a locus associated with lethal lung development disorders (Szafranski 2012).
Eosinophil granule ontogeny (EGO) RNA

Two isoforms: ~1.0kb unspliced EGO-A and ~1.5 kb spliced (two exons) EGO-B.
Transcribed antisense from a conserved intron of ITPR1 gene.

Highly expressed in human bone marrow CD34+ cells and BMMC (bone marrow mononuclear cells).
Highly upregulated during eosinophil development from CD34+ human hematopoietic stem cells before returning to basal levels within 72 hours. Despite a return to basal levels, EGO transcripts were present and inducible in mature eosinophils.

Proposed to affect myeloid development by regulating eosinophil gene expression, as knockdown of EGO in vitro in CD34+ cells decreases eosinophil granule protein MBP (major basic protein) and EDN (eosinophil derived neurotoxin) mRNA levels.
EGO and some of surrounding sequence is conserved. However the presence of EGO has not been investigated outside of humans.

205012bp. Found in GWAS locus associated with The HELLP syndrome. The HELLP syndrome is a pregnancy-associated disease inducing hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets in the mother. The HELLP locus is in an intergenic region on 12q23.2 between PMCH and IGF1.
Found to have expression in the (peri)nuclear region of extravillous trophoblast with the use of strand-specific RT-PCR complemented with RACE and FISH.
Activates a large set of genes that are involved in cell cycle (van Dijk (2012)).
1752bp RNA transcribed from the 8q24 region of the human genome containing the SNP rs6983267((Calin (2013))). A short 340bp variant also exists.

Overexpressed in non small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) ((Yin (2014))), breast cancers ((Calin (2013))), and microsatellite stable colorectal cancer (CRC) ((Calin (2013))). Expression associated with lung adenocarcinoma ((Yin (2014))). Combined with carcinoembryonic antigen, expression can predict lymph node metastasis in NSCLC ((Yin (2014))). Transcript levels are affected by SNP status, with the G allele resulting in increased transcription ((Calin (2013))). Downstream target of WNT ((Calin (2013))).

Promotes proliferation and invasion in NSCLC cell lines ((Yin (2014))), and CRC ((Calin (2013))). Promotes migration in breast cancers and down regulates chemosensitivity to 5â€™ FU ((Calin (2013))).Promotes chromosomal instability in CRC ((Calin (2013))). Up regulates MYC, miR17-5p and miR-20a by TCF7L2 mediated transcriptional regulation. Also physically interacts with TCF7L2, resulting in enhancement of WNT signalling activity ((Calin (2013))). The SNP, rs6983267, with the transcript has been identified by multiple GWAS and association studies as being associated with CRC ((Hsu (2013)), (Henderson (2007)), (Houlston (2007)), (Houlston (2008)), (Matsuda (2011))), prostate cancer ((Matsuda (2011)), (Easton (2008)), (Chanock (2008)), (Thomas (2007))) inflammatory breast cancer ((Olschwang (2012))) and ovarian cancer ((Dunning (2008))).
BMP/OP-responsive gene (BORG) RNA

~2.8kb. Spliced and polyadenylated RNA with three exons.
BORG RNA contains a number of repeat sequences.

Identified in a myoblast cell line (C2C12) trans-differentiating into osteoblastic cells.
Immediate early response gene to bone morphogenic proteins (BMPs), expressed within 2 hrs, peaked between 12-24 hours before declining back to basal levels.
Expression induced by BMPs and osteogenic proteins in multiple cell types that respond to BMP signaling.
Knockdown of BORG via transfection of antisense oligonucleotides partially inhibits BMP-induced differentiation of C2C12 cells into osteoblastic cells. Proposed involvement in bone morphogenesis.
Likely to be rodent specific as much of locus (and transcript) consists of rodent specific repeats. Unknown if a transcript is expressed in rat.
BMP: bone morphogenic protein OP: osteogenic protein
LXRBSV: Liver X receptor (LXR)-beta alternative splicing variant ((Hashimoto 2009)).

In mouse, LXRBSV is an alternative splicing isoform of LXR-beta that has a 270bp intronic sequence retained between exons 4 and 5 (or exons 2 and 3 depending on LXR-beta isoform). Quantitative expression and promoter reporter assays indicated that LXRBSV is preferentially transcribed and expressed in the pituitary ((Hashimoto 2010)).
5'-rapid amplification of cDNA ends (5'-RACE) produced a 677 bp PCR product and indicated that the transcriptional start site (TSS) of LXRBSV is located 40 bp downstream of LXR-beta's TSS ((Hashimoto 2010)).
A LXRBSV construct was translated as an approximately 22 kDa protein by in-vitro translation.

LXRBSV was detected in various tissues, such as liver and different regions of the brain (pituitary, hypothalamus, cerebrum, cerebellum). It was expressed at lower levels than LXR-beta ((Hashimoto 2009)).
Quantitative expression and promoter reporter assays indicated that LXRBSV is preferentially transcribed and expressed in the pituitary. LXRBSV expression in the whole brain and especially in the pituitary was significantly higher compared to that in the liver. This is in contrast to LXR-beta mRNA that showed similar expression in the liver and brain and significantly reduced expression in the pituitary and hypothalamus compared to liver ((Hashimoto 2010)).

LXRBSV acts as a specific transcriptional co-activator for LXR-beta to enhance its receptor-mediated transactivation. LXRBSV synergistically augmented ligand-dependent activation of the SREBP-1c promoter (Sterol Response Element Binding Protein-1c promoter), but not of thyroid hormone receptor (TR) and peroxidase proliferator and activating receptors (PPARs).
The intronic sequence inserted into LXRBSV is required for its transactivation activity.
LXRBSV protein was deduced to be 64 amino acids in length, but different evidence demonstrated that the alternative splicing transcript acts as a RNA co-activator: 1) a GAL4-LXRBSV fusion protein was not able to induce transactivation; 2) an ATG mutant of LXRBSV was able to induce transactivation as wild type, and 3) LXRBSV functions in the presence of cycloheximide ((Hashimoto 2009)).
Because the LXRB locus produces both functional protein-coding and regulatory RNA transcripts, it may be considered a 'bi-functional' locus.
PTENP1: PTEN Pseudogene 1

Processed pseudogene of PTEN tumour suppressor gene at 9p13.3 and ~3.9kb in length. Predominately polyA- ((Johnsson 2013)).PTENP1 "coding sequence" quite similar to PTEN but has lost start codon, while 3'UTR is ~1kb shorter than PTEN. Part of the PTENP1 3'UTR sequence is highly conserved compared to PTEN (~95%) with seed matches to the same miRNAs

Expressed in a very wide variety of human tissues and in prostate cancer. Good correlation between PTENP1 and PTEN levels.
Inhibition of endogenous miRNAs with seed matches to PTEN and PTENP1 leads to an increase in PTENP1 expression, validating it is targeted by miRNAs known to repress PTEN.

Competing endogenous RNA (ceRNA). PTENP1, through its 3'UTR, acts as a decoy for miRNAs that target PTEN.
PTNEP1 functions as a tumour suppressor gene.
Overexpression of the PTENP1 3'UTR lead to an increased level of PTEN and cellular growth inhibition, an effect dependent on the presence of mature miRNAs, supporting PTENP1's role as a miRNA decoy. While knockdown of PTENP1 lead to a decrease in PTEN levels and faster cell growth.
PTENP1 asRNA beta isoform forms an RNA-RNA interaction with PTENP1 sense and stabilizes it. This interaction promotes the function of PTENP1 sense as a positive regulator of PTEN mRNA levels, potentially by allowing the export of PTENP1 sense to the cytoplasm ((Johnsson 2013)).
The PTENP1 locus was lost in a subset of colon cancers and a relationship was reported between PTENP1 copy number and PTEN expression level.

Cells are very sensitive to levels of PTEN, with even subtle changes influencing cancer susceptibility ((Alimonti 2010)).
A wider role for pseudogenes as miRNA decoys/ sponges has been proposed.

Located in the 8q24 gene desert upstream of c-MYC (Chinnaiyan 2011). Predominately cytoplasmic, but a small proportion can be found in the nucleus (Feng (2014). Exists primarily as a single strand RNA, and secondarily as a RNA/DNA hybrid (Chinnaiyan 2011). Contains an Alu element, long terminal repeat promoter region and portions of a mariner family transposase(Chinnaiyan 2011).

Overexpressed in colorectal cancer (CRC) tissues compared to normal (Jia 2013). Repressed by Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2) (Chinnaiyan 2011). Upregulated in a subset of metastatic and high grade localised prostate cancers (Chinnaiyan 2011). Expression increases proliferation in prostate cancers(Chinnaiyan 2011).

High expression associated with a poorer survival rate in CRC (Jia 2013). Regulates cell response to genotoxic stress, impairing DNA damage repair (Chinnaiyan 2011, Feng (2014). Modulates the expression of ~370 genes, including BRCA2, CENPE, CENPF (Chinnaiyan 2011). Represses BRCA2, most likely through a post-transcriptional mechanism and not epigenetically, impairing homologous recombination of double strand DNA breaks (DSBs) (Feng 2014). Decreases in vivo prostate cancer tumor growth following PARP inhibition.

ERIC is regulated by endogenous E2F1 which, when knocked down, decreases the levels of ERIC in fibroblasts (Feldstein 2013). Expression of ERIC is highest in the G1 phase of the cell cycle (Feldstein 2013). DNA damage increases expression of ERIC (Feldstein 2013).
Decreased levels of ERIC leads to increased E2F1 and chemotherapy induced apoptosis, but knockdown by itself does not affect cell viability (Feldstein 2013).
Rian: RNA Imprinted and Accumulated in Nucleus Irm: Imprinted RNA near Meg3/Gtl2 MEG8: Maternally expressed gene 8

These overlapping but non-identical transcripts are found in the Dlk1-Dio3 imprinted region ((Hatada 2001), (Royo 2007), (Hagan 2009)) and should probably be viewed as different isoforms of the Rian gene. The human and mouse loci are quite similar, whereas the rat loci (Bsr gene) has undergone significant divergence and so has its own entry in the database.
Spliced lncRNAs that contain a number of intronic snoRNAs and sometimes miRNAs (CavaillÃ© (2002), (Royo 2007), (Hagan 2009)).
In human and mouse, transcription of the Meg8 isoform can extend through the snoRNA clusters. Mouse Meg8 is ~4.4kb with over 20 exons. In mouse the ~2.5 kb Irm transcript contains the last 10 exons of Meg8 but has its own transcriptional start site. Mouse Meg8 contains intronic miRNAs not found in Irm ((Hagan 2009)).
RNA sequencing confirms a large number of isoforms with alternative splicing and also retained introns exist at this locus though no evidence was found for Rian overlapping the Meg9/Mirg transcript ((Guttman 2010)). It is unclear if the Irm isoform exists in humans.

Imprinted: Maternally expressed ((Hatada 2001), (Charlier 2001), CavaillÃ© (2002)).
Expressed predominately in brain ((Hatada 2001)), embryo and muscle ((Charlier 2001)) with generally weak expression in other tissues ((Hagan 2009)). Expressed in mouse embryonic stem cells ((Guttman 2011)). In mouse the longer 'Meg8' transcript is also expressed in skin whereas the shorter 3' 'Irm' is not ((Hagan 2009)).
Up-regulated during differentiation of neuronal progenitors to GABAergic neurons in vitro ((Mercer 2010)).
Localised to the nucleus ((Hatada 2001)).
Intronic snoRNAs also show brain and embryo imprinted expression (CavaillÃ© (2002)).

LncRNAs contain a number of miRNAs and snoRNAs, little is known about the molecular function of the lncRNAs.
Rian transcript(s) bind to the PRC2 chromatin modifying complex in mouse embryonic stem cells ((Zhao 2010), (Guttman 2011)). Rian was also found to interact with a number of other chromatin binding protein(s)/complexes in mouse embryonic stem cells including PRC1, JARID1B, JARID1C and CBX3, with the general pattern being interaction with repressors of gene expression ((Guttman 2011)).
Aberrant repression of Rian and other maternally expressed lncRNAs from the DLK1-Dio3 imprinting cluster is present in most induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) lines and is responsible for the failure of iPSCs to form viable mice, with embryos dying mid-gestation ((Stadtfeld 2010)).

Bsr and Rian/MEG8/Irm are not highly conserved between species (CavaillÃ© (2002)). However, some Rian exons show good homology to Bsr and while many snoRNAs are specific to one species others are homologous ((Hatada 2001), CavaillÃ© (2002)).
Rian gene is present in mammals.

Comparing human, mouse and rat: All contain ncRNA gene(s) with intronic snoRNAs at this locus. The snoRNAs vary between species, but there are some homologous snoRNAs between each suggesting an evolutionary history with species specific snoRNA addition and duplication (CavaillÃ© (2002)).
The expression profiles of Bsr, Rian/Irm/MEG8 and the snoRNAs they contain are similar between rat, human and mouse.
Human UCSC browser link below is for Refseq Meg8, however it is clear from known human mRNAs that transcripts from the Meg8 locus can extend much further than the current Refseq annotation.
Pint is located in the nucleus. Downregulated in colorectal cancer compared to normal (MarAn-BAjar 2013).

Knockdown of Pint decreases cell viability in mouse embryoninc fibroblasts (MarAn-BAjar 2013). Pint knockdown leads to increase in apoptotic cells, while overexpression decreases the number of apoptotic cells (MarAn-BAjar 2013). ASOs for Pint increases the number of cells in G0/1phase and decreases numbers in S phase while overexpression of Pint leads to the opposite effect in cell cycle (MarAn-BAjar 2013). Pint is involved in regulating the expression of genes involved in the p53 pathway as well as genes for cell proliferation (MarAn-BAjar 2013). Pint is physically associated with Suz12, a subunit of PRC2, and Pint is involved in targeting PRC2 to certain genes (MarAn-BAjar 2013). Human PINT could work as a tumour suppressor by regulating p53 levels, and it is downregulated in colorectal cancer (MarAn-BAjar 2013).

located at 5q14.3, between GPR98 and ARRDC3. Consists of 4 exons, and contains a NF-E2 motif in its promoter (Wu 2013). A shorter transcript variant exists, which lacks three 3' exons and contains an alternate 3' exon.
Overexpressed in airway epithelium of cigarette smokers and in some lung cancer cell lines. Expression induced by cigarette smoke in a NRF2 dependent manner (Wu 2013).

Suggested role in mediating the cytoprotective function of NRF2 triggered by cigarette smoke. Chemical and oxidate stress activates NRF2, which binds to the pomoter of LUCAT1, altering its expression. siRNA knockdown of LUCAT1 resulted in decreased viability of lung cancer cells following exposure to cigarette smoke (Wu 2013).
Present in human diploid WI-38 fibroblasts (young) but not in PDF 52 fibroblasts (old) (Abdelmohsen 2013).
Reducing SAL-RNA1 levels enhanced senescence phenotype, including enlarged morphology, positive B-galactosidase activity, and heightened p53 levels (Abdelmohsen 2013).

Antisense to PHO84.
2 transcripts, one covers the entire PHO84 gene, the other is longer and extends into the YML122C (a short hypothetical ORF) locus. Both initiate transcription near the 3' of PHO84.

There was low expression of antisense transcripts constitutively but abundance increased in aged cells as PHO84 was silenced.
PHO84 antisense transcripts are degraded by the exosome, but increased in abundance in aged cells due to transcript stabilisation.

Summary: Silences PHO84 in aged cells
In aged cells exosome dissociates from PHO84 locus allowing the stabilisation and accumulation of PHO84 antisense transcripts.
Antisense RNAs recruit the histone deacetylase complex (Hda1, Hda2, Hda3) to the PHO84 locus, causing deacetylation and PHO84 silencing.
Blocking expression of full length PHO84 antisense transcripts prevented PHO84 silencing, demonstrating the antisense transcripts (not just transcription) was necessary for silencing.
Nb: not clear if PHO84 antisense binds HDAC complex directly.
PHO84 is an inorganic phosphate transporter

2849nt read-through long noncoding RNA overlapping EGLN2 and upstream of the RAB4B gene. Contains multiple SNPs associated with smoking behaviour (Furberg 2010), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (Cho 2011) and hepatocellular cancer (HCC) (Zhu 2012).

Expressed in HCC cell lines, highly expressed in particular in Hep3B. Expression levels correlae with EGLN2 in HCC tissue samples. Higher expression levels in HCC tissue samples and cell lines with the rs10680577 deletion allele (Zhu 2012).
Increases the expression of EGLN2 in vitro (Zhu 2012).

Originally classified as a cryptic unstable transcript (CUT) but now classed as a Xrn1-sensitive unstable transcript (XUT) ((van Dijk 2011))
Antisense to a Ty1 retrotransposon. Transcript initiates within Ty1 and is transcribed across the TY1 LTR (long terminal repeat) promoter sequence ((Berretta 2008)).
~400 nuc. Several initiations site, main site begins +661 nuc from the start of the LTR ((Berretta 2008)).
Transcribed by RNA polymerase II, polyadenylated ((Berretta 2008)).

Unstable, degraded by a cytoplasmic 5, to 3, degradation pathway including Xrn1, Dcp1 and Dcp2 ((Berretta 2008)).
Reversibly up-regulated by lithium ((van Dijk 2011))

Functions in trans to silence Ty1 retrotransposon and prevent its transposition ((Berretta 2008)).
Silencing requires histone deaceylation and Set1 histone methylation. Silencing causes a decrease in RNA polymerase II occupancy while TBP (TATA binding protein) is unchanged ((Berretta 2008)). While silencing appears to be antagonised by H3K4me3 ((van Dijk 2011)).
Case of a CUT/XUT RNA repressing a mobile element through transcriptional gene silencing ((Berretta 2008)).
Nb: Currently unclear exactly how silencing is mediated by RTL
Expressed in muscle cells, positively regulated by YY1 (Lu 2013). Downregulated upon differentiation and acts as an inhibitor of myogenesis (Lu 2013).
1556 bases; transcribed from the opposite strand of intron 1 of the human Fas gene.

Detected in several human tissues (such as heart, placenta, liver, muscle and pancreas, as well as kidney in lower levels). It was also detected in different cancer cell lines, including Jurkat (acute T-cell leukemia), MES-SA (uterine carcinoma) and U-937 (Histocytic Lymphoma); moderately expressed in CA46 (Burkitt,s lym- phoma), Raji (Burkitt,s lymphoma) and only slightly expressed in MG-63 (osteosarcoma).

In vitro over-expression of Saf protects cells from Fas-mediated apoptosis.
Over-expression of Saf induces alternative splicing of FAS transcripts, wherein an alternative exon overlapped by the antisense RNA is retained and non-adjacent 3' exons are skipped. This results in Fas proteins that are not able to anchor to the cell membrane, therefore regulating Fas-mediated but not TNF-alpha-mediated apoptosis.
Saf gene appears to be conserved among the primates and is absent in the rodents.

804 nucleotide, unspliced transcript, antisense to the 3' of tie1 in Zebrafish.
Tie-1as initiates just 3' of the tie-1 3'UTR, runs antisense through 3'UTR and into last exon.

Tie1-as and tie-1 show similar developmental expression patterns with both being up-regulated after gastrulation but tie-1 expression is ~10x higher.
At 24 hours post fertilisation (hpf), tie-1 and tie-1as are both expressed in some tissues but tie1-as is also expressed in brain and otic vesicles where tie1 is not expressed.
Genomic DNA downstream from tie1 3'UTR was shown to have promoter activity supporting the presence of an antisense transcript.

Overlapping region of tie1 and tie-1as appear to duplex in-vivo, which appears to reduce levels of the tie-1 transcript.
Overexpression of Zebrafish tie-1as in-vivo caused vascular defects during zebrafish development, while over-expression of human tie-1as caused defects in endothelial cell junctions in human cells.
Identified in zebrafish, similar transcripts may also be present in human and mouse.
Sequence and precise genome location of the transcripts have not been defined.
Abundantly expressed in the mouse neonatal heart (Klattenhoff (2013)).

Necessary for activation of a core cardiovascular gene network and functions upstream of mesoderm posterior 1 (MesP1) (Klattenhoff (2013)). Bvht interacts with SUZ12, a component of polycomb-repressive complex 2 (PRC2), during cardiomyocyte differentiation (Klattenhoff (2013)).

~1.6 kb transcript containing the RepA repeats ((Zhao 2008)). Repeats are internal to Xist, near the 5' end ((Wutz 2002)).
The RepA repeat sequence is expressed as part of full length Xist and as part of the shorter RepA transcript.
RepA repeats: 7.5 repeat units separated by spacers. Each repeat forms 2 stem loops ((Wutz 2002)).
RepA transcript is expressed prior to the onset of X-inactivation ((Zhao 2008)).

RepA repeats are required for X-chromosome silencing but not for localisation of Xist to the X-chromosome ((Wutz 2002)).
The repA transcript recruits polycomb repressor complex 2 (PRC2) to the inactive X chromosome, with Ezh2 serving as the RNA binding subunit ((Zhao 2008), (Zhao 2010)).
Recruitment of PRC2 by the RepA transcript allows deposition of HE-K27me3 marks at the Xist locus which is needed for up-regulation of full length Xist. Suggests the RepA transcript is necessary for the initiation of X-chromosome inactivation ((Zhao 2008)).
Sequence at 5' of Xist containing the A repeats and from where the separate RepA transcript is expressed show conservation throughout placental mammals.
693nt, 4 exons, located at chromosome 9 ((Flockhart 2012)).

Different expression patterns in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and melanomas. Over expressed in melanoma cells ((Flockhart 2012)). Under expressed in NSCLC tumour tissues ((Sun 2014)). Activated by BRAF protein ((Flockhart 2012)). Histone deacylation results in decreased expression in NSCLC ((Sun 2014)).

Potential role in melanoma cell migration, as siRNA knockdown reduces migration ((Flockhart 2012)). Reduced expression associated with larger tumour size, advanced pathological stage, metastasis distance, and shorter overall survival of NSCLC patients ((Sun 2014)).

Intergenic ~40kb 3â€™ from HoxA locus, transcribed back towards HoxA locus.
3-4 exons, alternative splicing ((Guttman 2010)).
Contains a number of repeat sequences.
Expressed in mouse embryonic stem cells (ESCs) and neural progenitors (NPCs) ((Guttman 2010)).

Involved in maintaining pluripotency in ESCs ((Guttman 2011)).
Knockdown in mECSs lead to down-regulation of Nanog, Oct4, Sox2, Klf4 and Zfp42 expression ((Guttman 2011)).
Found to interact with chromatin binding protein/complexes in mouse embryonic stem cells including SUV39H1 and CBX3 ((Guttman 2011)).
No evidence for expressed orthologue in human.
>2 kb, spliced, complementary (antisense) to the region extending from of the 3' end of exon 2 to the middle of intron 1 of the Msx1 gene ((Berdal 2002), (Blin-Wakkach 2001)).

Msx1as transcript is expressed in mouse embryos at E9.5 before the initial steps of skeleton morphogenesis and cell differentiation, and continuously up to birth ((Coudert 2005)). Expressed in differentiated dental and bone cells, being up-regulated during osteoblast differentiation and in developing tooth, bone and limb bud ((Coudert 2005), (Blin-Wakkach 2001), ID= 12489151). Also detected in hair follicles and neural tube, tissues where Msx1 are expressed ((Coudert 2005)).
Inversely correlated with Msx1 during mouse dental and bone differentiation with the two genes also showing a complementary spatial expression pattern ((Coudert 2005), (Blin-Wakkach 2001), (Berdal 2002)).
Msx1as transcript has also also detected by Northern blot analysis in dental epithelium and mesenchyme from a rat incisor ((Blin-Wakkach 2001)).

Over-expression of Msx1as in-vitro results in the reduction of Msx1 protein in a dose-dependent manner ((Berdal 2002)). Msx1as is proposed to negatively regulate Msx1 during craniofacial and skeleton development. ((Coudert 2005), (Blin-Wakkach 2001), (Berdal 2002))

Msx1as RNA has been detected in mice, rats, and humans. The transcription initiation site for Msx1as RNA was located by primer extension in both mouse and human in an identical region, including a consensus TATA box present in a highly conserved 66-bp region at the 3' UTR of Msx1 ((Blin-Wakkach 2001)).
The Msx1as putative TATA box is conserved in Msx2 cDNA sequences, suggesting a more general regulation pathway of the Msx gene family ((Blin-Wakkach 2001)).
Ene exon directly overlapps the first exon of the RFP2/LEU5 gene in the opposite orientation (Corcoran (2004)).

Negatively regulated by transcription factor BSAP (Kasar (2013)) and Pax5 (Chung (2008)). Derepression of the Dleu2 promoter in combination with BSAP knockdown increased malignant B-cell death (Kasar (2013)). Histone deacetylases inhibitor trichostatin A upregulate Dleu2 gene by increasing histone acetylation in lung cancer cells (Chen (2013)). Deleted in solid tumors and hematopoietic malignancies like chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) (Garding (2013)) (Tyybakinoja (2007)) (Migliazza (2001)). Altered expression of DLEU2 in hematological malignancies (Tagawa (2013)). Although previous reports show that DLEU2 negatively regulates the G1 Cyclins E1 and D1 through miR-15a/miR-16-1 (Lerner (2009)), expression of miR-15a/16- locus is independent of the DLEU2 host gene (Veronese (2014)).

The centromeric end of the locus where gene is located contains twice the expected amount of ALU repeats, whereas the telomeric end is LINE1 rich and contains four LINE1 elements longer than 4 kb, including two full-length LINE1 sequences. This feature of the sequence may favor the occurrence of chromosomal rearrangements and may confer instability to the region, resulting in deletionsof this tumor supressor (Bullrich (2001)).

Epigenetic aberrations on transcriptional start site of DLEU1 and DLEU2 are correlated with transcriptional deregulation of the neighboring candidate tumor suppressor genes (Garding (2013)). Deleted in lipomas (Creytens (2014)). Copy number variation clinically relevant in heamatological malignancies (Konialis (2013)).Deleted in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (Edelmann (2012)) (Stevens-Kroef (2009)) (Mertens (2009)) (Tyybakinoja (2007)) (Rowntree (2002)) (Rondeau (2001)) (Wolf (2001)) (Migliazza (2001)). Diminished expression or loss in Mycosis fungoides (MF), the most common cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (van Doorn (2008)). Downregulated in bone marrow cells from patients with the preleukaemic disorder Shwachman-Diamond syndrome (Rujkijyanont (2007)). Loss of DLEU1 region in multiple myeloma (Elnenaei (2002)) as well as head-and-neck squamous-cell carcinoma (Gupta (1999)).
Present in human mouse and rat.
LSINCT5 is a single exon transcript
The expression of LSINCT5 is upregulated in breast and ovarian tumours and cell lines with higher expression in the nucleus (Silva 2011).
Knockdown of LSINCT5 decreases the cell proliferation in cancer-derived cell lines (Silva 2011).

Sry is the male determining gene in mammals. Trigger testis formation. Member of the SOX gene family and known to encode a protein. For review see (Sekido 2012).
In mouse, Sry has long inverted repeats on either side of the Sry ORF. Transcriptional initiation within the 5' repeat extending through to the 3' repeat allows the formation of a stem loop structure, which promotes circularisation of the transcript. Transcription that starts after the 5' repeat gives rise to a linear Sry transcript (Dubin 1995), (Dolci 1997), (Sekido 2012).

A non-translated circular Sry transcript is expressed in mouse ((Capel 1993)).
Circular Sry is found in Setoli cells from 11.5 - 13.5 days post coitum ((Dolci 1997)) and in adult germ cells where it is expressed at high levels ((Capel 1993)).

Circular mouse Sry has 16 putative targets sites for miR-138 ((Hansen 2013)).
Circular mouse Sry appears able to interact with miR-138 and Ago2 acting as a microRNA sponge and potentially inhibiting the effects of miR-138 on other transcripts ((Hansen 2013)). Though the in-vivo impact of this action is not yet clear.
Sry appear to be a bi-functional gene with both protein coding and RNA functionality.
A circular Sry RNA has only identified in mouse and appears due to species specific long inverted repeats in the mouse Sry gene.

Ciliated protozoa contain two nuclei, a germline nucleus and a somatic nucleus. - The somatic nucleus is transcriptionally active but not passed on after fertilization. - The germline nucleus is transcriptionally inert in the mother cell but is transmitted to progeny. The new somatic nucleus is created from this germline nucleus ((Nowacki 2009)).
In Oxytricha trifallax creating the new somatic nucleus involves chromosomal fragmentation and deletion to remove ~95% of the genome ((Nowacki 2009)).
Hundreds of thousands of short sequences must then be "unscrambled" by reordering or inversion to create a compact somatic genome of nanochromosomes ((Nowacki 2009)).
This extremely specific and reproducible rearrangement has now been found to guided by maternal RNAs ((Nowacki 2009)).

Template/ Guide RNAs believed to arise from the maternal somatic nucleus ((Nowacki 2007)).
Long sense and antisense RNA transcripts, which appear to be transcribed full length nanochromsomes (contained telomere sequences), from the somatic nucleus were identified during early development when rearrangement is believed to be occurring ((Nowacki 2007)).

Maternal RNAs programming DNA rearrangements in progeny ((Nowacki 2007)).
Act as RNA guides or scaffolds to direct rearrangements. RNAi against them prevented unscrambling and injection of guides with altered gene sequences lead to the rearranged DNA containing the alteration ((Nowacki 2007)).
Cellular machinery required to carry out the DNA fragmentation and recombination is not fully understood but transposase proteins from Oxytricha trifallax transposons are required ((Nowacki 2009)).
Also found that mutations in guide RNA can be transferred to the rearranged somatic genome. Suggesting the presence of RNA directed DNA repair and also of DNA variants inherited via RNA without changing the germline genome ((Nowacki 2007)).

Non-mendelian epigenetic inheritance, independent from the germline ((Nowacki 2009)).
Inheritance of the somatic genome via a transient RNA genome separate to the nuclear germline DNA genome ((Nowacki 2009)).
See Nowacki and Landweber 2009 reivew: Epigenetic inheritance in ciliates, for a wider overview of the field.

Knockdown results in increased COL2,COL1 & agrecan expression and reduction MMP13 and ADAMTS5 in OA chondrocytes. OE in normal chondocytes has the opposite effect (confirmed by Western).((Liu 2014)) Acts at least in part by reducing expression of VIM (OE of VIM rescues effects of lncRNA-CIR knockdown. (Liu 2014)
PhyloCSF score of -5931 decibans
Xist: X inactive-specific transcript

Spliced, polyadenylated, ~17kb in mice, ~19kb in humans.
Contains repeated sequence motifs A-F that are critical for its function.
Xist is located on the X chromosome in the X-inactivation center (Xic), an approximately 100-kb region in the mouse containing (as of June 2012) five other lncRNAs, many of which play crucial roles in X-chromosome inactivation (XCI).
Xist expression initiates the process of XCI in mammals.

Xist is expressed in all somatic cells in female eutherian mammals, monoallelically from the inactive X-chromosome (Xi) ((Brown 1991)). Xist is not expressed in males
Xist is a nuclear RNA that coats the Xi ((Brown 1992), (Clemson 1996)).
In the mouse, Xist expression is imprinted at specific times and places in development: Xist is transcribed exclusively from the paternally-inherited X (and thus the paternal X is always the Xi) only in the early pre-implantation blastocyst, and later in development only in extra-embryonic tissues such as the placenta.
Imprinted XCI in humans has not been demonstrated and may not exist ((Moreira de Mello 2010)).
In somatic tissues in mouse and human, XCI is random, not imprinted: either the paternal or maternal X can express Xist and become the Xi. This decision is made in each cell of the epiblast in the mouse, and the same X is inactivated in subsequent generations of daughter cells. Thus expression of Xist (and of nearly all X-linked genes) is mosaic, in the sense that each of the two alleles is active in different populations of cells.
Stage specific expression in different regions of developing mouse retina, with Tsix displaying a similar but weaker profile ((Blackshaw 2004)).
In female undifferentiated mouse ES (embryonic stem) and iPS (induced pluripotent stem) cells, Xist is not expressed and both X chromosomes are active. Differentiation of mouse ES cells results in the onset of Xist expression and XCI, and thus these cells are an important model system for the study of XCI.
In contrast, Xist expression and XCI are variable in female undifferentiated human ES cells ((Shen 2008), (Silva 2008), (Hall 2008), (Lengner 2010)) and iPS cells ((Bruck 2011), (Hanna 2009), (Marchetto 2010), (Tchieu 2010)), which may reflect variability in the broader epigenetic states and developmental potential of these cells.

Xist is the master regulator of mammalian XCI, the mechanism of dosage compensation that balances X-linked gene expression between males and females.
Xist function is required to initiate XCI ((Penny 1996), (Marahrens 1997)). Ectopic Xist expression from an autosomal transgene causes long-range gene repression in cis ((Wutz 2000)).
Xist and RepA (see associated components below) RNAs bind to and recruit PRC2, which catalyzes the deposition of the repressive chromatin mark H3K27me3 on the Xi ((Zhao 2008), (Kaneko 2010), (Kanhere 2010), (Zhao 2010), (Guil 2012)).
Small RNAs formed from Xist/Tsix duplexes may play a role in regulating Xist expression and XCI ((Ogawa 2008)). However, loss of Dicer has only a modest effect on Xist expression ((Kanellopoulou 2009)), contrary to what would be expected if RNAi is a major regulator of XCI.
hnRNP U (also known as SP120 or SAF-A) binds Xist through its RGG domain while the SAF domain is also required for localisation to the Xi. hnRNP U is required for both Xist localisation to the Xi and the initation of X-inactivation ((Hasegawa 2010).
Xist Repeat C sequences are required for Xist localization to the Xi ((Beletskii 2001), (Sarma 2010)).
YY1 can interact with several DNA binding sites within exon 1 of Xist, and also to the repeat C (and perhaps repeat B) RNA sequences of the Xist transcript. Thus YY1 tethers Xist RNAs to the Xi and nucleates the Xist cloud that coats the Xi ((Jeon 2011)).
Xist forms a transcriptionally silenced sub-nuclear domain ((Chaumeil 2006)) and perinucleolar localisation of the silent Xist coated chromosome has been observed ((Zhang 2007)). The A region repeats are essential for the recruitment of late inactivated X genes to the silencing compartment and for the recruitment of the silencing complex PRC2 ((Maenner 2010)).
After the initiation of XCI, Xist function is not absolutely required to maintain XCI in fibroblasts ((Csankovszki 1999)). Nor is continued Xist expression required to maintain XCI-like repression around an autosomal Xist transgene in male, differentiated ES cells ((Wutz 2000)). However, lack of Xist function in differentiated cells can lead to partial reactivation of select X-linked genes ((Csankovszki 2001)).

Xist is present in all eutherian (placental) mammals examined to date, but it is not present in marsupials or monotremes ((Duret 2006), (Davidow 2007), (Hore 2007), (Shevchenko 2007)). An unrelated ncRNA in marsupials, Rsx, is likely to play a role similar to that of Xist in XCI ((Grant 2012)).
The most conserved Xist RNA region, the A region, contains eight or nine repeats separated by U-rich spacers.
Thanks to Derek Lessing and other members of the Lee lab for writing the majority of this entry.
3 exons
Expressed in liver cells and liver cancer. Expression increased upon stimulation with Trichostatin A. (Yang (2013))
Knockdown reduces TSA-induced apoptosis of Huh7 cells. TSA-induced apoptosis is uc002mbe.2 dependent.
SOX2OT: SOX2 overlapping transcript

SOX2OT holds within one of its introns the single-exon SOX2 gene, overlapping in the same transcriptional orientation ((Fantes 2003)).
Sox2ot has multiple transcription start sites, and several splicing isoforms and polyadenylation sites ((Amaral 2009)).
Mouse full-length clones range in size from 638 nt (GenBank accession no. BY721402) to ~3.5 kb (accession no. AK031919), consistent with Northern blot signals in mouse tissues, which show a major band of ~3kb, but also additional discrete bands of ~1, 4, 6, and >10 kb. In zebrafish embryos, Northern blot analysis showed a major band of ~2.5 kb, as well as less intense bands of ~1.5 and ~6 kb ((Amaral 2009)).
Alternative transcriptional start sites for Sox2ot homologs detected in different vertebrates are associated with highly conserved elements, transposon-free regions and histone modifications typical of promoters. These include a distal promoter that creates a Sox2ot isoform named Sox2dot ("Sox2 distal overlapping transcript"), located more than 0.5Mb upstream of the Sox2 gene in mouse ((Amaral 2009)), and which also has demonstrated enhancer activity in mouse developing forebrain.

Sox2ot is a stable transcript expressed in mouse embryonic stem cells, which, like Sox2, is down-regulated upon induction of embryoid body (EB) differentiation, but, unlike Sox2, is up-regulated during EB late differentiation. Sox2ot absolute levels are higher in cultured neurospheres, and Sox2 and Sox2ot are concordantly up-regulated in differentiated neurospheres. Sox2dot isoform is expressed at very low levels in undifferentiated neurospheres, but with a marked increase in the more differentiated neurospheres.
In situ hybridization analysis of mouse brain sections of Sox2ot and Sox2dot expression detected both transcripts in zones of adult neurogenesis, such as the subventricular zone, rostral migratory stream and olfactory bulb (where Sox2dot is most highly expressed) ((Mercer 2008), (Amaral 2009)).
Many Sox2ot isoforms are present in whole embryo and newborn mouse. In adult mouse, different isoforms are detected primarily in brain, but also at lower levels in tissues where Sox2 is detected, such as lung, or not detected, such as testis. In adult tissues, Sox2dot was only detected in brain.
Highly enriched binding of neuronal transcriptional repressor NRSF/REST has been found in conserved sites upstream of Sox2ot.
Sox2ot is dynamically regulated during chicken and zebrafish embryogenesis, consistently associated with central nervous system structures, including fish embryo eyes, but also mesoderm tissues. During chicken development, increasing levels ofSox2ot were observed after 2days of embryonic development, similar to the pattern observed for Sox2, although with lower absolute expression levels. Expression of both Sox2 and Sox2ot was enriched to the head of 6.5-d chicken embryos, compared to the limbs and whole body. In fish, sox2 and sox2ot presented concordant up-regulation after the sphere stage, suggesting that both are early zygotic genes, but their expression patterns diverged after the tailbud stage when sox2ot total levels decreased. Sox2dot is expressed at very low levels in early embryos, but is dramatically induced at 5 dpf.
In humans, qRT-PCR analysis showed that SOX2OT is highly enriched in the brain, where SOX2 is also predominantly expressed, but also detected in other tissues such as testis. The distribution of SOX2OT ESTs in human tissues also showed a high predominance in CNS libraries, with greatest enrichment in "lens," followed by subthalamic nucleus and Alzheimer cortex, while it is found in lowest relative abundance in cerebellum ((Amaral 2009)).

Function of Sox2ot is undetermined. SOX2OT is a candidate gene involved in myopia, as upstream or intronic regions of Sox2ot isoforms were identified as a myopia common susceptibility locus by linkage disequilibrium analysis ((Andrew 2008)).

Isoforms are positionally conserved in vertebrates. At primary sequence level, although not highly conserved overall, there are regions of high conservation, such as a 384nt-stretch in the exons immediately flanking Sox2 with 91.2% identity between the mouse and human genomes ((Amaral 2009)).
Some exons of SOX2OT may be species- or clade-specific ((Amaral 2009)).
Multiple SOX2OT promoters are associated with highly conserved elements in vertebrates and orthologous transcripts are detected with transcription start sites of transcripts detected in fish, amphibians, reptiles and mammals ((Amaral 2009)).
983 nucleotides, unspliced. Contain regions that display significant Z-score values for potential secondary structures, which span > 8% of its total length ((Hirsch 2006)).
Broadly expressed in all tissues analyzed (roots, rosettes, stems, inflorescences, etc) ((Hirsch 2006)).

Overexpression of npc48 in Arabidopsis thaliana led to strong leaf serration (a symptom of defects in cell proliferation along the margins of leaf primordia). Plants overexpressing npc48 showed other drastic developmental anomalies, including an increase in the rosette diameter and a delay in flowering time compared with wild-type plants.
The phenotype of npc48-over-expressing plants resembles that of plants over-expressing MIR168, which have reduced levels of the miR168 AGO1 target, and of AGO1-sensitive miRNAs such as miR166. They also show decreased miR166 accumulation, but presence of AGO1 mRNA and miR168 at wild-type levels.
In addition, npc48 plants exhibited reduced accumulation of miR164, suggesting that npc48 could regulate a subset of miRNAs. Interestingly, mir164a mutants also display abnormal serrations of the leaf margins, which are milder than the serrations induced by overexpression of npc48, suggesting that the reduction in miR164 alone cannot account for the phenotype.
Over-expression of npc48 did not have a general effect on miRNAs or AGO1 accumulation ((Ben Amor 2008)).

2-4 exon transcript terminates 4kb upstream from Myosin IG (Myo1G). No evidence the transcripts join.
Alternative splicing and potentially alternative initiation sites.
Transcripts contain repeat sequences.
SnoRNA host gene, sequence homologous to human SNORA9 present in one intron.
Expressed in mouse embryonic stem cells (ESCs) ((Guttman 2010)).

Found to interact with a number of chromatin binding proteins/complexes in mESCs including PRC1, PRC2, JARID1B, SUV39H1, SETD8 and CBX1, with the general pattern being interaction with repressors of gene expression ((Guttman 2011)).

Poorly conserved except for intronic snoRNA.
In syntenic position is human C7orf40, though there is little sequence conservation.

Several lncRNA transcripts, alpha, beta and unspliced, expressed antisense to PTENP1 pseudogene (also known as PTENpg1)
Alpha and beta isoforms are, at least, four exon transcripts that differ in the position of the transcription start site (TSS). Alpha isoform initiates 5' and so has a longer first exon.
Unspliced isoform initiates transcription from alpha TSS.
Spliced transcripts show evidence of alternative splicing of exon 3.

Alpha and beta spliced isoforms found predominately in cytoplasm and polyA +. Unspliced alpha isoform was predominately in nucleus and polyA-.
Expression of PTENP1 asRNAs negatively correlates with expression of PTEN coding gene and positively correlates with PTENP1 sense pseudogene expression. Combined, the PTENP1 asRNAs generally showed higher expression than the sense PTENP1 pseudogene.
AsRNAs expressed in a number of cell lines including HEK293T, U2OS, A375 and DU145.

PTENP1 asRNA alpha: Inhibits transcription of the PTEN coding gene (knockdown caused up-regulation of PTEN, while asRNA alpha overexpression inhibited PTEN mRNA levels).
PTENP1 asRNA alpha acts in trans by localising to the PTEN coding gene promoter and inhibiting expression. Repression of PTEN by PTENP1 asRNA alpha also involves EZH2 and DNMT3A. PTENP1 asRNA alpha binds DNMT3A (DNA methylase) and is required for the deposition of repressive H3K27me3 chromatin marks at the PTEN promoter.
PTENP1 asRNA alpha regulation of PTEN is functionally significant. Loss of asRNA alpha leads to increased PTEN and p21 protein levels, negatively regulating the cell cycle and also sensitizing cells to apoptosis.
PTENP1 asRNA beta: PTENP1 asRNA beta isoform forms an RNA-RNA interaction with PTENP1 sense and stabilizes it. This interaction promotes the function of PTENP1 sense as a positive regulator of PTEN mRNA levels, potentially by allowing the export of PTENP1 sense to the cytoplasm.
Summary: PTENP1 asRNA alpha and beta have different functions. Alpha negatively regulating PTEN transcription and beta positively regulating PTEN mRNA post-transcriptionally through PTENP1 sense. Sense and antisense transcrips from PTEN pseduogene regulate both transcription and translation of PTEN.
Not clear if 3' ends of various isoforms are known. BX374997 EST, which appears to initiate at beta start site may not be full length.
Hox antisense intergenic RNA

2.2 kb; spliced, polyadenylated and comprised of 6 exons in humans ((Rinn 2007)).
Transcribed from the HOXC locus from a position intergenic and antisense to the flanking HOXC11 and HOXC12 genes ((Rinn 2007)).

Expressed in posterior and distal fibroblasts ((Rinn 2007)).
Expression level in cancer is an efficient predictor of metastasis and survival with high expression levels predictive of poor outcomes ((Gupta 2010)). Also in patients with stage IV colorectal cancer (CRC), HOTAIR expression levels were higher in cancerous tissues than in noncancerous tissues, with high HOTAIR expression tightly correlated with the presence of liver metastasis and associated with poor prognosis ((Kogo 2011)) .
Some HOTAIR transcripts localise to the nucleus ((Khalil 2009)).
In situ hybridization analysis of the mouse cognate RNA (mHotair) showed expression similar to Hoxc11, with distinct levels in parts of the proximal hindlimbs, genital bud and tail in embryos at E11.5, as well as in in posterior part of the hindlimb and genital bud at E12.5 ((Schorderet 2011)).
Transcript found to be quite unstable with a half-life >4 hr in human Hela cells ((Tani 2012)).

Originally identified as silencing the HoxD locus but has since been found to epigenetic silence gene expression at many sites across the genome by recruitment of PRC2 and LSD1/CoREST/REST repressive chromatin modifying complexes ((Rinn 2007), (Tsai 2010)).
HOTAIR acts as a scaffold for protein complexes. A 5' domain binds PRC2 while a 3' domain binds LSD1 ((Tsai 2010)).
Oncogene - regulates metastatic progression ((Gupta 2010))((Schorderet 2011)).
HOTAIR dysregulated in breast cancer with frequent overexpression in metastases. Overexpression of HOTAIR leads to PRC2 re-targeting across the genome to a state similar to that in embryonic fibroblasts, promoting tumour invasion and metatasis. Oncogenic effects of HOTAIR upregulation were dependent on PRC2 ((Gupta 2010)).
Deletion of the HoxC cluster containing the cognate Hotair transcript in mouse showed little phenotypic effect, with little change in the expression on levels of H3K27me3 coverage in corresponding human HOTAIR Hoxd target genes ((Schorderet 2011)).

HOTAIR exists in mammals but with poor sequence conservation ((Rinn 2007))((He 2011)). A 239 bp domain in HOTAIR exon 6 is especially conserved in mammals ((He 2011)).
The mouse EST (AK035706) homologous to human HOTAIR is comprised of two exons only, with the second half of the first exon showing similarity to exon 4 of HOTAIR, whereas the second exon is homologous to exon 6 of HOTAIR ((Schorderet 2011)). This may underlie differences in function since the first three exons of HOTAIR (absent from mHotair) contain binding sites for EZH2, while the 3' extremity of human HOTAIR that interact with LSD1 is part of the least conserved DNA sequence within mHotair exon 2 ((Schorderet 2011)).
lncRNA-BGL3 is located between HBBP1 and HBG1. It consists of a single exon.
The expression of lncRNA-BGL3 is upregulated after knockdown of the Bcr-Abl hybrid gene which is present in 90% of Chronic Myeolid Leukemia (CML) (Guo 2014).

Treatment with Imatinib, an Abl tyrosine kinase inhibitor, decreases the viability to 35% in lncRNA-BGL3 overexpressed cell lines compared to 54% normal cell lines, and silencing lncRNA-BLG3 increased the viability of K562 cells treated with imatinib (Guo 2014). Tumour grotwh in xenograph mice injected with lncRNA-BGL3 overexpressed k563 cells was slower compared to contorl, while tumour growth increased after depletion of lncRNA-BGL3 (Guo 2014). The lncRNA also regulates the levels of PTEN by functioning as a ceRNA which binds miRNAs (miR-17, miR-20a, miR-20b, miR-93, miR-106a and miR-106b) targeting PTEN mRNA (Guo 2014). lncRNA-BGL3 is methylated by c-MYC (Guo 2014).
sfRNA: subgenomic flavivirus RNA

0.3-0.6 kb. Derived from the 3' untranslated region of the RNA genome (gRNA) of Flaviviruses ((Urosevic 1997)).
Contains a 5'-proximal stable hairpin (nt 6 to 56), the conserved flavivirus 3'-cyclization motif (nt 413 to 420) and the 3'-terminal long stable hairpin structure (nt 440 to 523) ((Lin 2004)). The stable RNA structures, which include multiple pseudoknots ((Olsthoorn 2001)), located at the beginning of the 3' untranslated region render this RNA resistant to nucleases ((Funk 2010), (Silva 2010), (Pijlman 2008)).

Present in infected tissues, such as the brain of mice after an intracerebral challenge with Murray Valley encephalitis (MVE) virus ((Urosevic 1997)).
In infected mammalian BHK-21 cells, the viral genome was detected as early as 24 h postinfection, and sfRNA was detected as early as 28 h postinfection, at levels 0.25 to 1.5 times as abundant as the genome RNA on a molar basis between 28 and 48 h postinfection. In mosquito C6/36 cells, the genome RNA and sfRNA were present 5 days postinfection and the small RNA was 1.25 to 5.14 times as abundant as the genome ((Lin 2004)).

Required for viral cytopathicity and pathogenicity ((Pijlman 2008)).
Transfection of sfRNA and reporter assays indicated that sfRNA modulates viral translation and replication in trans ((Fan 2011)).

Highly conserved among Flaviviruses, with primary sequence conservation concentrated at the loop regions of the secondary structure and at 27 nucleotides immediately adjacent to the 5' side of the structure ((Brinton 1986))
sfRNA subgenomic fragments result from incomplete degradation of the viral genome by the host 5'-3' exonuclease XRN1 ((Silva 2010)).

Several genomic locations for megamind homologues are possible in vertebrate genomes and many vertebrates have more than one homologous copy.
Three possible positions for megamind homolgoues have been identified: (1) Antisense to birc6 intron, â€œ(2) gene desert upstream of bdkrb1/,2 and (3) near hhipl1 homologs (found only in fish genomes)". All contain a conserved region near the 5â€™ of the final exon.
Zebrafish has expressed transcripts at all 3 loci, humans have (1) and (2).

Zebrafish linc-birc6: 2.4kb, 3 exons, alternative splicing. Antisense to intron of birc6. 5â€™ of last exon alignable and contains a highly conserved region.
Human (antisense birc6) - full length transcript has not been characterised, at least 2 exons, 5â€™ of second exon contains the highly conserved region.
Human LOC100507043 (upstream of BDKRB2) - ~3.2 kb, 2 exons, 5â€™ of second exon contains the highly conserved region.
Mouse 2810011L19Rik (upstream of BDKRB2) - 3.3 kb, 3 exons, 5â€™ of final exon contains the highly conserved region.

Linc-birc6 was most highly expressed of zebrafish megamind homolgoues. Expressed in zebrafish nervous system. Brain and eye at 24 hours post fertilization (hpf), brain only at 72 hpf.
Expressed in brain in mammals.

Linc-birc6 was required for normal embronyic brain development in Zebrafish. Morpholinos to decrease transcript level or block conserved site had brain and eye development defects. - Lack of functional megamind at 48 hpf caused â€œsmaller heads and eyes, enlarged brain ventricles (a hydrocephalic phenotype), and loss of NeuroD-positive cells in the retina and tectum.â€�
Defects could be recused by mature zebrafish megamind transcript (linc-birc6) as well as the mouse (AK012713, upstream of BDKRB2) and human (BX093813, antisense BIRC6) orthologues.
Conserved site was necessary, but not sufficient, to explain megamind function in zebrafish.
Has core highly conserved region in vertebrates of 93 nt. 15 of conserved nucleotides are Tâ€™s with 3 nt periodicity.
Antisense Igf2r RNA

108 kb (unspliced). Transcribed from an antisense promoter located in intron 2 of the Igf2r (insulin-like growth-factor type-2 receptor) gene ((Lyle 2000), (Wutz 1997)).
Also a number of spliced isoforms from 500bp to ~1.4kb ((Seidl 2006)).
Imprinted, expressed only from paternal allele ((Wutz 1997), (Lyle 2000)).

Expressed during embryonic development, in the placenta ((Wutz 1997), (Lyle 2000)), adult brain, lung and heart ((Seidl 2006)).
Expressed in glial cells of the developing brain but not in neurons, explains lack of Igf2r imprinting in these neurons. ((Yamasaki 2005))
Unspliced Air is unstable, localised to the nucleus. Spliced isoforms, found in nucleus and cytoplasm, are more stable ((Seidl 2006)).

Regulates genomic imprinting of a cluster of autosomal genes (Igf2r, Slc22a2 and Slc22a3) in cis, on mouse chromosome 17 ((Sleutels 2002)).
Truncation of Air disrupts imprinting not only of Igf2r but also the nearby non-overlapping genes Slc22a2 and Slc22a3, leading to mice with a lower birth weight ((Sleutels 2002)).
Air RNA forms a "cloud" over the imprinted DNA locus, binding to chromatin. Recruits G9a histone methyltransferase to epigenetically silence Slc22a3 ((Nagano 2008)). Igf2r is not silenced by this mechanism.
Nb: Slc22a3 and Slc22a2 are only imprinted at a specific time point in placental development. Outside of this time point the Air "cloud"/ Air chromatin binding and repressive histone modification are not found on these gene loci ((Nagano 2008)).
All characterisation been carried out in mouse. Recently Air has been identified in human ((Yotova 2008)) but full length transcripts have yet to be characterised.

Nb: Genebank and NCBI Gene sequences for Air are all for the spliced mouse isoforms. See http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gene/104103. UCSC browser link below is for transcript variant 3 which covers a similar length to the unspliced transcript. (Brosens 2012)

Found in an intron of KCNIP4 in the sense direction.
~2.3kb clones were identified in pig and human. NCRNA00099 which contains UM9-5 is ~10kb. Given it's position in an intron the full length of the transcript is somewhat unclear, cloning gave shorter transcripts, while transcription could be detected over whole NCRNA00099 site (but not outside it) in human.
Transcript contains a number of repeats.

Identified as a RNA that is more highly expressed in adult brain than fetal brain.
Expression in human and pig was similar. Mostly restricted to adult brain, highest expression in cerebellum.
Low expression was also detected in porcine embryonic tissues
Transcripts identified in pig and human. Southern blotting also could identify a homologous sequence in cow but not in rodents.

KCNIP4 is a voltage-gated potassium (Kv) channel-interacting protein which is expressed in brain.
UM9-5 accessions: AY072607, AY072608, AY072609, AY072610 and AY072611
CAR10: Chromatin Associated RNA 10
Positioned between 3' ends of of FANK1 (fibronectin) and ADAM12 (ADAM metallopeptidase domain 12) genes, with an overlap of a few hundred base pairs with ADAM12.

CAR Intergenic 10, ADAM12 and FANK1 are co-expressed in different tissues, including placenta, brain and a human skin fibroblast (HF) cell line.
CAR Intergenic 10 was most highly expressed in HF cells and very lowly expressed in brain, with placenta in-between.

Positively regulates gene expression of FANK1 and ADAM12 neighboring genes through modulating the chromatin structure in cis, as siRNA knock-down of the Intergenic10 ncRNA results in reduced expression of both FANK1 and ADAM12 mRNAs, with a significant decrease in the level of active chromatin mark H3K4me2 on FANK1 and ADAM12 promoters.
Knock-down of the ncRNA had no effect on the expression of two tested distal genes, UROS and DOCK1.
Note: Despite its overlap with the 3' end of ADAM12, Intergenic 10 is not simply an Adam12 3'UTR, as siRNA knockdown of Adam12 failed to decrease FANK1 expression unlike knockdown of CAR Intergenic 10.
BACE1 antisense RNA

~2 kb; two splice variants were identified for human and mouse BACE1-AS. Transcribed from an intron of the beta-secretase-1 (BACE1) gene in antisense direction it also completely overlapps exon 6 of BACE-1 ((Faghihi 2008)).

BACE1 and BACE1AS are co-expressed in a wide range of tissues and cell lines in mice and humans. BACE1 mRNA expression levels are higher than BACE1-AS levels across all tissues examined, except in Alzheimer's disease (AD) where, in contrast, BACE1-AS is expressed at a higher level in brain. Bace1 and Bace1-AS transcripts are also observed in various regions of the mouse brain ((Faghihi 2008), (Faghihi 2010)).
Several cell stressors, such as high temperature, serum starvation, amyloid-beta 1-42, H2O2 and high glucose, specifically increase BACE1-AS RNA and BACE1 protein levels ((Faghihi 2008)).
Showed increased expression in sporadic inclusion-body myositis (s-IBM) muscle fibers (possibly caused by endoplasmic reticulum stress). Nevertheless, unlike in AD and AD-transgenic mouse brain samples in which BACE1-AS transcript was increased more than the sense BACE1 transcript , in s-IBM muscle biopsies the reversed was found ((Nogalska 2010)).
Mouse RNA stability was very close to median for lncRNAs, with a half-life 3.6 hr in N2A (neuroblastoma) cells ((Clark 2012)).

BACE1AS expression is elevated in Alzheimers disease ((Faghihi 2008)). It was shown to regulate BACE1 mRNA and protein expression in vitro and in vivo ie: over-expression, shRNA and siRNA knockdown of BACE1AS affected BACE1 expression, influencing amyloid-beta 1-42 levels ((Faghihi 2008)).
It was proposed that BACE1-AS and BACE1 form an RNA duplex and this increases the stability of BACE1 ((Faghihi 2008)). More recently, it was suggested that BACE1AS may prevent translational repression of BACE1 mRNA by miR-485-5p via masking the binding site for the microRNA. Supporting this hypothesis, BACE1AS over-expression prevented miRNA-induced suppression ((Faghihi 2010)). Expression of BACE1-AS as well as miR-485-5p are dysregulated in RNA samples from Alzheimer's disease subjects compared to control individuals ((Faghihi 2010)).
BACE1-AS may also be involved in sporadic inclusion-body myositis (s-IBM), whose muscle-fiber phenotype shares molecular similarities with Alzheimer-disease brain (including increased BACE1 protein). BACE1-AS and BACE1 transcripts are significantly increased in s-IBM, and experimental induction of endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress increased both BACE1-AS and BACE1 transcripts. These results suggest that ER stress and increased BACE1-AS expression may be involved in s-IBM ((Nogalska 2010)).
BACE1-AS transcript has been identified in mouse and humans, with a conserved association with BACE1 across species ((Faghihi 2008)).
Mouse AK078885 and human CB960709 full-length clones are unspliced and are ~1.2kb- and 798b-long, but two spliced variants were extended by RACE by Faghini et al., 2008.

~1.6 kb in humans with a number of splice isoforms and evidence of retained introns creating longer transcripts ((Miyoshi 2000), (Zhang 2009)).
Similar situation in mouse and sheep with ~2kb - ~10kb transcripts due to alternative splicing, alternative 5' and 3' ends and retained introns. ((Schuster-Gossler 1998), (Bidwell 2001), (Hagan 2009)).
Imprinted: Maternally expressed from the Dlk1-Gtl2 imprinted locus ((Schuster-Gossler 1998), (Miyoshi 2000)).

Expressed in a temporal and spatially regulated manner: expressed early in mouse embryos in visceral yolk sac and embryonic ectoderm. Later in paraxial mesoderm, epithelial ducts, and also in skeletal muscle, cochlea, brain and eye ((Schuster-Gossler 1998), (Manji 2005)).
Dynamically expressed during mouse CNS development. This includes expression during retinal development ((Blackshaw 2004)) and in many developing forebrain areas including the "diencephalon, ventral telencephalon, post mitotic cell layers of the neocortex and pyramidal cell layer of the hippocampus" ((McLaughlin 2005)). Also found to be up-regulated during differentiation of neuronal progenitors to GABAergic neurons in vitro ((Mercer 2010)).
Expressed in adult brain ((Miyoshi 2000)) but in a more restricted manner ((McLaughlin 2005)).
Isoform Meg3a is detected in human normal pituitary gland, but is absent in nonfunctioning pituitary adenomas ((Zhang 2003)).
Expressed in the nucleus accumbens of normal human brains and upregulated in this brain region in heroin abusers ((Michelhaugh 2010)). Conversely, levels are decreased in the caudate nucleus of patients suffering from the neurodegenerative condition, Huntington's disease ((Johnson 2011)).
See cited papers for a more detailed analysis of developmental and tissue specific expression.

Localisation was generally nuclear, but some cells showed localisation to the cytoplasm or to both compartments ((Schuster-Gossler 1998)). In the nucleus Meg3 has been found associated with chromatin ((Mondal 2010)).

Expression of Meg3 is stimulated by cyclic-AMP (cAMP). cAMP stimulates CREB transcription factor(s) to bind a cyclic-AMP-response element (CRE) in the proximal promoter which is important for Meg3 expression. Methylation of this promoter region blocks cAMP action ((Zhao 2006)).

Summary: Meg3 is important for proper growth and development and is a putative tumour suppressor which functions to activate p53 and inhibit cell proliferation. Meg3 can also control gene expression at imprinted loci through recruitment of the PRC2 complex.
Function in Cancer: Expression of the Meg3a splicing isoform was silenced in pituitary tumours and ectopic expression was found to inhibit growth in human cancer cells, leading to the proposition that Meg3 RNA acts as a growth suppressor ((Zhang 2003)).
Silencing of Meg3 is associated with meningioma pathogenesis and progression while ectopic expression inhibited growth and stimulated p53 ((Zhang 2010)).
Meg3 knock-out increased expression of VEGF (Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor) signaling pathway genes in the brain, suggesting the RNA has a role in the control of vascularization, and therefore may function as a tumor suppressor in part by inhibiting angiogenesis ((Gordon 2010)).
Mechanism of action: Meg3 stimulates p53 expression and can also inhibit cell proliferation/ DNA synthesis in the absence of p53 suggesting these functions are independent of each other ((Zhou 2007)), (Zhang 2009). Meg3 contains several predicted secondary structural elements common to all isoforms. Replacement of the motif most important in p53 activation with a different sequence that formed the same structure maintained Meg3 function showing the RNA structural motifs are critical to Meg3 function ((Zhang 2009)).
Meg3 binds the PRC2 chromatin modification complex in mouse embryonic stem cells. Binding appears to be mediated by the 5â€™ 1kb of the RNA ((Zhao 2010)).
Controls expression of Dlk1 at the Dlk1-Meg3 imprinted locus, likely by recruiting PRC2 to the Dlk1 locus in cis. Knockdown lead to increased expression of Dlk1 and Gtl2-as along with a decrease in Ezh2/PRC2 recruitment to and H3K27me3 marks at the Dlk1 promoter ((Zhao 2010)).
Developmental phenotypes: Knockout of Meg3 and the Meg3 differentially methylated region (DMR) on the maternal allele lead to post-birth lethality, while paternal knockout lead to increased pre and post-birth lethality and growth retardation. However other lncRNAs (Rian, Meg9) were also down-regulated, perhaps due to the loss of the DMR, making attribution of the phenotype to specific lncRNAs difficult ((Takahashi 2009)). A potentially more specific lacZ gene trap insertion gave a parent of origin dwarfism phenotype ((Schuster-Gossler 1998)).
Aberrant repression of Meg3 and other maternally expressed lncRNAs from the DLK1-Dio3 imprinting cluster is present in most induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) lines and is responsible for the failure of iPSCs to form viable mice ((Stadtfeld 2010)). NB: iPSC embryos died mid-gestation, which was more severe than a maternal Meg3 KO ((Takahashi 2009)) indicating the phenotypic impact of other lncRNAs from this locus ((Stadtfeld 2010)).

Mammals.
Both the human and mouse gene have ten exons with the middle exons being those which are alternatively spliced in both species ((Zhang 2009)).

Contains a microRNA: miRNA 770 in the last intron, (although it appears that this intron is sometimes retained) ((Hagan 2009)).
A number of probes for Meg3 exist in NRED due to the large number of isoforms, accession IDs given are for probes that are common to most isoforms.

Downstream of Utf1 coding gene.
No evidence of transcriptional connection between Utf1 and Tip1.

Expressed in mouse embryonic stem cells (mESCs), with H3K4me3 histone marks present at Tip1 loci.
Down-regulated upon mESC differentiation in neurons. H3K4me3 replaced with H3K27me3.

Insertion of Tip1 upstream of a luciferase reporter gene could silence the luciferase reporter in mESCs. Effect was strand independent, (orientation of Tip1 DNA sequence did not matter). However, Tip1 RNA was not necessary for this function.
Knockdown of endogenous Tip1 did not effect expression of the cis (Utf1) gene in mESCs. Knockdown was associated with the up-regulation of other genes, including Syn1, which is normally upregulated during ESC differentiation. Suggesting Tip1 has a trans-repressive function in mESCs.
Exact transcription initiation and termination site of Tip3 not defined, so transcript could be larger than genomic region provided.
Downstream of Nkx2-9 coding gene. Appears to be independent transcript.

Expressed in mouse embryonic stem cells (mESCs) despite presence of H3K27me3 histone marks over Tip3 loci.
Tip3 expression increased upon mESCs differentiation to neural progenitors and then was switched off as the progenitor cells differentiated in neurons. Expression changes occurred alongside continued H3K27me3 marks at locus.

Insertion of Tip3 upstream of a luciferase reporter gene could silence the luciferase reporter in mESCs. Effect was strand independent, (orientation of Tip3 DNA sequence did not matter). Tip3 RNA was required for silencing.
Knockdown of endogenous Tip3 did not effect expression of the cis (Nkx2-9) gene in mESCs. Knockdown was associated with the up-regulation of other genes, including Lzic and Stox2, which are normally upregulated during ESC differentiation. Suggesting Tip1 has a trans-repressive function in mESCs.
Contains block of sequence conserved in most vertebrates.
Exact start and stop site of tip3 not defined but likely to be represented by Ak050890

Transcribed from region between Hoxa6 and Hoxa7.
798 nt, single exon, polyA+.

Expression in mouse embryonic stem cell (mESC) induced by retinoic acid treatment.
Activation of Mira expression occurs before expression of Hoxa6 and Hoxa7.

Role in activation of gene expression and cell differentiation. Required for the epigenetic activation of Hoxa6 and Hoxa7 and hence their target genes during mESC differentiation.
Mira was required for the recruitment of MLL1 to the Mira gene locus and the activation of Hoxa6 and Hoxa7. Mira mediated a local rearrangement in chromatin structure to bring the Mira, Hox66 and Hoxa7 loci into a complex providing a mechanism for MLL1 to act on HoxA6/A7 after recruitment to the Mira locus.
Mira bound to the SET domain of MLL1 through a short hairpin (activator binding motif, ABM) near the 3â€™ end of the RNA. In vitro binding studies suggested MLL1 recruitment was mediated by Mira forming a RNA/DNA hybrid with a protruding ssRNA 3â€™ end containing the ABM.
Otx2os1: OTX2 opposite strand transcript 1

Alternatively spliced transcripts found in a head to head arrangement with Otx2.
Mouse ~750nuc. Humans ~2.4kb.
Contains a number of repeat sequences (human). Mostly free of repeats (mouse).

Expression restricted to retina in panel of adult tissues (retina also shows the highest expression of Otx2).
Otx2 and Otx2os1 had a partially complementary expression pattern in adult retinal layers. Otx2 was predominately expressed in the outer nuclear layer (ONL) and into the inner nuclear layer (INL), while Otx2os was predominately expressed in the ganglion cell layer (GCL) and into the INL.
Low conservation between mouse and human transcripts.

Otx2 is a transcription factor involved in brain and eye development.
Otx2os1 Mouse: GeneID: 606497. Human GeneID: 100309464
MEG9 - Maternally expressed 9 Mirg- MicroRNA-containing gene

Imprinted: Maternally expressed lncRNA from the Dlk1-Dio3 locus, downstream from Rian ((Seitz 2003), (Tierling 2005), (Hagan 2009)). Contains intronic miRNAs which are also maternally expressed ((Seitz 2003), (Seitz 2004)).
