Mirg suggested to be a processed form of Meg9. Northern blot analysis identified a number of transcripts from this locus from ~1kb (putative Mirg transcript) to ~5.5kb (longer than cloned Meg9 transcript) ((Hagan 2009)).

Meg9/ Mirg show similar expression to other lncRNA from locus. Expressed in embryonic and extraembronic tissue but also found in adult skin and testis ((Tierling 2005), (Hagan 2009)).
The large cluster of intronic miRNAs show a similar pattern of expression inlcuding in embryos and adult brain ((Seitz 2004)).

Transcript(s) from the Meg9 locus bind to the PRC2 chromatin modification complex in mouse embryonic stem cells (mESCs) ((Zhao 2010)).
Aberrant repression of Meg9 and other maternally expressed lncRNAs from the DLK1-Dio3 imprinting cluster is present in most induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) lines and is responsible for the failure of iPSCs to form viable mice, with embryos dying mid-gestation ((Stadtfeld 2010)).
Some Meg9 miRNAs have a known function, including one known to be important in brain development ((Schratt 2006)). Others are predicted to target Dlk1, a paternally expressed gene from the same imprinted locus ((Hagan 2009)).

Meg 9 is present in mammals. However the Meg9 host mRNA for the miRNAs has not been identified in each species.
Meg9 microRNAs are mammalian specific ((Seitz 2004)).

Currently unclear if there is any overlap of transcripts from Rian/MEG8 and MEG9/Mirg loci. RNA sequencing by (Guttman 2010) found no evidence for overlap in mESCs, but there is imprinted transcription in the region between them with the same expression patterns ((Tierling 2005), (Hagan 2009)).
Sequence given is EU616813.1 from mouse. Note that northern blotting has suggested longer (characterised) transcripts also exist.
1.9kb, located at a cancer susceptibility locus 1q41 ((Yang 2012)).

Expressed in most tissues, most highly in muscle tissues. Overexpressed in metastatic breast cancer cell line compared to a non-invasive cell line. Overexpressed in cancer tissues compared to controls. Cell cycle specific expression profile, with highest expression during the S phase ((Yang 2012)).
Overexpression interferes with cell cycle progression, promoting progression at the G1/S transition ((Yang 2012)).
Sequence is conserved in primates ((Yang 2012)).

200 nucleotide ncRNA ((Tiedge 1993)) exapted from an Alu element ((Watson 1987)). Transcribed by RNA polymerase III ((Martignetti 1993)).
Three structural domains, 5' that shares homology with Alu elements, a central A rich region and a 3' unique region ((Tiedge 1993)).

Expressed predominantly in different regions of the brain. Also shows low level expression in testis but not in other normal tissues examined ((Watson 1987), (Tiedge 1993), (Kuryshev 2001)). RNA sequencing of 11 human tissues confirmed up-regulation of expression in brain (hypothalamus) and low or no expression elsewhere ((Castle 2010)).
Disregulated in cancer: expressed in a number of human tumours but not in corresponding normal tissue ((Chen 1998)).
Link with aging and Alzheimer disease: BC200 expression decreases with aging but is upregulated in Alzheimer's disease (AD). In AD affected brain regions, expression increased with disease severity. RNA localisation showed intense perikaryal staining, showing build up of RNA in cell body ((Mus 2007)).
Like BC1 ncRNA found in rodents, BC200 also suggested to localise to dendrites ((Tiedge 1993)).

Binds several proteins including the signal recognition particle SRP9/14 heterodimer ((Kremerskothen 1998)), eukaryotic initiation factor 4A helicase (eIF4A) ((Lin 2008)) and Poly(A)-binding protein (PABP), binding to PABP requires the central A rich region ((Muddashetty 2002)).
Inhibits translation in-vitro and in cultured cells similar to BC1. BC200 binding to eIF4A inhibits it by uncoupling eIF4A ATPase activity from its helicase/ duplex unwinding activity ((Lin 2008)). Translational inhibition also involves BC200 binding to to PABP ((Kondrashov 2005)).

Anthropoid primates (monkeys, apes and humans) ((Skryabin 1998)).
BC200, BC1 and G22 likely form a family of independently exapted repetitive elements which have evolved to carry out similar functions in different mammalian species ((Muddashetty 2002), (Khanam 2006)).
More than 200 pseudogenes reported ((Kuryshev 2001)).
Zfhx2as: zinc finger homeobox 2, antisense

Antisense transcription begins 6-10kb downstream of the Zfhx2 polyA site and ends in first exon of Zfhx2.
Alternatively spliced. Multiple start sites.
Estimated as up to ~30 kb in length.

Expressed in a number of specific regions in the developing mouse brain including the rostral migratory stream (RMS).
Antisense RNA was expressed in a complementary manner to the sense coding sequence. For example the antisense RNA was expressed initially in hippocampal development, with the sense RNA only starting to be expressed when antisense transcription declined. Or, alternatively in the dorsal forebrain where sense and antisense transcripts are expressed in different layers of cells at the same stage.
Expression was highest in mid-gestation E13.5-E16.5.
Adult expression specific to brain, with expression in areas of adult neurogenesis.

Zfhx2as negatively regulates the expression of Zfhx2.
Knockout of antisense RNA lead to up-regulation of Zfhx2 expression, with coding gene expression in areas previously showing only expression of the antisense transcript. The same effect was seen in a mutant where Zfhx2 and Zfhx2as no longer overlapped strongly suggesting Zfhx2as negatively regulates Zfhx2.
Identified in rodents and humans.

NCBI Gene and Refseq sequence given for Zfhx2as (provided here) is only a partial sequence from the center of the antisense transcript.
Since full length transcript not defined, UCSC browser links are best estimates of transcripts. Mouse transcript comes from a Scripture transcript defined by (Guttman 2010).
rncs-1: RNA noncoding, starvation up-regulated 1

847 bases. Spliced and polyadenylated. Highly structured, with an almost perfectly double-stranded helix of ~300 nuc.
Expressed from F55A4.9 noncoding RNA gene.

Transcript is enriched in males. Detected in all developmental stages tested (embryos, larval stages (L1-L4), and young adults). Spacial expression localized to intestine (robustly detected in E cell lineage of midgut from 28-cell stage to adulthood), as well as to hypodermis (starting by the comma stage, including Hyp7 syncytium and head and tail hypodermis).
RNA has higher expression in arrested L1s, and dauer larvae purified from exhausted liquid culture, by transcriptional modulation in response to food supply (induced by starvation).

Forms extensive double-stranded RNA structures and inhibits Dicer cleavage of other dsRNA in-vitro, although rncs-1 itself is not a substrate for Dicer (because of branched structures at its termini). Expression of rncs-1 reduces Dicer-generated siRNA, and affects levels of Dicer-regulated genes (5 identified genes).
Lines overexpressing rncs-1 may result in increased frequency of males among hermaphrodite self-progeny.
Absence of an identifiable rncs-1 homolog in closely related Caenorhabditis briggsae and Caenorhabditis remanei species.

Functional analogy is drawn with certain viruses dsRNA expressed to compete with cellular dsRNA-mediated pathways, such as VAI adenovirus RNA ((McKenna 2006)).
It is a substrate of ADAR deamination.
PCNA-AS1 is an antisense transcript to PCNA
PCNA-AS1 is coexpressed with PCNA, and PCNA-AS1 is highly expressed in hepatocellular carcinoma (Yuan 2014)

Overexpression of PCNA-AS1 increases the tumour growth in vitro as well as in vivo (Yuan 2014). Cell population in the G2 phase increased after overexpression of PCNA-AS1 (Yuan 2014). PCNA-AS1 forms RNA duplex with PCNA and stabilises the PCNA mRNA transcripts (Yuan 2014).
4.3 kb. Spliced, antisense to Nkx2.2 (upstream sense of Pax1).
Preferentially expressed in the nervous system.
Over-expression of the ncRNA enhances oligodendrocytic differentiation.
N/A
N/A

Located in cytoplasm ((Kessler (2011))). Spliced and polyadenylated with 3 exons ((Chen (2008))). Multiple isoforms (1.4kb, 2.2kb and 2.7kb). The 2.2kb isoform contains an extended final exon compared to the 1.4kb isoform while the 2.7kb isoform has not been characterised ((Chen (2006)), (Kwok (2007)) , (Chen (2008))). UCA1a refers to the 2.2kb isoform ((Kwok (2007)), (Li (2012))). Sequence is mainly repeat elements. Initiates in an LTR, exons sample pieces of a HERV-H element and longer 2.2kb isoform contains a second LTR at the 3' end ((Chen (2006))).

Upregulated in gastric cancer ((Zhang (2013))). Widely expressed during embryonic development, detected at 5weeks to 28 weeks ((Kessler (2011)), (Chen (2008)), (Chen (2006))). Not expressed in normal adult tissues except heart, spleen and placental tissue ((Chen (2008)), (Kessler (2011)), (Kwok (2007))). Upregulated in colon, cervix, lung, liver, mammary, eosphagous, stomach and bladder cancers ((Chen (2008)), (Chen (2006)), (Zhang (2013))), however, not expressed in renal cancer or hyperplastic prostate. Identified as a biomarker for bladder cancer ((Chen (2006))).

1.4kb isoform Promotes bladder cancer cell proliferation, tumorogenicity, invasive potential and drug resistance ((Chen (2008))). Regulates cell cycle progression through CREB via PI3K-AKT pathways ((Chen (2012))). Overexpression of 2.2kb isoform caused resistance to drug induced apoptosis, ((Kwok (2007))) and promoted tumoregenicity ((Li (2012))). Also enhanced proliferation migration and invasion of bladder cancer cell line ((Li (2012))). 2.2kb isoform promoted transformation in-vitro, possibly because resistance to apoptosis is an important step in tumourigenesis ((Kwok (2007))). Given its expression during development, may also have a role in embryogenesis ((Chen (2008)), (Li (2012))). UCA1 ( described as CUDR ) was found to cooperate with SET1A to accelerate hepatocarcinogenesis and promote malignant transformation of hepatocyte-like stem cells (Li 2015) UCA1 ( described as CUDR ) acts as a sponge cushion in which enhances the phosphorylation of RB1, C-myc expression and the interplay between the SET1A and pRB1 (Li 2015).

Orththologues in primates, including chimpanzee (Pan troglodytes,Â XM_001159928.1), Sumatran orangutan (Pongo abelii,Â AC210534.3), and rhesus monkey (Macaca mulatta,Â AC197808.1). No homologues were found in other species. ((Chen (2008)))

Spliced ~1.7kb transcript. Sequence contains multiple repeat elements.
it acts as a key regulator of this inflammatory response. It is a broad-acting regulatory component of the circuit that controls the inflammatory response. it has three splice variants (GenBank accession numbers JX682706, JX682707, and JX682708). Variant 1 was the most abundant transcript containing exons 1 and 4, common to all splice variants (Carpenter 2013).

mediates both the activation and repression of distinct classes of immune genes. Transcriptional repression of target genes is dependent on interactions of lincRNA-Cox2 with heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein A/B and A2/B (Carpenter 2013)

Reglulated by NFkB. Highly up-regulated upon Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) stimulation of CD11C+ bone-marrow-derived dendritic cells (BMDC). lincRNA-Cox2 expression is induced by Tlr ligands in a MyD88- and NFkBâ€“dependent manne (Carpenter 2013).
Found ~50kb from Cox2 (Ptgs2), which is also induced by NFkB.
Located at 12q15 on the opposite strand to IFNG.

Selectively expressed in Th1 cells relative to Th2 cells. Expression correlated with IFNG expession levels. Not expressed in CD8+ cells under Th1 culture conditions. Expression regulated by the Th1 transcription factors Stat4 and T-bet((Hu 2013), (Collier 2012)). Expressed in CNS-infiltrating immune cells of mice. Not expressed following innoculation with Theiler's virus in suseptible mice ((Vigneau 2003)).
Role in regulating Ifng expression in Th1 cells. shRNA knockdown results in lower IFN-y protein levels ((Hu 2013)).
Ortholog in mouse ((Vigneau 2003)).
SNHG5: Small nucleolar RNA host gene 5

Contains U50 and U50-like snoRNAs in introns ((Tanaka 2000)).
Alternatively spliced transcript ((Tanaka 2000)).
Refseq isoform is ~0.5kb in humans.
Transcriptional start site has characteristics of 5' TOP gene family ((Tanaka 2000)).

Broadly expressed in human adult tissues.
Identified as enriched in the cytoplasm of human GM12878, HepG2, HUVEC and K562 cells bu nuclear enriched in HeLaS3 ((Derrien 2012)).
RNA is unstable with a half-life <2 hr in mouse N2A (neuroblastoma) and 3T3 cells and a half-life ~2 hr in human B cells ((Friedel 2009), (Clark 2012)).

Mouse has two transcripts at syntenic loci which are separated by several hundred kb and contain U50. Some sequence similarity is found between then so it is likely they share a common ancestor ((Tanaka-Fujita 2007)).
Comparing mouse and human host transcripts revealed they were "dissimilar". It was hypothesized that the host transcripts share a common ancestor but there has been little selection for maintaining the sequence the host gene exons ((Tanaka-Fujita 2007)).
SNHG5 forms a novel translocation breakpoint with Bcl6 in a diffuse large B-cell (DLB) lymphoma, although it is unclear if SNHG5 contributed to malignancy ((Tanaka 2000)).
Jpx; Enox (expressed neighbor of Xist)

Spliced (5 exons), with multiple isoforms. Located at the X-inactivation center (XIC), transcribed from an unmethylated CpG island 10 kb upstream of Xist. Transcribed in antisense orientation to Xist. ((Johnston 2002))

Ubiquitously expressed.
Up-regulated during both male and female embryonic stem cell differentiation ((Tian 2010)).

Involved in the regulation of X chromosome inactivation in mammals via activation of the Xist RNA, possibly by interfering with Tsix expression ((Tian 2010)).
Jpx seems to act in trans, as its deletion prevents Xist up-regulation also from the Xist allele on the wild type chromosome ((Tian 2010)).
First exon is highly conserved in mouse, human and cow ((Chureau 2002)).
SNHG6: Small nucleolar RNA host gene 6

Spliced transcript with U87 snoRNA in second intron.
~0.5kb transcript
Transcriptional start site has characteristics of 5' TOP gene family.

Broad expression in human and mouse tissues.
Localises mostly to the cytoplasm
Human transcript found to show greater stability that SNHG1 in Hela cells ((Makarova 2005)). Also found to be quite stable in human B cells with a half-life of 7 hr, while mouse Snhg6 was significantly less stable (half-life 2.2hrs in 3T3 cells), suggesting the transcripts may have different stabilities between species ((Friedel 2009), (Clark 2012)).
Minority of SNHG6 associates with monosomes.
Blocking translation led to a very modest increase in SNHG6 levels, in contrast to SNHG1 (which showed a large increase in transcript level) suggesting it is not very sensitive to nonsense mediated decay. This may help explain its increased stability.
Unknown, however the authors point out that 5' TOP family genes are important for translation and that ribosomal associated SNHGs could be involved in this process as well.

Host gene sequence shows more conservation between species than other SNHG RNAs with conservation similar to levels of mRNA 3'UTRs.
Conserved between human, mouse, rat and dog.
SNHG1: Small nucleolar RNA host gene 1 UHG: U22 host gene

Spliced transcript with a number of short exons (>40bp) and snoRNA containing introns ((Tycowski 1996)).
Transcriptional start site has characteristics of 5' TOP gene family ((Tycowski 1996)).
~1.1kb transcript in human ((Tycowski 1996)).
Contains 8 (maybe 9) snoRNAs in human, 8 in mouse ((Tycowski 1996)).

Localised to the cytoplasm and associates with ribosomes ((Pelczar 1998)).
RNA unstable in both human and mouse cells ((Tycowski 1996), (Friedel 2009), (Clark 2012)), can be stabilised by inhibition of protein synthesis. This suggests SNHG1 may be sensitive to nonsense mediated decay and could be therefore be "translated" but perhaps only to degrade it ((Tycowski 1996)).
Up-regulated during lineage restriction of neural stem cells into bipotent neuronal/oligodendrocyte progenitors in vitro ((Mercer 2010)).
Mouse SNHG1 is in a syntenic position with the human host gene. However, there is little conservation of exonic sequence compared to intronic snoRNA sequence ((Tycowski 1996), (Tanaka-Fujita 2007)).
SChLAP1 levels independently predict poor outcomes, including metastasis and prostate cancer-specific mortaliy nuclear localization.
Overexpressed in a subset of prostate cancers (25%)
SNHG3: Small nucleolar RNA host gene 3

Upstream from the RCC1 protein coding gene. Multiple SNHG3 splice isoforms exist, minority join RCC1, majority do not. Isoforms range from ~0.9kb to ~2.6kb in human.
Contain U17a and U17b snoRNAs in introns.
SNHG3 contains a number of exonic Alu elements
Transcriptional start site has characteristics of 5' TOP gene family.

Localised to cytoplasm.
Unlike SNHG1 it was not stabilised by translation inhibitors or associated with translating ribosomes and was unaffected by translation inhibitors.
Identified as expressed in mouse embryonic stem cells ((Guttman 2011)).
Transcript found to be unstable with a half-life <2 hr in mouse N2A (neuroblastoma) cells and human B cells ((Friedel 2009), (Clark 2012)).

Involved in maintaining pluripotency in ESCs ((Guttman 2011)).
Knockdown in mECSs lead to down-regulation of Nanog, Sox2, Klf4 and Oct4 expression as well as changes to ESC morphology ((Guttman 2011)).
Snhg3 was found to interact with a number of chromatin binding proteins/complexes in mESCs including PRC1, PRC2, JARID1B and SUV39H1, with the general pattern being interaction with repressors of gene expression ((Guttman 2011)).
Not highly conserved, ~40-50% identity between mouse and human exons.

~300 nucleotide, nonpolyadenylated, RNAP III transcript.
SINE (short interspersed nucleotide element - AluJb). 21A lacks the Alu-specific intragenic consensus elements needed to promote its pol III transcription such as the blocks A and B, which points to transcription driven by an extragenic type 3 pol III promoter.
Very low free energy (deltaG) value (deltaG < -100) indicating strong secondary structure.

Nuclear localisation. Detected in tested cultured cells such as HeLa and skin fibroblast cells.
The level of 21A transcription was very low in three immortalized, fully proliferating cell lines (HeLa, 293T, and LAN5) compared to unproliferating/resting PBL (peripheral blood lymphocyte) cells. Similarly, the 21A RNA level in primary skin fibroblasts was higher than in 293T cells, reinforcing an inverse correlation between endogenous 21A expression and cell proliferation.

21AS is one of a number of RNAP III-transcribed short ncRNAs that have sequence complementarity to protein-coding genes, possibly acting as as a natural trans-chromosomal antisense RNA. Aligned to the human genome, it shows several homology hits, among which the most highly significant were associated to multiple intronic regions of centromeric protein F gene (CENP-F). In vitro over-expression of 21AS transcripts inhibits CENP-F protein accumulation and decreased levels of CENP-F mRNA, indicating that 21AS regulates CENP-F expression in trans.
21A RNAs has a role in the control of the proliferation of human tumor cell lines, possibly via regulation of CENP-F expression. This effect was not observed in a mouse cell line.
Similarly to all of the 7SL/Alu-derived elements, 21A is primate-specific.
Transcript on the antisense strand of the HoxC locus between Hoxc4 and Hoxc5 ((Guttman 2009)). LincRNA - Large intervening noncoding RNA.

Expression is highly anti-correlated with HOTAIR during limb development ((Guttman 2009)).
Putatively regulated by NFkB. Amongst lincRNAs differentially expressed after TLR4 (Toll-like receptor 4) stimulation of CD11C+ bone-marrow-derived dendritic cells (BMDC) ((Guttman 2009)).
Sequence and exact genomic coordinates of the lncRNA have not been defined.
2.7kb transcript, encoded in the herpesvirus HCMV genome. Unspliced and polyadenylated ((Greenaway 1987)).

Beta2.7 kb transcript is found predominantly in the cytoplasm and does associate with polysomes ((Greenaway 1987), (Greenaway 1987))((McSharry 2003)). It is an early transcript expressed upon infection (12 to 24 hours), and rapidly accumulated in infected cells, accounting to ~20% of viral RNA transcription ((Greenaway 1987), (Greenaway 1987)).

Beta2.7 RNA has a fundamental role in preventing stress response and apoptosis of the host cell, by binding to components of the mitochondrial respiratory chain complex I (reduced nicotinamide adenine dinucleotideâ€“ubiquinone oxido-reductase). Beta2.7 specifically binds and prevents re-localization of essential complex I subunit genes associated with retinoid/interferon-induced mortality-19 (GRIMâ€“19), in response to apoptotic stimuli. This interaction is also important for stabilizing the mitochondrial membrane potential and the mitochondrial ATP production, preventing metabolic dysfunction, which is essential for completion of the virus' life cycle ((Reeves 2007)).
Beta2.7 transcripts have also been shown to protect endothelial cells from rat aorta against apoptosis during ischemia/reperfusion injury, which also involves complex I of the mitochondrial respiratory chain. Overexpression of beta2.7 RNA reduced reactive oxygen species production and inhibited apoptosis ((Zhao 2009)).

Beta2.7 sequence is highly conserved not only in HCMV clinical isolates but also in the common laboratory strains, demonstrating that the gene sequence was not substantially modified during prolonged in vitro passage ((McSharry 2003)).
A potential open reading frame of 170 amino acids was identified close to the 5'-terminus of the gene ((Greenaway 1987)), but no protein product of this RNA has ever been detected in infected cells.
dUHG: Drosophila U snoRNA Host Gene.

7 known dUHGs (dUHG 1-5, 7-8), spliced noncoding RNAs that contain intronic snoRNAs ((Tycowski 2001), (Huang 2005)). Nb: UHG6 identified as protein coding.
These 7 genes contain around half the known box C/D snoRNAs in Drosophila with snoRNAs in almost every intron ((Huang 2005)).
dUHG1 & 2 transcriptional start sites have characteristics of the 5' TOP gene family ((Tycowski 2001)).
dUHG1 and 2 can be stabilised by inhibition of protein synthesis suggesting they are normally degraded by nonsense mediated decay ((Tycowski 2001)).

dUHG 1 and 2 contain snoRNAs that appear homologous to some of those found in UHG/SNHG1 and Gas5/SNHG2. Calling these genes homologous is not straightforward however, ie: both dUHG1 and 2 contain snoRNAs found in UHG, dUHG2 also contain snoRNAs found within introns of mammalian protein coding genes.
GeneID NCBI Entrez Gene dUHG1: 3772106. dUHG2: 3772246. dUHG3: 3772557. dUHG4: 8673973. dUHG5: 8673975. dUHG7: 8674061. dUHG8: 8674065.
"adaptive response 33"

1.46 and 0.99kb bands detected by Northern blot ((Wang 1996)).
Mouse 5430416N02Rik has 0.6 and 3.5 kb isoforms.

Isolated from Chinese hamster ovary cell-derived HA-1 fibroblasts ((Wang 1996)).
Multiple stress-responsive gene. Hydrogen peroxide-inducible. Induction appears to be dependent on calcium, occurred as early as 90 min, and was maximal at 5h. Adapt33 induction by hydrogen peroxide is suggested to occur at the mRNA stability level, and stability analysis indicated a short half-life. ((Wang 2003), (Wang 1996))
Cell fractionation revealed that a significant proportion of adapt33 RNA is associated with active translation in the polysomes. ((Wang 1996))
Analysis of expression following the stimulation of apoptosis with hydrogen peroxide and staurosporine indicated a strong correlation with the apoptosis response. ((Wang 2003))
In mouse probable homologue expressed in mouse embryonic stem cells (ESCs) ((Guttman 2011)).
Mouse RNA found to be highly unstable with a half-life <2 hr in N2A (neuroblastoma) cells ((Clark 2012)).

Mouse RNA was found to interact with a number of chromatin binding protein/complexes in mouse embryonic stem cells including PRC1, PRC2, JARID1B, ESET, SUV39H1, SETD8 and CBX1 with the general pattern being interaction with repressors of gene expression ((Guttman 2011)).
Adapt33 sequence has homology to mouse AK017316.
Adapt33 promoter constructs have strong activity in both hamster and human cells. ((Wang 2003))

83-112 nt. Four human Y RNAs (hY1, 112nt; hY3, 101nt; hY4, 93nt; and hY5, 83nt) encoded in single copy genes, which are present in a cluster in human chromosome 7 ((Maraia 1994)). Pyrimidine-rich, transcribed by RNA polymerase III, and contain a 5-triphosphate and a retained 3' poly(U) tail ((Hendrick 1981)).
Y RNAs form characteristic stem-loop structures, with a highly conserved double-stranded stem formed by partially complementary 5' and 3' terminal domains, linked by a loop domain containing secondary stem-loops ((Teunissen 1999), (O'Brien 1993), (van Gelder 1994)). Parts of the RNA structure appear to be flexible, able to adopt different conformations. Y RNAs contain an essential characteristic bulged C in the middle portion of the stem (in position 8 or 9), as well as the characteristic pyrimidine-rich region that is single-stranded in the secondary structures ((Teunissen 1999), (Green 1998)).

All four Y RNAs are primarily cytoplasmic, they are also detected in perinucleolar compartments, discrete structures near the nucleolar rim ((Matera 1995)).
Y RNAs are expressed in similar levels in all human tissues and cell lines investigated, with all Y RNAs showing a positively correlated expression across different tissue types ((Christov 2008))((Pruijn 1993)). Y RNAs are up-regulated in a number of human solid tumours compared to corresponding nonmalignant tissues. In particular, hY1 and hY3 RNAs are over-expressed in carcinomas and adenocarcinomas of the bladder, cervix, colon, kidney, lung and prostate ((Christov 2008)).

The different Y RNAs may have multiple roles.
Y RNAs were identified as the RNA component of the 'small cytoplasmic' (sc) Ro autoantigen (soluble ribonucleoproteins (RNP) detected in sera of systemic lupus erythematosis patients), binding the autoantigen La and Ro proteins ((Lerner 1981)).
Y RNAs have been shown to be required for semiconservative chromosomal DNA replication in vitro, in a mammalian cell-free experimental system. hY1, hY3, hY4 and hY5 RNAs are functionally redundant ((Christov 2006)), and have been shown to act at the initiation step of DNA replication* ((Krude 2009)). (*See (Krude 2009) for review).
Regulate cell DNA replication and cell proliferation, with knock-down of hY1 and hY3 RNA in human cells causing a cytostatic arrest of cell proliferation ((Christov 2008), (Krude 2009), (Christov 2006)).
Bind to Ro proteins through their terminal stem, which contains conserved binding sites for Ro60 and La proteins ((Green 1998)). The central portion of the double-stranded stem is essential for reconstituting chromosomal DNA replication, while the central loop and the terminal stem are not ((Gardiner 2009)).
Different proteins may also bind Y RNAs or be present in human Ro RNPs, such as hnRNP K, PTB, RoBP1 and nucleolin ((Bouffard 2000), (Fabini 2000), (Fouraux 2002)), indicating that Y RNAs may be involved in their regulation, such as in the control of alternative splicing. hY5 RNA uniquely binds to ribosomal protein L5 and its binding partner 5S RNA, with Ro-Y5 suggested to have a specialized role in 5S ribosomal RNA quality control ((Hogg 2007)). Ro60 protein had been previously shown to bind misfolded small RNAs and suggested to be involved in quality control of the RNAs ((Shi 1996), (Stein 2005), (Fuchs 2006)). A role is also proposed in the regulation of the translation of ribosomal mRNA ((Pellizzoni 1998)).

A single cluster of functional Y RNA genes is preserved throughout tetrapod evolution, which however exhibits clade-specific tandem duplications, gene-losses, and rearrangements ((Mosig 2007)).
Homologues of functional Y RNAs are present throughout vertebrates, with conserved synteny, but numbers vary between species, with individual gene-loss events having occurred during evolution in most classes (the mouse expresses only Y1 and Y3 RNAs, zebrafish only Y1, and chicken Y3 and Y4). No Y RNA gene has been identified in some species such as Drosophila melanogaster and Schistosoma species. ((Copeland 2009), (Pruijn 1993), (Mosig 2007), (Gardiner 2009), (O'Brien 1993), (Perreault 2007), (Farris 1995)). Y3 is the most conserved Ro RNA, not only by its more consistent presence in other species, but also at the levels of sequence divergence and secondary structure similarity ((Farris 1995)).
Recently, the 'sbRNAs' or stem-bulge RNAs from Caenorhabditis elegans have been identified as homologs of vertebrate Y RNAs present in nematode worms, showing the characteristic Ro protein binding motif ((Boria 2010)).
An Y-like RNA (as well as other small RNAs) has been also identified in the bacterium Deinococcus radiodurans binding to an ortholog of Ro60 (Rsr), which accumulate following UV irradiation, and contribute to the resistance to irradiation ((Chen 2000)).

Thousands of Y RNA 'retropseudogenes' are present among various species ((Perreault 2007)). It has been suggested that hY RNAs represent a novel class of nonautonomous, L1-dependent, retrotransposable elements ((Perreault 2005)).
Xrn1-sensitive unstable transcript (XUT) antisense to TPO1 gene. Transcript initiates within TPO1 gene.

Upregulated by Xrn1 knockout. Hence degraded by Xrn1 cytoplasmic pathway.
TPO1axut is reversibly up-regulated by lithium
TPO1 is down-regulated upon Xrn1 inactivation, hence it is possible TPO1axut represses TPO1, similar to the action of other XUTs.
6795 long, 2 exons.

Hypomethylated and overexpressed in Barrett's esophagus and esophageal adenocarcinoma tissues andesophageal adenocarcinoma cells (Wu (2013)). Silencing by small interfering RNA inhibited proliferation and colony-forming ability, induced apoptosis, and reduced EAC cell migration and invasion without altering the expression of its protein-coding counterpart, AFAP1 (Wu (2013)).

Multiple spliced transcripts between HoxA6 and HOXA7 on the antisense strand, share some splice junctions but have different 5' and 3' ends ((Sessa 2006), (Sasaki 2007)).
Some HOX6as transcripts overlap to one or both HOX protein coding genes ((Sessa 2006), (Sasaki 2007)).

Expressed in adult lung, kidney, testis, placenta, colon, muscle. Fetal ovary and kidney, similar to HOXA6 and HOXA7 ((Sessa 2006), (Sasaki 2007)).
Expression can be induced by retinoic acid ((Sessa 2006)).
Shows collinear regulation of expression like HOX PTC genes ((Sessa 2006), (Sasaki 2007)).

HOXA6as transcripts contain sequences conserved in mammals and even sequences ultra conserved in vertebrates.
Similar mouse transcripts are not known, however, transcripts which run antisense to both HOXA5 and HOXA6, that share an splice junction with HOXA6as and transcribe through the vertebrate conserved element, are present in both species.
Example accessions: AK091933, AK092154.
Two transcripts
Gastric cancer. Expression level correlated with metastasis and tumour differentiation. Potential biomarker for gastric carcinoma. (Sun (2013))
HULC: Highly upregulated in liver cancer RNA

~500nuc, spliced, polyadenylated, two exon transcript ((Panzitt 2007)).
Exon 1 mainly consists of an LTR (MLT1A) ((Panzitt 2007)).

Binding of phospho-CREB to the HULC promoter activates HULC expression. Phosphorylation of CREB was stimulated by PKA signaling ((Wang 2010)).
Highly up-regulated in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and to a lesser extent in liver focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH). Up-regulation was specific to HCC with high expression not detected in normal liver, other tissues and their associated neoplasms ((Panzitt 2007)).
HULC expression was also up-regulated in colorectal carcinomas that metastasised to the liver but not in primary colorectal carcinomas or carcinomas that metastasised to lymph nodes ((Matouk 2009)).
HULC RNA could be detected in the blood of HCC patients ((Panzitt 2007)).
Localised to the cytoplasm, may associate with ribosomes, but no sign of translated products could be found ((Panzitt 2007)).
HULC expression was also identified in 3 old world monkeys ((Panzitt 2007)).

Competing endogenous RNA (ceRNA). Functions as a sponge/ target mimic for miR-372 through a conserved target site, reducing the expression and activity of miR-372 ((Wang 2010)).
One of targets of miR-372 is Prkacb (catalytic subunit of PKA) which is able to phophorylate CREB. Hence expression of HULC stimulates further HULC expression by inhibiting miR-372, and allowing PRKACB to create active CREB ((Wang 2010)).
HULC knockdown affects expression of other genes including some described in liver cancer ((Panzitt 2007)).
HLUC also present in other primates, gene shows good conservation above that of surrounding sequence. Not detected in rodents so may be primate specific ((Panzitt 2007)).

Intergenic, two exon transcript. LincRNA ((Guttman 2010)).
Two transcription start sites generating unique first exons ((Guttman 2010)).
~7kb upstream of Enah coding gene on same stand
Expressed in mouse embryonic stem cells (ESCs) ((Guttman 2010)).

Involved in maintaining pluripotency in ESCs ((Guttman 2011)).
Knockdown in mECSs lead to down-regulation of Nanog and Oct4 expression as well as changes to ESC morphology ((Guttman 2011)).
No evidence for expressed orthologue in human
CDR1 Antisense CDR1 Natural antisense transcript Circular RNA sponge for miR-7

Identified as ~1.5kb (no internal splicing) and ~1.3kb (with internal splicing) ((Hansen 2011)).
Circular transcript in which 5â€™ and 3â€™ ends have splice donor and acceptor sequences and are spliced together ((Hansen 2011)).
Human CDR1 AS contains 1 target site with almost perfect complementarity to miR-671 and 73/74 miR-7 target sites, of which 63 are conserved. The miR-7 sites have seed and 3' base pair matches to miR-7 but also central mismatches, which would be expected to prevent miR-7 mediated cleavage ((Hansen 2013), (Memczak 2013)).
Also contains 2 internal splice sites ((Hansen 2011)).

Highly expressed in HEK293 cells where it could potentially bind up to 20 000 miR-7 molecules per cells ((Memczak 2013)).
Highly expressed in human adult and fetal brain and spinal cord. Expression in brain considerably higher than that of CDR1 mRNA. Modest expression in other human tissues including heart, lung, thymus and thyroid ((Hansen 2011)).
Expressed in mouse brain (cerebellum, cerebrum/cerebral cortex, hippocampus, forebain and midbrain) ((Hansen 2011), (Memczak 2013)), with high expression in the neocortex, hippocampus (including the dentate gyrus), thalamus and E13.5 midbrain. At a tissue level CDR1 AS highly overlaps miR-7 expression ((Hansen 2013), (Memczak 2013)).
Localises to neuronal cell bodies and dendrites ((Hansen 2013)).

First lncRNA identified as a miRNA target ((Hansen 2011)). Acts as a miRNA sponge for miR-7 and miR671 but with different functional outcomes ((Hansen 2011), (Hansen 2013), (Memczak 2013)).
Function in association with miR-7: CDR1 AS acts as a sponge for miR-7, which can bind to CDR1 AS but not degrade it ((Hansen 2013), (Memczak 2013)). CDR1 AS shows high levels of miR-7 and Ago2 association, which causes co-localisation of CDR1 AS to P-bodies ((Hansen 2013), (Memczak 2013)). CDR1 AS and miR-7 expression patterns are not identical. However co-expression in the same brain cells can be identified in the dentate hilus and different layers of the cingulate gyrus ((Hansen 2013)). The lack of CDR1 AS expression outside the brain makes it possible this is a brain specific interaction and function. CDR1 AS inhibit miR-7 activity causing depression of some miR-7 targets ((Hansen 2013), (Memczak 2013)). Expression of human or mouse circular CDR1 AS in developing zebrafish (which have miR-7 but not the CDR1 locus) caused a decrease in midbrain size. This closely mimicked the phenotype of miR-7 knockdown, further supporting CDR1 AS as a biologically relevant miR-7 sponge ((Memczak 2013)).
Function in association with miR-671: CDR1 AS functions to stabilize CDR1 mRNA, as a decrease in CDR1 AS levels leads to a decrease in the expression level of the sense CDR1 mRNA. Conversely, the sense transcript does not act to stabilize the antisense lncRNA and appears to destabilize it, perhaps through a feedback mechanism ((Hansen 2011)). CDR1 AS and hence CDR1 sense are regulated by miR-671. A conserved miR-671 binding site is present in the antisense transcript (a site which corresponds to near the transcriptional start site of the sense CDR1 mRNA). miR-671 localises to the nucleus and can repress CDR1 AS and CDR1 sense mRNA ((Hansen 2011)). miR-671 causes Ago2 mediated cleavage and down-regulation of CDR1 AS, likely due to the near perfect complementarity between miR-671 and CDR1 AS ((Hansen 2011)). Mechanism for how CDR1 AS stabilizes CDR1 is not certain but it does not appear to be due to the lncRNA acting as a miR-671 sponge ((Hansen 2011)). By down-regulating CDR1 AS miR-671 could potentially indirectly regulate miR-7 and hence the levels of miR-7 target genes ((Hansen 2013)).

CDR1 AS found in eutherian mammals ((Hansen 2011), (Hansen 2013)).
miR-7 targets sites are conserved in eutherian mammals ((Hansen 2013)), with 63 present in a least one other species ((Memczak 2013)).

Note: Evidence of antisense transcription across locus from a number of tissues present in Illumnia Body Atlas (IBA2). These suggest antisense transcripts can extend in both 5â€™ and 3â€™ directions and can be longer than 1.5kb. Whether these represent longer or primary CDR1 AS transcript is unclear.
AK054921 may represent an isoform although the sequence does not reach the miR-671 binding site.
NDM29: neuroblastoma differentiation marker 29 ((Castelnuovo 2010), (Pagano 2007)).

~130 nt. 'Alu-like RNA', it has a canonical Alu/7SL-derived sequence structure. Transcribed by RNA Polymerase III from the first intron of the ASCL3 (Achaete Scute-Like homologue 3) gene ((Castelnuovo 2010)).

NDM29 expression was analyzed in 6 different cell types and found in abundant levels in neural cells (neuroblastoma cell lines SHSY5Y and SKNBE2, and primary culture of human glioma cells), but at a very low levels in epithelial-derived cells (HeLa, HEK293, and primary cultures of skin fibrobroblast). NDM29 expression was increased in differentiating cells ((Castelnuovo 2010)).
NDM29 RNA was detected in both the nucleus and cytoplasm of SKNBE2 and HeLa cells, but enriched (~70%) in the latter ((Castelnuovo 2010)).

In humans, NDM29 maps in a genomic region whose deletion has been shown to be involved in neuroblastoma development ((De Preter 2005)).
In-vitro over-expression of NDM29 promoted differentiation of neuroblastoma (NB) cells into cells with neuron-like features (including marker expression, morphology, anchorage-dependent growth and excitatory properties), and a reduction in the tumor initiating ('stem-like') cell fraction in the NB cell population. In-vitro and in-vivo experiments indicated that increased expression of NDM29 restricts NB development and malignancy. It also lead to reduced expression of multidrug resistance 1 (MDR1) mRNA in malignant NB cells, and so increased their susceptibility to doxorubicin and cis-platinum antiblastic drugs used in NB therapy ((Castelnuovo 2010)).
RNA was detected in humans - Alu-derived elements are restricted to primate lineage ((Castelnuovo 2010)).

NDM29 transcript comprises Alu sequences and unique sequences and might have been inserted into the genomic locus by retrotransposition ((Castelnuovo 2010)).
Similar to 21A RNA, it is also a short interspersed nucleotide element, marked as AluJb elements. ((Pagano 2007))
hsr omega: heat shock RNA omega

Product of the 93D (or hsr-omega) locus, one of the largest heat-shock puffs in Drosophila polytene chromosomes. This locus produces three major long transcripts (by alternative polyadenylation and splicing) in all Drosophila species examined (reviewed in (Jolly 2006)). The locus spans 10â€“20 kb, composed of two small exons (~475 and 700 bp in Drosophila melanogaster) separated by a 700 bp intron, and followed by a long stretch (5â€“15 kb) of short (280 bp in D. melanogaster) tandem repeat units ((Jolly 2006)).
Long noncoding transcripts produced include three major hsr-omega transcripts, which share the same 5' end ((Bendena 1991), (Garbe 1986)):
Hsr-omega-n (omega-1) is >10kb-long and nuclear transcript that covers the entire length of the gene (including the tandem repeats), is polyadenylated, and retains the intron.
Hsr-omega-c (omega-3 ) is 1.2-kb, spliced and cytoplasmic.
The third common RNA, omega-pre-c (omega-2) is spliced to produce the mature omega-c transcript. It is 1.9kb-long and terminates at a first polyadenylation site located at the 3' end of exon 2.

Transcripts are constitutively expressed at relatively high levels in many tissues, in almost all cell types analysed, and are developmentally regulated ((Lakhotia 2001))((Bendena 1991))((Mutsuddi 1995)).
Transcripts were not detected in gonadal cell types such as male and female gonial cells and in follicle cells and oocytes in ovary. Polytenised tissues such as salivary glands, and certain regions of larval gut and the Malpighian tubules, showed a greater abundance of hsr-omega transcripts with a strong hybridization in nuclei ((Bendena 1991)).
Expression is stress-induced, being highly active after heat exposure, but also responsive to other stresses such as amides benzamide and colchicine ((Tapadia 1997)).
Nuclear hsr-omega-n is localized in nuclear granules called omega-speckles ((Sengupta 2006), (Bendena 1991), (Prasanth 2000)).

Flies null for Hsr-omega mostly die at embryonic stage, and the surviving flies are weak, sterile and die within a few days of emergence ((Jolly 2006)).
Transcribed from a locus involved in the heat shock response in Drosophila. hsr-omega-n nuclear transcripts form complexes with various hnRNP proteins and related proteins in nucleoplasmic omega-speckles, distributed in the interchromatin space in close proximity to the chromatin ((Sengupta 2006), (Bendena 1991), (Prasanth 2000)).
Many proteins are found associated with the hsr-omega-n transcripts, including: (i) various hnRNPs Hrp40 (hnRNP A), Hrb87F (hnRNP A1/A2), Hrb57A (hnRNP K), Hrb98DE (44); (ii) other nuclear RNA-binding proteins like NonA, PEP, Sxl, nuclear non-histone proteins recognized by Q14, Q16, T29, P75 antibodies; (iii) Snf; (iv) Hsp83 and (v) Tpr (see (Jolly 2006) for review and references).
Omega speckles disappear after heat shock, except from the hsr-omega/93D locus, and speckled distribution of associated hnRNPs is disrupted in hsr-omega nullosomics ((Prasanth 2000)). It is suggested that the ncRNA may regulate the availability of hnRNPs in active (chromatin bound) and inactive (in omega-speckles) compartments and interfere with the processing of pre-mRNAs in cyst cells ((Rajendra 2002)).
Altered expression of the hsr omega RNAs enhances poly-Q-induced neurotoxicity in Drosophila ((Sengupta 2006), (Mallik 2009), (Fernandez-Funez 2000)).

The hsr-omega/93D locus and genomic organization is conserved among Drosophila species. However, the hsr-omega transcripts have poor sequence conservation among different Drosophila species ((Garbe 1986)), but, similar to other ncRNAs, have short stretches of conservation.

Heat shock puffs in Chironomus genus also produce non-conding transcripts analogous to Drosophila hsr omega transcripts, and interaction of Hsp90 with puffs is dependent on transcription ((Morcillo 1993)). Analogy is also drawn with non-related human heat-shock induced Satellite III (Sat III) transcripts ((Jolly 2006)).
Natural variation in hsr-omega expression influence rates of protein synthesis in Drosophila lines ((Johnson 2009)).
Small open reading frames (ORFs) present in hsr-omega are poorly conserved in different Drosophila species. A short ORF of 23â€“27 amino acids present in the hsr-omega-c sequence of three examined Drosophila species is translatable, but the predicted protein has not been detected ((Fini 1989)).

Antisense and head to head with Dio3 from the Dlk1-Dio3 imprtinted locus ((Hernandez 2004)). A large number of isoforms are transcribed through alternative splicing and start sites some of which overlap Dio3 ((Hernandez 2004)).
Also overlaps a provisional microRNA miR1247.

Various DIO3OS isoforms are expressed in a wide range of human tissues including adult testis, adrenal cortex, heart, bladder, uterus, placenta and fetal lung ((Hernandez 2004)).
Expressed in embryonic and extra-embryonic tissue in mouse. Weakly expressed in several neonatal and adult tissues: brain and liver (adult only), intestine and tougue (neonate only), kidney and lung (expressed in both) ((Tierling 2005)).
Analysis in different cell culture lines showed co-expression of DIO3OS transcripts and DIO3 ((Kester 2006)). Conversely differentiation of mature brown adipose tissue (BAT) adipocytes from precursor cells showed that Dio3 was only expressed in the proliferating precursors while a specific Dio3os isoform was expressed only in differentiated adipocytes ((Hernandez 2007)).
Not imprinted in mouse ((Tierling 2005)).
Aside from the short exon 1, there is poor sequence conservation and no conserved ORFs between mouse and human Dio3os ((Hernandez 2004)).
May negatively influence Gabrr2; a key feature of the GAGAergic pathway (Petazzi 2013)
>1 kb, intergenic RNAs transcribed from the beta-globin locus.

Dynamically expressed during erythroid cell development.
Nuclear localised.

Intergenic transcripts (or their transcription) are believed to participate in the developmental switch of beta-globin cluster genes, with proposed roles in chromatin remodeling and long-range cis-activation. RNAs may be processed by RNAi machinery.
N/A
N/A
ADAMTS9-AS2 is an antisense overlapping lncRNA to ADAMTS9 which is mostly located upstream from ADAMTS9.
Expression of ADAMTS9-AS2 was downregulated in 70 patients with glioma compared to matched non-tumour tissues (Yao 2014).

Decreased expression was also associated with poor patient prognosis (Yao 2014). The expression of the antisense lncRNA is positively correlated with ADAMTS9 and DNMT3A and showed a negative correlation with DNMT1 (Yao 2014). Overexpression of ADAMTS9-AS2 upregulates the ADAMTS9 mRNA expression (Yao 2014). DNMT1 is responsible for methylating ADAMTS9-AS2 which is evident by the increased expression of ADAMTS9-AS2 resulting from DNMT1 knockdown (Yao 2014). Increased expression of ADAMTS9-S2 inhibited cell migration and invasion in T98G cells while knockdown of the lncRNA increased the same phenotypes in U87 cells (Yao 2014).

TERRA: telomeric repeat-containing RNAs
TelRNAs: Telomeric RNAs

Heterogeneous sizes (between 100 nt and 9 kb); transcribed from telomeric C-rich strand (RNAs contain UUAGGG repeats) from telomeres, initiating in subtelomeric regions.
Transcribed by RNA polymerase II. Polyadenylated. ((Azzalin 2007), (Schoeftner 2007))

TERRA expression is regulated by several mechanisms, especially telomere length. Measured RNA stability indicates a half-life of approximately 2.2 h ((Schoeftner 2007)).
Nuclear-restricted. Detected in different human and rodent cell lines. Levels vary according to developmental stage, cellular stress, tumour differentiation and chromatin structure: very low levels in mouse embryos between days 11.5 and 15.5 of embryonic gestation; higher levels in all adult tissues tested, with highest levels in thymus, kidney and spleen and other tissues with low or no telomerase activity; low levels in cancer cells. ((Azzalin 2007), (Schoeftner 2007))

TERRA RNAs remain associated to telomeric chromatin, making them potential components of mammalian telomeres, and proposed involvement in shortening of telomeres.
Telomere length correlates with TERRA levels in immortal cell lines.
TERRA siRNA knock-down caused an increase in telomere dysfunction-induced foci, aberrations in metaphase telomeres, and a loss of histone H3 trimethyl K9 and origin recognition complex (ORC) binding at telomere repeat DNA.
SMG proteins (effectors of nonsense-mediated decay) are enriched at telomeres in vivo and negatively regulate TERRA association with chromatin, protecting chromosome ends from telomere loss ((Azzalin 2007)).
TERRA transcripts inhibit telomerase activity in vitro, therefore suggested to negatively regulate telomere length. Consistent with this hypothesis, TERRA knock-down causes a loss of telomeric DNA repeats.
TERRA transcripts have recently been detected associated with heterochromatin marks typical of telemores (histone H3 trimethyl K9) as well as with different telomere proteins, including telomere repeat factors 1 and 2 (TRF1 and TRF2), subunits of the ORC, heterochromatin protein 1 (HP1), and members of the DNA-damage-sensing pathway. In particular, TERRA can interact directly with the TRF2 amino-terminal GAR domain and ORC1 to form a stable ternary complex, and ORC1 binding to TRF2 is RNase A sensitive ((Deng 2009)).
Different lines of evidence indicate that TERRA transcripts form a parallel G-quadruplex structure localized to telomere DNA at cell nuclei, and may form an intermolecular G-quadruplex with DNA ((Xu 2008), (Xu 2010)).
TERRA RNAs have been described in different vertebrates ((Schoeftner 2007)) and yeast ((Luke 2008)), and more recently in Arabidopsis ((Vrbsky 2010)).

Telomeric repeat-containing transcripts have been described in Arabidopsis. A portion of these TERRA transcripts are processed into small interfering RNAs, which contribute to the maintenance of telomeric chromatin through promoting methylation of asymmetric cytosines in telomeric (CCCTAAA)(n) repeats. This process relies on the RNA-dependent DNA methylation pathway ((Vrbsky 2010)).
Located immediately upstream of Xite is Tsx (Testes-specific X-linked).

Highly expressed in mouse testes and brain (Anguera 2011) (Simmler 1996), (Cunningham 1999) In mouse testes, expression is increased 40-fold during meiosis, specifically in pachytene-stage spermatocytes (Anguera 2011) Tsx RNA exists as multiple RNA species in pachytene spermatocytes (Anguera 2011) Expressed during mouse preimplantaion development (Sebastiano 2004) decreasing from a peak at 2-cell stage (5-10 fold higher in femail ES) during differentiation (Anguera 2011) search for Tsx peptides has not identified matches in the extensive mouse or human proteomic databases to date, sequence is not translated in vitro (Anguera 2011).

DKO females have mildly reduced fertility with a slight favoring of female births (Anguera 2011) DKO has no effect on male fertility but does decrease testis size (assoc with increased apoptosis (Anguera 2011). KO likely affects specific enhancement of short-term hippocampal memory, at least in male mice (Anguera 2011). KO ES cells are growth retarded and prodice smaller embryoid bodies, poorer attachment and may induce ectopic Xist expression by blunting the upregulation of Tsix during ES cell differentiation (Anguera 2011).
absent in marsupials, Tsx partially aligns to genomic sequences in chickens (Duret 2006) believed to be a pseudogene in some species such as human, cow, and dog (Chureau 2002)

Dramatically increased in human HCC compared with noncancerous adjacent tissues (Braconi 2010)
siRNA to TUC338 decreased both anchorage-dependent and anchorage-independent growth of HCC cells (Braconi 2010)
TUC339 was functionally implicated in modulating tumor cell growth and adhesion. Suppression of TUC339 by siRNA reduced HCC cell proliferation, clonogenic growth, and growth in soft agar (Kogure 2013)
Highly expressed in exosomes (Kogure 2013)
Malat1: Metastasis-associated lung adenocarcinoma transcript 1 Neat2: Nuclear enriched abundant transcript 2

Intergenic ~7kb single exon transcript ((Ji 2003), (Hutchinson 2007)).
A conserved tRNA-like sequence at the 3' end is cleaved off and processed to generated a short tRNA-like ncRNA mascRNA (MALAT1-associated small cytoplasmic RNA) ((Wilusz 2008)).
Post transcriptional processing of Malat1 therefore allows two ncRNAs to be created from the one original transcript ((Wilusz 2008)).

Both Malat1 and the processed mascRNA transcript are expressed in a wide range of tissues ((Ji 2003), (Hutchinson 2007), (Wilusz 2008)), (Bernard 2010)), ((Ulitsky 2011)).
Malat1 is highly expressed in the brain. RNA fluorescence in-situ hybridization (RNA-FISH) on adult mouse brain sections showed high expression of nuclear-localized Malat1 transcripts in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus, Purkinje cells of the cerebellum and neurons of the substantia nigra and motoneurons, but very low levels in non-neuronal cells ((Bernard 2010)). In the hippocampus and in Purkinje cells, Malat1 was first detected between post-natal day 0 (P0) and P7 and its level increased until P28 ((Bernard 2010)). This high expression appears to come from up-regulation of Malat1 during differentiation, with in-vitro differentiation of neural stem cells showing significant up-regulation of expression in neuronal and glial differentiated progeny ((Mercer 2010)).
Expressed in the nucleus accumbens of normal human brains and upregulated in this brain region in heroin abusers ((Michelhaugh 2010)).
In neuroblastoma cells Malat1 was up-regulated by the hormone oxytocin ((Koshimizu 2010)).
Malat1 is up-regulated in a range of cancers ((Ji 2003), (Yamada 2006), (Lin 2006), (Guffanti 2009)).
High expression of Malat1 is associated with metastasis in certain histological subtypes of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and is predictive of poor prognosis ((Ji 2003)).
Malat1 is up-regulated in placenta previa increta/percreta, a disease characterised by excessive invasion of fetal placental trophoblasts into the uterus ((Tseng 2009)).
Malat1 is stable in human B cells and Hela and wt MEFs (half-life >7 hrs) but has significantly lower stability in mouse 3T3 and N2A cells. Suggesting differences in Malat1 stability both within and between species ((Friedel 2009), (Bernard 2010), (Clark 2012), (Tani 2012)).
Malat1 localises to SC35 domain nuclear speckles in several cell lines ((Hutchinson 2007)) ((Clemson 2009)). Localisation to nuclear speckles is transcription-dependent, as RNA pol II inhibition promoted re-distribution of Malat1 ncRNA from nuclear speckles to a homogenous nuclear localisation ((Bernard 2010)). Malat1 co-localises with pre-mRNA-splicing factor SF2/ASF and CC3 antigen in the nuclear speckles ((Bernard 2010)).
MALAT1 is enriched in nuclear speckles in interphase cells and concentrates in mitotic interchromatin granule clusters (IGCs, structural analogs of nuclear speckles present in mitotic cells), but unlike Neat1 it is not required for the structural integrity of the nuclear domain ((Tripathi 2010)).
mascRNA derived from Malat1 is transported to the cytoplasm ((Wilusz 2008)).

Summary: Malat1 has been found to regulate alternative splicing of endogenous target genes, and it is implicated in cancer and a series of molecular and cellular phenotypes, as indicated below.
Identified as an oncogene that promotes tumorigensis. Expression of a Malat1 fragment in NIH 3T3 cells transformed cells ((Li 2009)).
Knockdown inhibited cell mobility and lead to decreased expression of several genes (CTHRC1, CCT4, HMMR, or ROD1) that promoted cell migration ((Tano 2010)). This result may also explain why knockdown inhibited trophoblast-like cell invasion in-vitro, with MALAT1 hypothesised to regulate the level of trophoblast invasion into the uterus in vivo ((Tseng 2009)).
MALAT1 depletion resulted in aberrant mitosis, with a large fraction of cells accumulating at G2/M boundary, and increased cell death ((Tripathi 2010)).
Depletion of Malat1 in neuroblastoma cells indicated that Malat1 affects the expression of genes involved not only in the organization and the function of the nucleus, but also in synapse function and dendrite development. In cultured hippocampal neurons, knock-down of Malat1 decreased synaptic density, whereas its over-expression resulted in a cell-autonomous increase in synaptogenesis ((Bernard 2010)).
There is a significant enrichment for SRSF1 (SF2/ASF) binding sites within the 5' half of both human and mouse MALAT1, whose direct interaction has been demonstrated, and is dependent on its canonical RRM (RRM1) or the pseudo RRM (RRM2) domains ((Sanford 2009), (Tripathi 2010)). Independent sequence elements in MALAT1 influence its distribution to nuclear speckles and the recruitment of SRSF1 ((Tripathi 2010)).
Additional interactions have been found between MALAT1 and SRSF1, SRSF2, and SRSF3 proteins, but only weak interactions with SRSF5 and PSP1 (an RNA-binding protein that is a component of paraspeckles) have been identified ((Tripathi 2010)).
Knock-down of nuclear Malat1 in a transfected U2OS cell line showed that it modulates the recruitment of SR proteins (SRSF1 or SF2/ASF and SC35) to a transcriptionally active transgene array (stably integrated), indicating a role in the regulation of the association of pre-mRNA-splicing factors to transcription sites and control of post-transcriptional gene expression ((Bernard 2010)). Malat1 modulates the speckle association of a subset of pre-mRNA splicing factors, such as SF1, U2AF-65, SF3a60, and B-U2snRNP ((Tripathi 2010)).
Malat1-depleted HeLa cells show increased cellular levels of dephosphorylated SRSF1 (SF2/ASF) ((Bernard 2010)), as well as a moderately increased cytoplasmic pool of poly(A)+ RNA ((Tripathi 2010)). It has recently been shown to regulate alternative splicing of endogenous target genes by modulating SR splicing factor phosphorylation, affecting their levels and the distribution and ratio of phosphorylated to dephosphorylated pools ((Tripathi 2010)).
Suggested to interact with the PRC2 complex in the HCT-116 cancer cell line ((Guil 2012)).

Therian mammals (found in oppossum as well as placental mammals) ((Hutchinson 2007)).
Recently described in zebrafish. Sequence homology to zebrafish was limited to the 3â€™ end, but the ~7kb long, single exon structure as well as positional synteny was conserved, as was the high expression in brain found identified in mammals ((Ulitsky 2011)).
HOTAIRM1: HOX antisense intergenic RNA myeloid 1

Bidirectional transcript with HoxA1. Located between HOXA1 and HOXA2 genes ((Sessa 2006), (Sasaki 2007), (Zhang 2009)).
Identified transcript is 483 nt ((Zhang 2009)) but other splice isoforms are also likely to be expressed.

Expressed in the myeloid lineage ((Zhang 2009)). Has also been identified as showing a similar expression pattern to HoxA1 and A2 with expression in thymus, muscle, colon, lung, kidney, spleen etc ((Sessa 2006), (Sasaki 2007)).
Induced by retinoic acid (RA) ((Sessa 2006), (Zhang 2009)).
Shows collinear regulation of expression like HOX PTC genes ((Sessa 2006)).
Expressed in mouse embryonic stem cells (ESCs) ((Guttman 2011))

HOTAIRM plays a role in the regulation of gene expression during RA-induced myeloid differentiation ((Zhang 2009)). Knock-down of HOTAIRM prevented induction of HOXA1 and HOXA4 expression during myeloid differentiation as well as the induction of myeloid differentiation genes CD11b and CD18 ((Zhang 2009)).
Found to interact with a number of of chromatin binding proteins/complexes in mouse embryonic stem cells including PRC1, PRC2 and CBX1 ((Guttman 2011)).
Sequence quite highly conserved in mammals, with transcripts also detected in mouse and rat ((Zhang 2009)).

DHFR upstream transcripts initiate from an upstream minor promoter of the DHFR (dihydrofolate reductase) gene and extend from approximately 400 nucleotide upstream of the 5'-untranslated region of DHFR (which corresponds to DHFR major/core promoter), to the second intron of the DHFR gene where they terminate ((Masters 1985), (Martianov 2007)). Therefore, the region located between minor and major transcript initiation sites (~400 bp) corresponds to a noncoding transcript and is a promoter of DHFR.
Discrete DHRF upstream initiating transcripts of diverse sizes have been reported, including five major discrete species with sizes of 4.3, 3.8, 3.1, 2.1, and 1.0 kb and four minor ones with sizes of 7.3, 5.0, 1.4, and 0.8kb. Primarily in the poly(A)+ fraction ((Masters 1985)).
DHFR upstream transcripts adopt a series of structures in vitro that are dependent on the G-tract encompassed in its sequence ((Blume 2002)).

Enriched in the nucleus ((Masters 1985)).
At least six minor 5' ends mapping upstream of the DHFR gene correspond to approximately 1% of the DHFR-specific polysomal polyA RNA. Most of these species have been found in 6A3 cells, VA2-B cells (the parental line of 6A3), and in HeLa cells ((Masters 1985)).
DHFR upstream transcripts accumulate in a population of serum-starved, contact-inhibited (quiescent) U2OS cells, in which the levels of DHFR mRNA are markedly reduced ((Martianov 2007)).

Initial studies indicated that DHFR upstream transcripts could impair the formation of the preinitiation complex (PIC) on the major promoter in vitro, thereby repressing the transcriptional activity of the major DHFR promoter ((Blume 2002)). DHFR upstream transcripts were shown to inhibit transcription from the DHFR core promoter in-trans in a concentration-dependent manner in in-vitro runoff transcription assays. Transcription factor binding sites positioned between the minor and major promoters within the DHFR gene were indicated to be affected by the upstream regulatory transcripts, which selectively sequestered transcription factor Sp3, and to a lesser extent Sp1, preventing their binding to the DHRF core promoter. The sequestration of Sp3 and Sp1 by the DHFR upstream transcripts appears to involve an altered conformation of the RNA, and a structural domain of the protein distinct from that required for binding DNA ((Blume 2002)). However, in-vitro experiments confirmed that transcription from the major promoter could be suppressed in-trans in the absence of Sp1 or any other upstream activating sequence ((Akoulitchev 1995), (Martianov 2007)).
A more recent study demonstrated that these promoter associated transcripts act as interfering transcripts, directly interacting with TFIIB and dissociate the PIC efficiently to repress DHFR expression ((Martianov 2007)). Transcription of the regulatory RNA in trans has a repressive effect on the major DHFR promoter only when the transcript contained the sequence of the core major DHFR promoter ((Martianov 2007)). In addition, the major DHFR promoter is GC-rich and contains several G-track sequences ((Blume 2002)), and specific and stable triplex structures have been shown to form between the DHFR upstream transcripts and the major promoter, which may contribute to promoter targeting and repression in vivo ((Martianov 2007)) ((Blume 2002)).
A comparison of in-vitro transcription from templates containing DHFR minor, major or both promoters in their original sequential order indicated very low transcriptional activity when the minor promoter preceded the major one, but robust transcription from the major promoter, suggesting that transcriptional interference in-cis may also play a role in DHFR inhibition by DHFR upstream transcripts ((Martianov 2007)).

Unpublished analysis of the epigenetic effects of DHFR upstream transcripts indicated similarities to epigenetic markers associated with transcriptional gene silencing induced by the targeted application of synthetic antigene RNAs complementary to the promoter regions of mammalian genes ((Martianov 2007)).
DHFR is the major target of methotrexate, a key component in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) treatment. DNA variations of major promoter/noncoding transcript region and specifc haplotype subtypes involving this region have been associated with childhood ALL, including associations with high-risk patients and lower event-free survival. One particular haplotype (Haplotype *1b) is associated with higher DHFR expression ((Al-Shakfa 2009)).
Zinc finger antisense 1

Expressed from a bi-directional promoter with the protein-coding gene Znfx1. Zfas1 5, is antisense to 5, of Znfx1.
Spliced, polyadenylated.
SnoRNA host gene, contains 3 intronic C/D box snoRNAs.
Human orthologue is alternatively spliced.

Highly expressed and differentially expressed during mammary development. Strongly down-regulated during lactation compared to pregnancy and then up-regulated again during involution. Znfx1 coding gene,in contrast, was more lowly expressed and was not differentially expressed during mammary gland development.
Expressed in the epithelial cells of the mammary gland ducts and alveoli.
Zfas1 is widely expressed in mouse tissues including brain, liver, lung, kidney, spleen, heart and embryo, showing higher expression than Znfx1.
Zfas1 extremely stable with a half life of >32 hrs in N2A (neuroblastoma) cells. Compared to a half life of 50 minutes for Znfx1. The increased stability of Zfas1 may explain why its expression level is much higher than Znfx1. However, in mouse 3T3 and embryonic stem cells Zfas1 stability was much lower with a half-life of 1.7 hr and 63 min respectively, while the human ZFAS1 had a half-life of 3 hr in B-cells ((Friedel 2009), (Sharova 2008), (Clark 2012)). These results suggest there is significant regulation of Zfas1 stability both within and between species ((Clark 2012)).
Localised to both the nucleus and the cytoplasm.
Human ZFAS1 expression is reduced in ductal carinoma compared to normal tissue.

Zfas1 appears to have a role in mammary gland proliferation and differentiation.
- Zfas1 knockdown in a HC11 cell culture model of mammary differentiation showed increased differentiation and a probable increase in proliferation. Knockdown had little effect on intronic snoRNA expression suggesting the Zfas1 host transcript is functional.
- Zfas1 knockdown appears to affect Znfx1 expression.

Syntenic transcription observed in multiple mammals.
Low conservation of Zfas1 sequence between human and mouse compared to snoRNAs, but Zfas1 has potential secondary structural similarities.
Psoriasis susceptibility-related RNA Gene Induced by Stress (PRINS)
~3.6 kb, transcribed by RNA Polymerase II; spliced (2 exons) and polyadenylated ((Sonkoly 2005)).

Elevated expression in psoriatic epidermis. Regulated by the proliferation and differentiation state of keratinocytes ((Sonkoly 2005)).
Expressed at different levels in various human tissues, with highest levels detected in veins ((Sonkoly 2005)).
Several stress signals such as ultraviolet-B (UV-B) irradiation, viral infection (herpes simplex virus), and translational inhibition increased the RNA level of PRINS ((Sonkoly 2005)), as well as HaCaT keratinocyte cell treatment with microbial agents such as bacteria peptidoglycan, lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and wall extract ((Bari 2011)).

siRNA knock-down shows that PRINS is required for cell viability after serum starvation ((Sonkoly 2005)), and also alters cell morphology and gene expression ((Szegedi 2010)).
Elevated PRINS expression in the epidermis is suggested to contribute to psoriasis susceptibility ((Sonkoly 2005)).
In keratinocytes PRINS regulates the expression of the G1P3 gene, an anti-apoptotic protein that is overexpressed in psoriasis ((Szegedi 2010)), although the mechanism is unknown.

PRINS RNA contains contains two Alu elements, as well as a short sequence stretch with ~70% similarity to an element in a small cytoplasmic noncoding RNA, named G8, from Tetrahymena thermophila, whose expression responds to heat shock and is involved in thermotolerance ((Sonkoly 2005)).
Overexpressed in HCC over normal. Not associated with other clinicopathological features. Higher expression associated with poor outcome (n=52). Negatively correlated with nearby TSG ZAK (Xu 2014).
KD decreased cell viability, blocking of entry into S-phase and increased apoptosis. Mechanism seems to be through negative regulation of ZAK by URHC (Xu 2014)
Located on a discrete locus at 6q16.1. Found binding to polypyrimidine tract-binding (PTB) protein-associated splicing factor protein from RNA SELEX experiment
Human melanoma
Knocking down Llme23 remarkably suppressed the malignant property of YUSAC cells, accompanied by the repressed expression of proto-oncogene Rab23.
3 exons ((Zhao (2013)))
Sensory neurons of rat dorsal root ganglion, activated by myeloid zinc finger protein 1 ((Zhao (2013)))

Overexpression of this RNA in rat decreases expression of Kcna2, reduces total voltage-gated potassium current, increases excitability in DRG neurons and produces neuropathic pain symptoms ((Zhao (2013)))
Expressed in liver cells in mouse and human (Xu (2013)).

Associated with Wnt/B-catenin signaling during liver regeneration (Xu (2013)). Enhances hepatocyte proliferation by promoting progression of the cell cycle in vitro - more specifically it facilitated cyclin D1 expression through activation of Wnt/B-catenin signaling by way of suppression of Axin1 (Xu (2013)).
a-globin transcript long non-coding RNA
a long non-coding RNA (CPC score <-1) of about 23 kb is transcribed in the a-globin domain

The relative abundance of lncRNA-aGT is orders of magnitude less than the a-globin genes. lncRNA-aGT transcript is absent in undifferentiated HD3 cells, which do not express globin genes, and increases (with associated H3K4me and PolII marks) during differentiationof chickenerythroid cells indicating correlation with a-globin expression. (Arriaga-Canon 2013))

lncRNA-aGT is important for full activation of adult chicken a-globin genes, and favors maintenance of promoter structuring into transcriptionally permissive chromatin. Ablation of lncRNA-aGT caused down-regulation of the adult aD gene, and its presence correlated with enrichment of H3K4me3 over the adult aD gene promoter (Arriaga-Canon 2013).
SNHG4: Small nucleolar RNA host gene 4

Upstream from the Matrin 3 protein coding gene. A number of splice isoforms of SNHG4 exist, some of which join Matrin3 and so act as an upstream initiation site for Matrin 3.
SNHG4 specific isoforms appear to contain the first four SNHG4 exons and differ at the 3' end.
Contains U19 snoRNA in intron 3 (annotated as SNORA74A in Refseq).
Transcriptional start site has characteristics of the 5' TOP gene family.

Expressed in a number of adult human tissues.
Shows a nucleoplasmic localisation. In constrast to other SNHG RNA (SNHG1, SNHG3) which are localised in the cytoplasm.
Human SNHG4 isoforms 1&2 were highly stable in B cells (half-life >8 hr), while mouse Snhg4 was highly unstable in mouse 3T3 cells, suggesting differential stability between species ((Friedel 2009), (Clark 2012)).
Likely present in mouse with same relationship with Matrin 3
Head to head natural antisense transcript of DHRS4. 1865nt, 3 exons, spliced and polyadenylated RNA transcribed from intron 1 of the DHRS4 gene (Li 2012). Four transcript variants exist.
Located in both the cytoplasm and nucleus. Expressed in multiple normal and cancer cell lines (Li 2012).

Regulates expression of DHRS4, DHRS4L1 and DHRS4L2. Controls the epigenetic status of the promotors of these three genes by mediating repressive histone modifications in the promoter regions. Regulates DHSR4 in cis, and DHRS4L1 and DHRS4L2 in trans. Interacts with H3K9 and H3K27 methyltransferases to silence DHRS4L1 and DHRS4L2. Induces methylation of DHRS4L2 promotor by recruiting methyltransferases (Li 2012).

~900bp in humans. Contains a 'human accelerated region' (HAR). Overlaps with an antisense noncoding RNA, HAR1A ((Pollard 2006)).
Two splice isoforms, one with 2 exons, one with 3 exons ((Pollard 2006)).
Conserved HAR1 sequence (common to both HAR1A and HAR1B) forms a secondary structure which is highly conserved ((Pollard 2006)) but has undergone changes from a hairpin structure in chimps to a cloverleaf structure in humans ((Beniaminov 2008)).

Expression was found in adult brain, ovary and testis in human. Expression level was much lower than HAR1A ((Pollard 2006)).
Repressed transcriptionally by REST, which causes repression of HAR1B in striatum of Huntington's disease patients ((Johnson 2010)).
The mouse locus is expressed during embryonic development (peak at E15) and in adults it is specifically expressed in the brain. Unlike in human, "HAR1B" was expressed at similar levels to "HAR1A" in mouse ((Pollard 2006)).

Contains a 'human accelerated region', which is a sequence highly conserved in amniotes (negative selection) but which has evolved rapidly in the human lineage (positive selection) since the divergence of humans and chimpanzees from the last common ancestor (18 bases out of 118 are different between human and chimpanzee but only 2 differences between chimpanzee and chicken) ((Pollard 2006)).
Rest of HAR1B sequence has little conservation outside of chimp and macaque ((Pollard 2006)).

~2.8kb, spliced 2 exon transcript. Contains a 'human accelerated region' (HAR). Overlaps with an antisense noncoding RNA, HAR1B ((Pollard 2006)).
Conserved HAR1 sequence (common to both HAR1A and HAR1B) forms a secondary structure which is highly conserved ((Pollard 2006)) but has undergone changes from a hairpin structure in chimps to a cloverleaf structure in humans ((Beniaminov 2008)).

Expressed in adult brain and during cortical development ((Pollard 2006)).
Expressed in Cajal-Retzius neurons in the neocortex during early to mid-gestation (7-9 to 17-19 weeks) in humans and macaques ((Pollard 2006)).
During mid-gestation expressed in developing hippocampus, dentate gyrus and cerebellar cortex in human. Expression was found in adult brain, ovary and testis ((Pollard 2006)).
Repressed transcriptionally by REST, which causes repression of HAR1A in the striatum of Huntington's disease patients ((Johnson 2010)).
The overlapping antisense RNA (HAR1B) is also expressed in adult brain ((Pollard 2006)).
In mouse, locus is expressed during embryonic development (peak at E15) and in adults it is specifically expressed in the brain ((Pollard 2006)).

Contains a 'human accelerated region', which is a sequence highly conserved in amniotes (negative selection) but which has evolved rapidly in the human lineage (positive selection) since the divergence of humans and chimpanzees from the last common ancestor (18 bases out of 118 are different between human and chimpanzee but only 2 differences between chimpanzee and chicken) ((Pollard 2006)).
HAR1A has orthologues in a number of closely mammals but in mouse and more distantly related species only the HAR1 sequence is conserved ((Pollard 2006)).
Zeb2NAT: Zeb2 natural antisense transcript
>1.2 kb; antisense to Zeb2 (a transcriptional repressor of E-cadherin) ((Nelles 2003)).
Expression is upregulated by Snail1 ((Beltran 2008)).

Controls translation and therefore function of the Zeb2 protein coding gene through regulation of Zeb2 mRNA splicing ((Beltran 2008)).
Zeb2 translation requires retention of an intron, Zeb2NAT overlaps the 5' splicing site of this intron and when expressed inhibits splicing allowing translation of Zeb2 ((Beltran 2008)).
Snail1 acts to stimulate Zeb2 synthesis via post-transcriptional regulation which appears to be mediated by Zeb2NAT ((Beltran 2008)).
Good conservation between human and mouse ((Nelles 2003)).
SPRY4 intronic transcript 1 (non-protein coding)

Single exon ~700 nt transcript expressed in sense direction from the 2nd intron in SPRY4.
Contains a SINE at 5' end.
Secondary structure predicted to contain several long hairpins and multiple pseudoknots

Expression significantly up-regulated in melanoma cell lines and patient tumour samples (both primary and metastatic) compared to melanocytes and keratinocytes.
SPRY4-IT1 showed much greater expression variation across 20 human tissue than SPRY4. Both showed positively correlated expression and depending on the tissue either could be more highly expressed than the other.
Knockdown of SPRY4-IT1 did not affect expression levels of SPRY4, validating that the two transcripts are independent.
Localized predominately in the cytoplasm. Larger punctate nuclear signal could be transcription sites.

Knockdown of SPRY4-IT1 in melanoma cells lines decreased cell viability, increased cell apoptosis
SPRY4-IT1 impacts cell invasion and cell mobility with decreased invasion and motility in SPRY4-IT1 knockdown cells and increased mobility (faster speed of migration) in SPRY4-IT1 over-expressing cell lines.
Not well conserved outside of primate, with 5' SINE element and predicted secondary structural elements only present in primates.

SPRY4 protein coding gene is also more highly expressed in melanoma cells and patient samples compared to melanocytes.
It is unclear if SPRY4-IT1 has a separate promoter or is transcribed as part of the SPRY4 transcript.
DISC2: Disrupted-In-Schizophrenia 2

Along with DISC1 identified as a gene disrupted by translocation in a family with schizophrenia ((Millar 2000)).
Antisense to DISC1, and covers one DISC1 exon ((Millar 2000)).
Contains a number of repeat sequences. SINEs, LINES and a DNA transposon ((Millar 2000)).
Exact length and structure not certain. Described as unspliced and may be more than 15kb long. Polyadenylated. ((Millar 2000)).

Expressed in adult heart, saw transcripts of >9.5, ~6, ~3 and ~2.5kb ((Millar 2000)).
Detected in several fetal tissues including heart and brain ((Millar 2000)).
Identified in humans, not found in mouse ((Taylor 2003)).

Genebank accession for 15kb genomic sequence corresponding to DISC2: AF222981.1
Refseq lists DISC2 as a 3.9kb unspliced RNA. Accession: NR_002227.2
3 transcripts: ENST00000355358 (2214bp, 2 exons), ENST00000420815 (650bp, 3 exons) and ENST00000438755 (675bp, 3 exons).

Expressed in primary TH2 cells and largely undetectable or with limited expression in other tissues (Zhang 2013). GATA3-AS1 and GATA3 were significantly correlated (Zhang 2013). GATA3-AS1 expression increased in patients with a TH2-associated diseases such as seasonal allergic rhinitis (Zhang 2013).

Retropseudogene, from retro-tranposition of processed ataxin-7â€“like protein 3 (Atxn7l3). Most of ORF degraded, remaining homologous 97 a.a ORF not found to encode a stable protein product.
Single exon
Mouse Lnc-SCA7 has 6 miRNA-response elements (MREs) for miR-124

Expressed in a range of tissues, highly expressed in brain in mouse and human
Within mouse brain regions, highest expression observed in retina and cerebellum.
Expression correlates well with ATXN7 level in mouse and human
Cytoplasmic localisation

Positively regulates level of Atxn7 mRNA and protein (in mouse cell culture). Both Lnc-SCA7 and Atxn7 have conserved MREs for miR-124, by competing for miR-124, Lnc-SCA7 regulates the level of Atxn7.
Atnx7 is a member of the STAGA transcriptional activation complex. Lnc-SCA7 also positively regulates the expression level of many other members of the STAGA complex with which it shares MREs, including for miR-124. Nb: Would hypothesise this regulation is a mix of direct and indirect effects.
Feedback loop: STAGA transcriptional activation complex, (of which Atxn7 is a member) transcriptionally activates miR-124. Lnc-SCA7 regulates levels of many STAGA complex RNAs, likely by competing for miRNAs, preventing them from inhibiting Atnx7 and other STAGA component RNAs.
In spinocerebellar ataxia type 7 (SCA7) this feedback loop is broken (results from fibroblasts derived from human patients and a mouse models of SCA7). The polyQ-repeat expansion in ATXN7 leads to less active STAGA, lower miR-124 levels and increased levels of Lnc-SCA7 and the abnormal ATXN7 in brain tissue.
