It is hypothesised this occurs in the brain because this is the tissue where the lncRNA, microRNA and ATXN7 are most highly expressed and therefore the loss of miR-124 repression could lead to disease by allowing the accumulation of sufficient levels of abnormal ATXN7 protein .
Function does not require 97 a.a ORF suggesting Lnc-SCA7 function is RNA directed.
Summary: Through crosstalk with miR-124 and other miRNAs, Lnc-SCA7 regulates the level of ATNX7 and other members of the STAGA transcriptional activation complex.

Placental mammals, arose via the retrotranspositon of a Atxn7 paralog, ataxin-7â€“like protein 3 (Atxn7l3), in common ancestor of placental mammals.
miR-124 MREs conserved in both mouse and human lnc-SCA7
Expressed in prostate (Yang 2013), (Chung 2010) and colorectal cancer (Li 2013).

Binds to the androgen receptor and enhances both androgen-receptor-mediated gene activation and proliferation in prostate cancer cells (Yang 2013). Binding of PRNCR1 to the carboxy-terminally acetylated androgen receptor on enhancers and its association with DOT1L is required for recruitment of the second lncRNA, PCGEM1 (Yang 2013). DOT1L, CARM1, GADD45 and AR specifically associated with in vitro transcribed biotinylated PRNCR1, as identified by mass spectrometry (Yang 2013). The finding is challenged by Prensner et al. who do not find association of this gene with poor patient outcome in a cohort of 230 (Prensner 2014).
Expressed in colon crypt cells (Franklin 2013).

Colonocytes transformed by ncNRFR are highly invasive and metastatic. ncNRFR has a region similar to the miRNA, let-7 family. ncNRFR expression alters let-7 activity as measured by reporter construct. ncNRFR expression upregulates let-7b targets (Franklin 2013).
Located at 1q32.1. Preferentially localises to the nucleus (Lin 2013).
Overexpressed in bladder cancer (BC). Expression correlates with lymph node metastasis, poor survival in BC patients (Lin 2013).

Regulates poliferation of bladder cancer cells. Acts in trans, binding to the PRC2 complex, modulating histone methylation of target genes by regulating its localisation. siRNA knockdown results in decreased tumour cell poliferation, cell motility, invasiveness and colony formation in vitro, and less lung colonisation in vivo (Lin 2013).
685 bp long, 3 exons, no open reading frame (Tran (2012)).
Expressed in lung, thyroid gland, brain and placenta, identified in Duchenne muscular dystrophy patient with mental retardation (Tran (2012)).
Nctc1 is co-regulated with Igf2 and H19 and physically interacts with the shared muscle enhancer (Eun (2012)).

Consists of 4 exons, spanning greater than 40kb of genomic DNA. Exon 1 is unique within the genome, and exons 2, 3, and 4 overlap with repetitive elements. Promoter region contains SNP rs944289 ((Jendrzejewski 2012)).

Almost uniquely expressed in thyroid, however also has very low expression in kidney. Down-regulated in papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) tissues. Risk allele rs944289[T] decreases PTCSC3 promoter activity ((Jendrzejewski 2012)).
Expression inhibits PTC cell growth and alters expression of genes involved in DNA replication, recombination, and repair in vitro ((Jendrzejewski 2012)).

2 RNAs of ~5 and ~5.5kb transcribed antisense to the frequency (frq) gene ((Aronson 1994), (Kramer 2003)).
Antisense transcription initiates at several sites (217, 241 and 278bp) downstream of the frq sense stop codon ((Kramer 2003)).

Antisense RNA showed a cyclic expression pattern but with the opposite rhythm to frq sense RNA and at a lower expression level when Neurospora was grown in the dark ((Kramer 2003)).
Strongly up-regulated when cells exposed to light (as is frq sense) ((Kramer 2003)).

Required for entrainment of the circadian clock in Neurospora crassa ((Kramer 2003)).
Loss of antisense transcript altered circadian rhythms with the clock set several hours earlier than normal and causing delayed onset of rhythmic conidiation (spore production) ((Kramer 2003)).
Antisense transcripts were also necessary for proper clock resetting on exposure to light. In the wild type light exposure caused a small resetting of the clock, while loss of antisense transcripts caused a massive resetting of the clock ((Kramer 2003)).
Cyclic expression of the the sense frequency RNA (and frq protein) is required for Neurospora circadian timing.
ncR-uPAR: non-protein coding RNA, upstream of F2R/PAR1

~400 bp. RNA polymerase II transcript. Found several kb upstream of the human protease-activated receptor-1 (PAR-1) gene.
Mostly made up of repeat sequences including an Alu element.

Expressed during embryonic development.
Presence of the ncR-uPAR promoter sequence drives expression of a transgene during embryonic vascular development at E9, which recapitulates PAR-1 expression at E9 quite well. At E16 expression was seen in brain and in arteries but not veins.

ncR-uPAR can act in-trans to stimulate PAR-1 expression.
ncR-uPAR binds nuclear proteins in-vivo, which could provide a mechanism for it to positively regulate the PAR-1 promoter during embryogenesis.

Refseq ncR-uPAR appears to be the ncR-uPAR promoter and the lncRNA sequence. UCSC genomic co-ordinates are to this Refseq annotation, while the sequence provided is from the identified transcriptional start site to the end of the polyadenylation sites (exact 3' terminus is unknown).

2.3 kb. Imprinted at the Igf2 locus ((Bartolomei 1991), (Zemel 1992)).
Also contains a microRNA (miR-675) in exon one ((Cai 2007)).

Expressed from the maternal allele, while the neighbouring Igf2 gene is transcribed from the paternal allele ((Bartolomei 1991)).
In mice, H19 is activated in extra-embryonic cell types at the time of implantation. Strongly expressed during embryogenesis, down-regulated after birth with strong expression only retained in skeletal muscle and cartilage ((Pachnis 1984), (Pachnis 1988), (Poirier 1991), (Castle 2010), (Dudek 2010)); upregulated in various tumors ((Matouk 2007)).
Can be found in both the nucleus and the cytoplasm ((Runge 2000), (Schoenfelder 2007), (Brannan 1990)).

Complex functions:
Influences growth via control of Igf2 expression, with a H19 knockout showing an overgrowth phenotype due in part to bi-allelic expression of Igf2 ((Ripoche 1997)).
Can also function in trans to downregulate the expression of a number of imprinted genes in the hypothesised Imprinted Gene Network (IGN) including Igf2r, Dlk1 etc. Allowing H19 to regulate growth during development ((Gabory 2009)).
Implicated as both a tumor suppressor ((Hao 1993), (Yoshimizu 2008)) and an oncogene upregulated by c-myc and hypoxia ((Matouk 2007), (Barsyte-Lovejoy 2006) and references therein). A number of reports have also shown upregulation / reactivation of H19 in various cancers although the functional significance (if any) is unclear in many cases ((Gabory 2010), (Adriaenssens 1998)).
The mode of action by which H19 functions is still unclear:
Focusing on its regulation of Igf2, H19 has been hypothesised to act at the level of transcription since an H19 knockout lead to methylation changes and loss of imprinting of Igf2 ((Ripoche 1997), FornÃ© (1997)). However, H19 can bind Igf2 mRNA binding-protein (IMP) family members ((Runge 2000)), which appear to act to promote translation of Igf2 ((Hansen 2004), (Liao 2005)), therefore competition between Igf2 and H19 for IMP1 binding may allow H19 to regulate Igf2 post-transcriptionally.
Both sense and antisense transcripts from the H19 locus were identified as binding to the PRC2 chromatin modification complex in mouse embryonic stem cells, suggesting a potential function for H19 RNA ((Zhao 2010)).
miR-675 may be responsible for the oncogenic activity of H19 as it was found to down-regulate the tumour suppressor retinoblastoma (RB) in human colorectal cancer, causing increased tumour cell growth ((Tsang 2009)). Also, in adult human chondrocytes, expression of H19 (and subsequently miR-675) is driven by SOX9 with miR-675 acting to positively regulate COL2A1 which encodes a collagen protein important to the cartilage matrix ((Dudek 2010)).
H19 appears to be a bi-functional RNA acting as both a miRNA and a lncRNA. Such properties may help to explain the conflicting reports that it is both a tumour suppressor and an oncogene ((Smits 2008)). Additionally its effect on tumour development may be heavily context dependent ((Gabory 2010)).
Conserved and imprinted in therians (eutherians and marsupials). Both the miRNA and the H19 lncRNA exon structure are conserved ((Smits 2008)).
First long noncoding RNA described in mammalian cells ((Brannan 1990)). Gabory 2010 provides a useful review of some of the extensive literature on H19 ((Gabory 2010)).
LincRNA ~100kb from the Sox2 transcription factor in mouse ((Guttman 2009)).

Expressed in embryonic stem cells but not in other cells tested ((Guttman 2009)).
Promoter bound by Oct4 and Nanog ((Guttman 2009)).
Promoter cloning showed expression can be driven by Sox2 and Oct4 individually and synergistically ((Guttman 2009)).
The chromosomal position of the lincRNA given in Guttman et al., (2009) is quite broad, however it is probable that it corresponds to the sequence, Accession ID and Browser link provided.
It has a antisense trancsripts. MHM sense is localised to the nucleas while the antisense transcripts is localised to the cytoplasm.
MHM is expressed in females, while it is methylated and silenced in males (Roeszler 2012).

Overexpression of MHM induced general ovegrowth of tissues, disruption of normal gonadal differentiation and brain defects (Roeszler 2012). In females overexpression lead to enlarged ovaries. Overexpression in males leads to lowered gonodal expression of the testis gene DMRT1 (Roeszler 2012).

LincRNA enriched in ESC (embryonic stem cells) and iPSCS (induced pluripotent stem cells) compared to the fibroblast and CD34 cells the iPSCs were derived from.
Also more highly expressed in iPSCs than ESCs.
Locus is a binding site for pluripotency transcription factors Oct4, Sox2 and Nanog. Knockdown of Oct4 or differentiation of stem cells caused down-regulation of lincRNA- SFMBT2 expression. Suggesting expression is controlled by these transcription factors.
Function not certain: knockdown didn,t affect generation of iPSC cells, suggesting it is not essential to this process.
No syntenic correlate expressed in mouse ESCs.

The chromosomal region given in Loewer et al (2010) is for histone modifications and does not identify the precise transcript expressed in stem cells. Furthermore their qPCR primers do not correspond to exonic regions from the known transcript AK094154 at this locus, so no transcript sequence can be given.
lincRNA-SFMBT2 location from histone modifications is: hg19 chr10:6,779,694-6,889,494

overexpression of lncRNA MVIH significantly promoted the growth of HCCLM3 cell tumours in vivo. ((Yuan 2012)) Activates angiogenesis by inhibiting secretion of PGK1. ((Yuan 2012)) Knockdown of MVIH impaires NSCLC cell proliferation and invasion and overexpression of MVIH promotes NSCLC cell viability and invasion in vitro.((Nie 2014))
Located in the 8q24 gene desert. Produces multiple lncRNA splice variants. Also contains a cluster of six miRNAs ((Barsotti 2011)).

Expression correlated with copy number. Expression can be used as a prognostic indicator for colorectal cancer patients ((Takahashi 2013)). Overexpressed in breast and ovarian cancers ((Guan 2007)). Expressed in multiple renal cell types and associated with kidney disease ((Millis 2007)) Upregulated by glucose treatment in human mesangial cells ((Alvarez 2011)). Expression induced by p53 ((Barsotti 2011)).

Expression levels positively correlated with Myc protein expression in human primary tumours ((Tseng 2014)). Generates antiapoptotic activity in CRC ((Takahashi 2013)). Increases cell poliferation ((Cao 2013)). plays a role in cell cycle progression and cellular transformation ((Shtivelman 1989)).knockdown in human mesangial cells significantly reduced mRNA and protein levels of the major ECM proteins, fibronectin and collagen, type IV, alpha 1, and two key regulators of ECM proteins, therefore may contribute to the increased accumulation of ECM in the glomeruli characteristic of diabetic nephropathy ((Alvarez 2013))
**Annotation in Progress**

Family of RNAs.
In legumes, it encodes a conserved 10-25 amino acid peptide, and contains up to six inverted repeats (IRs) (Girard et al. 2003).

***The Enod40 family is expressed in differentiating cells of the primordial nodule (Yang et al. 1993; Crespi et al. 1994), but also has varying levels of expression in all parts of the plant, particularly the vascular system, where its expression correlates with the emergence of lateral roots and emerging leaves (Vleghels et al. 2003, Kouchi et al. 1999, Varkonyi-Gasic and White 2002).***
Expression regulated by growth conditions affecting root tissues ((Campalans 2004)).
ENOD40 transcripts are required for correct subcellular localization of RNP particles in legume plants ((Campalans 2004)).
N/A
N/A

Present in multiple splicing isoforms ((Folkersen 2009)) (such as the CDK2BAS RefSeq sequence NR_003529.3 of ~3.9kb). Also detected as an unspliced transcript of 34.8 kb ((Yu 2008)), specified as p15AS, but which seems to correspond to an isoform with the first intron of CDK2BAS retained. Antisense to the tumor suppressor gene p15/CDKN2A. ((Yu 2008))
Traverses a noncoding region centromeric to CDKN2A, a region containing the INK4b/ARF/INK4a locus and implicated in a range of complex diseases including cancer (such as melanoma-neural system tumor syndrome), type 2 diabetes, periodontitis and coronary heart disease (see extensive reference list in Literature below, and (Popov 2010) for a review).
Transcript found to be quite unstable with a half-life >4 hr in human Hela cells ((Tani 2012)).

Expressed in tissues and cell types affected by atherosclerosis. Increased levels of ANRIL are found in patients carrying the atherosclerosis risk haplotype expression, including in peripheral blood mononuclear cells, whole blood and atherosclerotic plaque tissue, and the levels were directly correlated with the severity of atherosclerosis ((Holdt 2010)).
Up-regulated in prostate cancer ((Yap 2010)).

In vitro over-expression of p15as/ANRIL RNA was originally demonstrated to induce epigenetic silencing of p15 gene expression ((Yu 2008)).
Recently, ANRIL RNA was found to interact and regulate chromobox 7 (CBX7), a component of the Polycomb Repressor Complex 1 (PRC1), which methylates histone H3 lysine 27 to promote epigenetic silencing, and is also up-regulated in prostate cancer. Interaction occurs with a conserved chromodomain of CBX7 and is essential for the ability of PRC1 to repress the INK4b/ARF/INK4a locus and control cell senescence. ((Yap 2010))

Bidirectional promoter with HOXA11. Multiple splice isoforms are present which share a common 3' exon ((Hsieh-Li 1995), (Potter 1998)), only some overlap HOXA11 ((Potter 1998)).
Annotated human isoform is ~1.6kb. A number of isoforms including ~1.4, ~1.9, ~2.9 and ~3.2kb transcripts have been identified in mouse ((Hsieh-Li 1995)).

More highly expressed than HOXA11 in mouse development ((Hsieh-Li 1995)).
Expressed in developing limbs where it showed a complementary expression pattern to HOXA11 ((Hsieh-Li 1995)). Also expressed in fetal kidney ((Potter 1998)), placenta, adult colon, muscle and prostate ((Sessa 2006), (Sasaki 2007)). Shows collinear regulation of expression like HOX PTC genes ((Sasaki 2007)).
Expressed in same cell types as HOXA11 in the uterus. HOXA11as was dynamically expressed in the uterus during the menstrual cycle, with a peak in the endometrial late-proliferative phase, showing a pattern inverse to HOXA11 ((Chau 2002)).
HOXA11as levels were down-regulated by progesterone in primary uterine stromal cells, which correlated with HOXA11 up-regulation in the same cells ((Chau 2002)).

Due to the inverse or complementary expression pattern between Hoxa11 and HOXA11as mRNA expression levels, in the developing limbs ((Hsieh-Li 1995)) and adult endometrium ((Chau 2002)), HOXA11as has been proposed to negatively regulate Hoxa11 mRNA levels ((Chau 2002)).
Sequence highly conserved ((Potter 1998)), found throughout mammals.

Some HOXA11as isoforms have long ORFs, however these ORFs are not conserved between human and mouse (despite high nucleotide sequence conservation) ((Hsieh-Li 1995), (Potter 1998)). So while HOXA11as is thought to be noncoding, a possible role for HOXA11as encoding a protein cannot be completely discounted.

GAL10-ncRNA runs antisense through the GAL10 gene, through the bidirectional GAL1-10 promoter and through to the 3, of GAL1 gene in the sense direction. 4kb transcript.
Transcripts are 5, capped and 3, polyadenylated.

Under non-induced and repressed conditions, marks of active transcription (H3 K4 me2/me3) are not present at GAL protein coding gene promoters but instead found at 3, end of GAL10. Histone modifications require binding of Reb1.
Reb1 drives expression of ncRNAs under repressive, and non-induced nutrient conditions. GAL10-ncRNA was the 4kb major transcript but also a weaker 2.3kb transcript is also present. All characterisation was on the 4kb GAL10-ncRNA.
GAL10-ncRNA stability was tested, half life ~8 min (relatively stable for a yeast transcript) and targeted for degredation by the TRAMP / exosome complexes.
Steady state expression level ~0.07 transcripts per cell / ~ 1 transcript per 14 cells.
Estimate ncRNA transcribed once every 50 minutes.

Summary: GAL10-ncRNA enhances repression of GAL10 and GAL1 expression when yeast are growing in repressive nutrient conditions.
Transcription of GAL10 ncRNA causes changes in chromatin. - H3 K36 me3 is deposited over the chromosomal region GAL10-ncRNA is transcribed from. - GAL10 transcription also causes a decrease in some histone 3 acetlyation.
GAL10 ncRNA acts in cis, recruiting the Rpd3S HDAC complex. Unknown if GAL10 ncRNA can physically recruit any chromatin modifying complexes or if transcription dependent chromatin changes independent of the GAL10-ncRNA sequence are responsible.
Note: this is not a transcriptional interference mechanism (see infrequent GAL10-ncRNA trancription) but a chromatin modification mechanism.

GAL cluster of 3 genes (GAL1, GAL7, GAL10) are involved in galactose metabolism. Yeast has complex regulation of nutrient metabolism genes and the cluster can be induced, non-induced or repressed depending on the carbon sources available.
WT1-AS: WT1 (Wilms' tumor 1) antisense transcript

0.4 - 3kb, spliced and present in multiple splicing isoforms ((Dallosso 2007)), as well as a protein coding isoform (WIT1) transcribed from a downstream promoter ((Eccles 1994),(Campbell 1994)). Transcribed antisense to WT1 from intron 1 or from the same promoter region (bidirectional) of WT1, corresponding to a differentially methylated regulatory region ((Eccles 1994),(Malik 1995),(Malik 2000)).

Imprinted in humans (but not in mouse), with monoallelic (paternal) expression in normal kidney ((Malik 2000),(Dallosso 2003),(Dallosso 2007)).
Co-regulation with WT1 during mouse kidney development, and co-expression in mouse and human tissues, including fetal spleen, fetal kidney, and normal kidney ((Dallosso 2007)).
Abnormal splicing of WT1-AS has been reported in acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) samples ((Dallosso 2007)).
WT1-AS transcripts are exported to the cytoplasm and form heteroduplexes with WT1 mRNA, with a proposed regulatory role in WT1 expression via RNA:RNA interactions ((Dallosso 2007)).

WT1 has a positionally conserved antisense/bidirectional transcripts in mouse and humans, although WT1-AS RNAs do not show extensive sequence conservation between these species, except at their 5' ends, which may extend into WT1 exon 1 ((Dallosso 2007)).

Originally described as a ~6-kb transcript that initiates in the intergenic region between the alpha and beta myosin heavy chain (MHC) genes, ~2 kb downstream of the beta-MHC gene and transcribed across the entire gene in the antisense orientation ((Haddad 2003)).
Natural antisense transcripts in the MHC cluster have been described forming three major products in rats, antisense to MHC IIa, IIx, and IIb genes. These antisense RNAs are named aII, xII, and bII NATs, respectively ((Pandorf 2006)). The aII NAT begins in the IIa-IIx intergenic region in close proximity to the IIx promoter, extends across the 27-kb IIa MHC gene, and continues to the IIa MHC gene promoter ((Pandorf 2006)).

Expressed in cardiac muscle development ((Haddad 2007)). Increasingly expressed following birth or in response to increases in T3 (3,5,3'-triiodothyronine) thyroid hormone.
Expression is inversely correlated with beta-MHC levels: for example, expression of the antisense beta MHC RNA under altered thyroid state and in diabetes directly correlates with that of the alpha MHC mRNA, but negatively correlates with beta mRNA expression ((Haddad 2003)).
Negative correlation has also been observed between the beta MHC mRNA expression and the antisense beta-RNA in response to aortic constriction-induced pressure overload, in which the beta-MHC gene is up-regulated while the alpha-MHC gene is down-regulated ((Haddad 2006)).
Expression of MHC "aII" antisense is also up-regulated in muscles after spinal cord isolation (SI) in rats, and was negatively correlated with MHC IIa expression and positively correlated with MHC IIx gene expression ((Pandorf 2006)).

Proposed to negatively regulate beta-MHC expression to coordinate the cardiac transition marked by the switch from beta- to alpha-MHC, during early neonatal development, and in adult heart in response to diabetes and to hypothyroid state ((Luther 1998)) ((Haddad 2007)).

Comparative analyses of the MHC intergenic DNA sequence across five mammalian species (human, rat, mouse, hamster, and rabbit) indicates a conserved region that is proposed to be a common regulatory region for the alpha and antisense beta promoter ((Haddad 2003)).
TEA: T early alpha

TEA transcripts originate from the TEA promoter at the 5' of the array of joining (J) gene segments of the T-cell receptor alpha chain (TCRA) ((de Villartay 1987)). Another noncoding transcript has been identified coming from a promoter within the J array (J-alpha 49).
TEA transcription extends up to ~71kb, covering the length of the J array and terminating in the C alpha region ((de Villartay 1987)).
Full length of actual spliced TEA transcript reported as ~2kb ((de Villartay 1987), (Shimizu 1993)). ~4.5 and 8kb transcripts have also been reported. Transcripts generally include TEA sequence spliced to C alpha and sometimes include J segments ((Villey 1997)).

Expressed during thymocyte development at a time recombination is occurring ((Abarrategui 2006), (Abarrategui 2007)). Expression is highest in fetal thymocytes and is absent in mature adult T cells ((de Villartay 1987), (Shimizu 1993)).
TEA transcripts have been identified in the nucleus ((Abarrategui 2007)).

TEA transcription regulates V alpha-to-J alpha recombination and is necessary to generate the full complement of recombined segments ((Abarrategui 2006), (Abarrategui 2007)).
Transcription has both activating and repressive effects on the promoters of different J segments. Segments only a small distance downstream from the TEA promoter are activated while segments more distal are repressed, with alterations in histone modifications and chromatin accessibility ((Abarrategui 2006), (Abarrategui 2007)).
These effects target initial recombination events to the active proximal J segments. In the absence of TEA ncRNA transcription recombination occurs in more distal J segments which are normally repressed ((Abarrategui 2006), (Abarrategui 2007)).
Repressive effects of the TEA ncRNA suggested to be due to transcriptional interference. Unknown if TEA ncRNA also has a function itself, ie: recruitment of chromatin modification complexes ((Abarrategui 2006), (Abarrategui 2007)).
Humans and mouse ((de Villartay 1987), (Shimizu 1993)).

V(D)J recombination acts to assemble the variable regions of T cell receptors from germline variable (V), diversity (D) and joining (J) gene segments.
RNA accessions from (de Villartay 1987) and (Shimizu 1993) some are spliced some are not. Human 147: GenBank: M18204.1 Human 147A1: GenBank: M18206.1 Human 147A19: GenBank: M18205.1
Mouse T early alpha (TEA) region: GenBank: D13547.1
Transcript not characterised, RNA fragment maps to repeat rich intergenic region.
Specifically expressed in melanoma cell lines ((Li 2009)).

Fragment from PSF inhibiting RNA was found to bind hPSF, could release it from GAGE6 proto-oncogene regulatory DNA in-vitro and in-vivo ((Li 2009)).
Expression caused increased colony formation in culture and a modest increase in tumour formation in mice ((Li 2009)).
Suggests PSF inhibiting RNA has oncogenic activity by repressing the hPSF tumour suppressor ((Li 2009)).
Only studied in human cells.
Referred to as "unidentified RNA fragment/gene" in Li et al paper.

AK023948 is embedded in the TG-SLA (thyroglobulin and Src-like adaptor) locus on chromosome 8q24, a susceptibility locus for papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC). An unspliced cDNA, AK023948 is located in an intron of both the TG (sense orientation) and SLA (antisense) genes.
A 12 Kb haplotype containing 8 SNP markers for PTC is harboured in the TG-SLA locus, which also includes two additional putative noncoding RNA genes.
AK023948 (cDNA FLJ13886 fis, clone THYRO1001559) was cloned from thyroid gland and is 2,807b long ((Ota 2004)). The transcript is significantly down-regulated in most PTC tumors, thus representing a candidate susceptibility gene for PTC.
FOXCUT is located upstream of the FOXC1 gene
Expression of FOXCUT has been shown to be upregulated in Oral Squamous Cell Cercinoma (OSCC) patients and OSCC cell lines, and the expression is positiviely correlated with FOXC1 (Kong 2014).

Knockdown of FOXCUT decreases the expression of FOXC1, but knockdown of FOXC1 does not affect the expression of FOXCUT (Kong 2014). The results of knockdown of either FOXC1 or FOXCUT decreases the cell proliferation and the cell migration in OSCC cell lines (Kong 2014). Lower levels of FOXC1, as a result of FOXCUT or FOXC1 siRNA results in decreased expression of MMP1, MMP2, MMP7, MMP9 and VEGFA (Kong 2014).

Bidirectional with Cbln1, two-five exons. LincRNA ((Guttman 2010)).
Alternative splicing and multiple transcriptional start sites generate a number of isoforms.
Some isoforms contain repeat elements.

Expressed in mouse embryonic stem cells (ESCs) ((Guttman 2010)).
Expressed in cerebellum.

Involved in maintaining pluripotency in ESCs ((Guttman 2011)).
Knockdown in mECSs lead to down-regulation of Nanog, Oct4, Sox2, Klf4 and Zfp42 expression ((Guttman 2011)).
Sirt1 AS lncRNA is on the opposite strand on the 3'UTR of Sirt1

Sirt1 AS lncRNA is expressed in multiple tissues and compared to heart, spleen had the highest expression (Wang 2014). Expression in heart, brain, kidney and white adipose tissue is similar. The expression of Sirt1 AS lncRNA decreases with differentiation of C2C12 (Wang 2014).
Overexpression of Sirt1 AS lncRNA inhibited the downregulation of Sirt1 by miR-34a (Wang 2014).

Cytoplasmic long noncoding RNA found most abundant in vascular smooth muscle cells and endothelial cells (Bell 2014) RNA-seq alignment, 5' RACE, and RT-PCR with oligo-dT and strand-specific primers established that SENCR comprises 3 exons and is transcribed in the antisense orientation from within the first intron of Friend leukemia virus integration 1 (FLI1 gene) (Bell 2014) . However, there is no overlap between SENCR and FLI1 exonic sequences,indicating that SENCR is not a natural antisense transcript (Bell 2014) .

SENCR gene is transcribed and expressed as 2 splice variants (SENCR_V1 and SENCR_V2) (Bell 2014) . Quantitative RT-PCR of SENCR_V1 and SENCR_V2 in a panel of human tissues and cell lines , shows that SENCR_V1 to be more broadly expressed than SENCR_V2 (Bell 2014) . SENCR show co expression with FLI1 gene (see above), suggesting that these transcripts may be under the same transcriptional control (Bell 2014) . Knockdown of SENCR exerts little effect on FLT1 mRNA (Bell 2014) .

Base on RNASeq experiment, knockdown of SENCR in human coronary artery smooth muscle cell (HCASMC) results in decreased expression of Mycardin and numerous smooth muscle contractile genes and an upregulation of promigratory genes are increased. (Bell 2014).
Western blot and RT-PCR assay confirms down regulation of genes involved in smooth muscle contraction - CNN1, ACTA2, TAGLN1, LMOD , upon SENCR knockdown in HCASMC (Bell 2014)
RT-PCR assay of HCASMC and HUVEC cell line shows upregulation of promigatory genes MDK and PTN upon SENCR knockdown (Bell 2014)
Boyden chamber assay and scratch wound assay demonstrated hyper-motile HCASMC with SENCR knockdown (Bell 2014)
Collectively, these data show that reduced SENCR expression compromised the SMC contractile phenotype and promoted a promigratory gene signature. (Bell 2014)
No orthologous SENCR transcripts have yet been found outside human/chimp lineages.

Prominent HUVEC-associated H3K4me3 mark near exon 1 of SENCR. (Bell 2014) . Luciferase assays showed little to no detectable SENCR promoter activity in HUVEC unless sequences encompassing the 5? FLI1 promoter region were included (Bell 2014)
HOTTIP - HOXA transcript at the distal tip

Gene located at 5â€™ end of HoxA cluster, bidirectional transcript with HOXA13 ((Sasaki 2007)).
~3.8kb, transcript in human, spliced and polyadenylated ((Wang 2011)).
~2.3kb transcript in mouse, different splice isoforms, currently known transcripts initiate downstream from the syntenic site in human.

Shows collinear regulation of expression like HOX protein coding genes ((Sasaki 2007)).
Has bivalent chromatin marks (both H3 K4me3 and H3 K27me3) whether expression off or on, but only expressed in more distal cells ((Wang 2011)).
Has a similar expression profile to HOXA13, expressed in colon, prostate, placenta and uterus, as well as hand, foreskin and foot fibroblasts ((Sasaki 2007), (Sasaki 2007), (Wang 2011)). Mouse E13.5 in-situs gave similar results ((Wang 2011)).
Nuclear localised, generally to a single small nuclear spot ((Wang 2011)).
Lowly expressed, estimated at ~0.3 copies/cell in expressing tissues ((Wang 2011)).

Summary: Controls activation of 5â€™ HOXA genes. Chromosomal lopping bring it into close association with 5â€™ gene loci. HOTTIP binds WDR5 and recruits a MLL chromatin modifiying complex to maintain a domain of active chromatin over the 5â€™ of HOXA cluster ((Wang 2011)).
- HOTTIP controls activation of 5â€™ HOXA genes in mammals and chicken. - Impact on HOXA genes decreases with increased genomic distance from HOTTIP. - Phenotypic impact in chicken forelimb of HOTTIP knockdown was shorter than normal distal bones.
- HOTTIP doesnâ€™t affect chromosomal structure and looping but it was necessary for maintenance of H3 K4me3 chromatin marks over the distally expressed 5â€™ half of the HOXA locus. HOTTIP RNA binds WDR5 a component of MLL/Trithorax complexes recruiting a MLL complex to lay down H3 K4me3 marks. - WDR5 binding mediated by sequence(s) in 5â€™ 1kb of HOTTIP.
HOTTIP appears to act in cis, its function is facilitated by the chromosomal looping that brings it into close proximity with 5â€™ HOXA genes.

Present in human and mouse. Portions of HOXA13as sequence are well conserved throughout mammals ((Wang 2011)).
Appears to be present in chicken although there is little homology ((Wang 2011)).
RNA contains some highly conserved sequences which are predicted to form a conserved structure ((Sasaki 2007)).

Background: Hox genes are found in 4 clusters. Genes in each cluster are expressed in certain tissues along body axes dependent on their position in the cluster. In the HoxA cluster genes near the 5â€™ are expressed in more distal tissues while genes near the 3â€™ are expressed in more proximal tissues.
Expressed genes have active chromatin marks and show close physical association (likely due to chromosomal looping). Inactive genes do not associate and have repressive chromatin marks ((Wang 2011)).
Human clone accession: GU724873 Mouse clone accession: BC046496

VegT is a bifunctional gene with functional RNA and protein products ((Kloc 2005)).
VegT protein is a T box transcription factor ((Zhang 1996)).
VegT RNA localises to the vegetal pole cytoskeleton in Xenopus oocytes ((Zhang 1996), (Kloc 2005)).

VegT RNA is necessary for the structure and integrity of the vegetal pole cytoskeleton ((Kloc 2005)) as well as the proper anchoring and localization of germ plasm islands and yolk platelets to the vegetal pole ((Kloc 2007)).
Degradation of VegT led to the disintegration of the cytokeratin cytoskeleton ((Kloc 2005)).
Suggested to be integrated into the cytoskeleton holding subunits together or promoting subunit assembly ((Kloc 2005)).

LTR retrotransposon. Human endogenous retrovirus.
Integenic.
Size of full length transcript unknown.
Expressed in tumour cell lines but little expression in fibroblasts ((Li 2009)).

Fragment from Mer11C found to bind hPSF protein, can release it from GAGE6 proto-oncogene regulatory DNA in-vitro and in-vivo ((Li 2009)).
Expression caused increased colony formation in culture and a small increase in tumour formation in mice ((Li 2009)).
Suggests Mer11C has oncogenic activity by repressing hPSF tumour suppressor activity ((Li 2009)).
Repeat is human specific
Nespas: neuroendocrine secretory protein (Nesp) antisense.

Northern blot with a probe for Nespas detects a smear and discrete band of 4.4kb and larger ((Wroe 2000)). In addition to an unspliced form, five alternatively spliced forms of up to 1.4 kb in length have also been detected ((Williamson 2002)).
Imprinted (transcribed from the paternal allele). Transcribed from intron 2 of Nesp (Gnas), encompassing exons 2 through 1. The imprinted GNAS locus encodes the alpha-subunit of the stimulatory G protein as well as additional imprinted transcripts including the maternally expressed NESP55 and other paternally expressed transcripts (XLalphas and A/B transcripts).

Tissue-specific expression with signal in heart, in cerebral cortex, adrenal, and spleen, where Nesp is also expressed. Nesp and Nespas transcripts show expression from opposite parental alleles in most (but not all) tissues ((Li 2000)), and Nespas may be abundant in some tissues where Nesp is not detected ((Williamson 2002)). Furthermore, the Nesp transcripts can also remain imprinted in tissues that lack Nespas.

A 4.2 kb microdeletion in humans that ablates two GNAS antisense exons is associated with pseudohypoparathyroidism type Ib. When maternally transmitted, this mutation causes loss of maternal GNAS imprints, partial gain of NESP55 methylation, and resistance to parathyroid hormone (PTH) in affected and obligate carrier individuals. Paternal transmission leads to epigenetic alterations in cis, including a partial loss of NESP55 methylation and a partial gain of A/B methylation. ((Chillambhi 2010))
Nespas RNA was identified as binding to the repressive PRC2 chromatin modification complex in mouse embryonic stem cells, suggesting that like noncoding RNAs from other imprinted region, nespas could act to regulate the imprinting cluster it is transcribed from ((Zhao 2010)).
N/A
**Annotation in progress**
RN7SK: RNA, 7SK small nuclear

~330 nt in vertebrates*. Transcribed by RNAP III, GC-rich sequence forming conserved secondary structures (especially 3' and 5' stem-loop motifs).
7SK RNA is capped at its 5' end by BCDIN3, a specific methylase methylphosphate capping enzyme (MePCE) ((Jeronimo 2007)).
RNAP II was recently found to bind near 7SK promoter, as well as many other known Pol III genes, suggesting that RNAP II may also play a role in regulating their transcription ((Raha 2010)).
*In invertebrates, 7SK homologs may have different sizes (such as >400 nt and ~130 nt in drosophilids and nematodes, respectively). ((Gruber 2008)) ((Marz 2009))

Nuclear, highly abundant (one of the most abundant small RNAs in vertebrate cells), first isolated from HeLa nuclear extracts, but ubiquitously expressed.
RNA sequencing from 11 humans tissues confirmed ubiquitous high expression of 7SK with expression in some tissues being higher than any mRNA ((Castle 2010)).

Controls RNAP II activity by inhibiting P-TEFb elongation factor, which is a cdk-cyclin kinase that functions as both a general and an HIV-1 Tat-specific transcription factor ((Nguyen 2001)) ((Yang 2001)), with an impact on cell growth and differentiation.
7SK snRNA is a central scaffold that coordinates protein-protein interactions and, by inhibiting P-TEFb kinase-mediated CTD phosphorylation, regulates RNAP II elongation ((Nguyen 2001)). 7SK snRNP (composed of 7SK snRNA, Hexim1, Larp7/Pip7S, and the P-TEFb subunits CycT1 and Cdk9) is not only critical for controlling transcription, but also for regulating alternative splicing coupled to transcription elongation ((Barboric 2009)). It is also essential for vertebrate development ((Barboric 2009)). The 3' end of HIC mRNA has full activity and contains a predicted structure resembling the 3'-terminal hairpin of 7SK that is critical for P-TEFb binding ((Barboric 2009)).
7SK has been found highly enriched in isolated chromatin fractions, which may be related to its role in transcriptional regulation ((Mondal 2010)).
At an early stage of the HIV transcription cycle, elongation is prevented as P-TEFb is recruited to the HIV-1 promoter in a catalytically inactive state bound to the 7SK snRNP and also the Tat trans-activator of transcription protein. The inhibitory 7SK snRNP may be displaced by the nascent TAR HIV RNA that also binds Tat protein, activating P-TEFb kinase and transcriptional elongation ((D'Orso 2010)). Displacement of 7SK may also be performed by cellular RNAs, as indicated by the 3'-untranslated region (~300-nt) of HIC mRNA, which forms complexes with P-TEFb and is necessary and sufficient for stimulation of P-TEFb-dependent transcription of the HIV promoter ((Young 2007)).
7SK RNA also inhibits APOBEC3C deaminase activity and sequesters it to the nucleolus, suggesting broader role for 7SK RNA in regulating key nuclear functions ((He 2007)).

Highly conserved throughout jawed vertebrates (but in lamprey it differs in 32% of its sequence from the mammalian 7SK (GÃ¼rsoy (2000))), and has a few conserved sequence and structure motifs over longer evolutionary distances. Homologs have been identified in deuterostome invertebrates and in two protostome phyla (mollusks and annelids) ((Gruber 2008)). More recently, it has also been detected in arthropods, showing that two highly structured conserved domains (5'- and 3'-stem regions) were present in the bilaterian ancestor ((Gruber 2008)), and even in nematode Caenorhabditis species ((Marz 2009)).

The 7SK family contains a number of pseudogenes and derived repeats.
May be implicated in the transformation-dependent activation of oncogenes SV40 T-antigen and c-myc gene promoters ((Krause 1996)).
Hsr1: Heat shock RNA 1
~600 nt. Likely to be unspliced and does not have a polyA tail ((Shamovsky 2006)).

Constitutively expressed ((Shamovsky 2006)).
Appears to undergo some sort of conformation change upon heat shock ((Shamovsky 2006)).

Required for the heat shock response ((Shamovsky 2006)).
HSR1 and eEF1A (eukaryotic translation elongation factor 1) are required to activate heat shock factor 1 (HSF1) upon heat shock. HSR1 binds to eEF1A upon heat shock, which then forms a complex with HSF1 ((Shamovsky 2006)).
Knockdown/inhibition of HSR1 prevents HSF1 activation and makes cells heat shock sensitive ((Shamovsky 2006)).

604 nuc HSR1 seq couldn't be found in any mammalian genome examined, nor in expressed sequence libraries ((Kim 2009)).
3' of HSR1 shows nucleotide and protein sequence homology to bacterial chloride channel proteins ((Kim 2009)).
Sequence is most similar to chloride channel from bacterial species of order Burkholderiales. Unclear if this is horizontal gene transfer or due to bacterial infection of the studied cells ((Kim 2009)).
Robust experimental results for functionality of HSR1, despite uncertainty regarding its origins.
RN7SL1: RNA, 7SL, cytoplasmic 1

~300 nt, transcribed by RNAPIII.
The eukaryotic small cytoplasmic 7SL is an RNA component of the SRP (signal recognition particle), which associates with the ribosome and targets nascent proteins to the endoplasmic reticulum for secretion or membrane insertion ((Walter 1982)) ((Zwieb 2004)).

Ubiquitously expressed at high levels. Localises to the cytoplasm. An expression profile from 11 human tissues using RNA sequencing showed 7SL was most highly expressed ncRNA and could be an order of magnitude more highly expressed than any mRNA ((Castle 2010)).

7SL RNA is required for structural and functional properties of SRP ((Walter 1982)), being a scaffold component upon which the six proteins of the SRP bind in higher eukaryotes. In mammals SRP consists of the SRP RNA the six proteins named SRP9, SRP14, SRP19, SRP54, SRP68, and SRP72 ((Walter 1983)).
Bacterial SRP has a much reduced complexity, consisting of a small SRP RNA (4.5S RNA) and a homolog of protein SRP54, also called Ffh or P48 ((Bernstein 1993)). In archaea only two SRP proteins, SRP19 and SRP54, are thought to be part of the SRP, although SRP RNA closely resembles the mammalian homolog ((Bhuiyan 2000)).
There is evidence that a highly conserved region of 7SL RNA catalyses the binding of SRP to its receptor SR, and that this RNA stimulates the GTPase activities of the SRP-SR complex ((Zhang 2008)) ((Siu 2006)) ((Peluso 2000)).

May have originated from the bacterial SRP (GTP-regulated ribonucleoprotein that targets secretory or membrane proteins during translation), it is ubiquitously present in eukaryotic cells and several viruses ((Li 1982)). The secondary structure of 7SL RNA is conserved from prokaryotes to distant eukaryotic species ((Labuda 1994)).

7SL is the RNA ancestor of Alu transposon sequences, which emerged ~ 55 million years ago, are present specifically in primates and comprise ~10% of the human genome. Rodent B1 elements, as well as 4.5S and primate BC200 RNAs are also related to the terminal portions of 7SL RNA sequence ((Labuda 1994)) ((Quentin 1994)).
Pldi: Polymorphic derived intron containing ncRNA

~850nuc, alternatively spliced 2 or 3 exon transcript.
Evolution of a lncRNA gene from an intergenic region.
Has an overlapping antisense transcript.

Expressed in postmeiotic cells in the testis.
May regulate the expression levels of other genes in testis.
Knockout showed reduced sperm motility and reduced testis weight.

Gene is specific to certain Mus species. Intergenic region is present in other mammals (rat, human) and other more basal Mus species but no transcripts are expressed showing evolution of this gene in the past 2.5-3.5 million years.
Splice and polyA sites utilised by Pldi were present as crytpic sites in other mouse species, mutations in the 5' regulatory region of Pldi appear to have allowed its expression, which has subsequently been selected for.

Disruption of ASAR6 results in late replication, an under-condensed appearance during mitosis, and structural instability of human chromosome 6. ASAR6 shares many characteristics with Xist, including random mono-allelic expression and asynchronous replication timing. Proposed as a "inactivation/stability center" that controls proper replication, condensation, and stability of chromosome 6 in humans (Thayer (2012)). Cis-acting controler of replication timing. Controls the replication-timing program when ectopically integrated in other chromosomes. (Donley (2013))

Northern suggests a transcript of around 3kb.
Transcript initiation and termination sites not defined, however at least some of transcript is located between Rtl1 and Meg3/Gtl2.
Identified in mouse embyonic stem cells (mESCs)
Binds PRC2 chromatin modifying complex
As the transcript itself is not defined no accurate ucsc browser link is possible.
KRAS Pseudogene 1
Processed pseudogene of KRAS oncogene on 6p12-p11 ((McGrath 1983)).

Probable competing endogenous RNA (ceRNA). KRASP1 is hypothesised to act as a decoy for miRNAs targeting KRAS, similar to how PTENP1 acts a decoy for PTEN ((Poliseno 2010)).
Expression of the KRASP1 3'UTR sequence lead to de-repression of KRAS mRNA levels and increased cellular proliferation ((Poliseno 2010)).
Pseudogene sequence at this locus only present in some primates.
Expression of linc00467 is upregulated after silencing of N-Myc (Atmadibrata 2014).

N-Myc regulates the expression of linc00467 by binding to the Sp1 binding site in the linc00467 promoter which reduces the expression of linc00467 (Atmadibrata 2014). siRNA directed at linc00467 reduces the mRNA expression of RD3 as well as reducing the viability of neuroblastoma cells (Atmadibrata 2014). However, knockdown of linc00467 increases the expression of the tumour supressor gene DKK1 (Atmadibrata 2014). Knockdown of DKK1 ameliorated the reduction in cell viability resulting from linc00467 knockdown (Atmadibrata 2014).

Expression identified upstream and downstream of H19 including through H19 enhancers and imprinting control region (ICR) in cancer cell lines ((Berteaux 2008)).
Suggested to be an antisense transcript covering ~120kb which starts in intron 1 of the (non-imprinted) MRPL23 gene and runs through H19 towards Igf2. A full length clone has not been identified so the presence of splicing is unknown. Transcript hypothesised to cover much of MRPL23 in sense direction as well as the H19 enhancers and ICR plus H19 in the antisense direction ((Berteaux 2008)).

Transcript appears to be nuclear and highly unstable. It is lowly expressed in normal cells with up-regulation in cancer cells due to transcript stabilisation ((Berteaux 2008)).
Antisense transcription throughout locus was also identified in mouse ((Berteaux 2008)).
Imprinted: Maternally expressed ((Berteaux 2008)).
High Expression associated with poor outcome in colorectal cancer ((Deng 2014))

Knockdown lead to a decrease in Igf2 expression. Knockdown had little effect on H19 expression ((Berteaux 2008)) and it is unclear if it affected expression of H19 enhancers or the ICR. KD results in decreased proliferation and impaired cellular migration (PMID: 25058480)
Mouse and human ((Berteaux 2008)).

It is difficult to define the independent transcripts throughout this locus since enhancer and ICR sequences are known to be transcribed, sometimes bi-allelically ((Drewell 2002), (Schoenfelder 2007)).
Question of whether a 120kb unspliced antisense transcript exists in that form, or if there are a mixture of antisense transcripts throughout this loci or both.
Note that at least one protein coding gene has now been identified antisense to H19 ((Onyango 2011)), although its genomic location is only a small segment of the genomic region H19 antisense is hypothesized to cover.

Transcripts accumulate at nearby DMRT1 locus (Teranishi 2001). OE of sense induced abnormalities in embyros of both genders: In females: large ovaries with increased hormone production and proliferation index (recapitulated with antisense transcript) In males: did not induce feminisation bit resulted in high mortality OE of either transcript reduced DMRT1 expressionand substantial brain aberrations

Growth arrest-specific transcript ((Schneider 1988)), multiple splice isoforms ((Coccia 1992)) of ~250, ~450, ~600nuc and longer ((Mourtada-Maarabouni 2008)), encodes 9 (10 in humans) snoRNAs in its introns ((Smith 1998)).

Widely expressed in adult tissues and over embryonic development ((Coccia 1992)).
Transcript undergoes post-transcriptional regulation, highly unstable but stabilised by growth arrest, serum starvation and inhibition of protein synthesis ((Coccia 1992), (Smith 1998), (Kino 2010)). Associates with ribosomes in the cytoplasm ((Smith 1998)).
Localises to both the nucleus and the cytoplasm ((Kino 2010)).
Down-regulated in breast cancer ((Mourtada-Maarabouni 2008)).
Transcript was classified as unstable with a half-life >4 hr in human Hela cells ((Tani 2012)). Similar half-lives were identified in human B cells and mouse 3T3 fibroblasts ((Friedel 2009), (Clark 2012)).

Necessary and sufficient for growth arrest in human peripheral blood T-cells. Functions by controlling apoptosis and the cell cycle in lymphocytes ((Mourtada-Maarabouni 2008)).
In some cell lines certain Gas5 isoforms act to sensitise the cells to apoptosis but can't induce apoptosis on their own. In other cells types Gas5 can both induce apoptosis and growth arrest and sensitise the cells to further apoptosis ((Mourtada-Maarabouni 2008)).
Gas5 can be regulated by mTOR, with mTOR (which promotes cellular proliferation) acting to inhibit the function of Gas5 ((Mourtada-Maarabouni 2010)).
Gas5 carries out its function by binding the DNA binding domain of the glucocorticoid receptor (GR) with a sequence that mimmics the glucocorticoid response element (GRE). Gas5 is translocated into the nucleus bound to the GR where it prevents GR from binding GREs and regulating transcription of target genes including apoptosis inhibitors ((Kino 2010)).
Gas5 also appears to repress the action of many steroid hormone receptors, showing some similarities to another lncRNA SRA ((Kino 2010)).
Gas5 is a snoRNA host and a functional RNA. Function does not require putative but nonconserved ORF, or the intronic snoRNAs ((Mourtada-Maarabouni 2008), (Mourtada-Maarabouni 2008), (Kino 2010)).

Gas5 in mouse and human do not show high sequence identity ((Tanaka-Fujita 2007)) although the GRE mimmic region is conserved ((Kino 2010)).
Most of the snoRNAs found in human Gas5 also cluster in the same order in a putatively noncoding RNA host gene in chicken. 42% homology was found between human Gas5 and the chicken gene which was named Gas5-like ((Shao 2009)).

Mourtada-Maarabouni., et al (2010) provide an interesting hypothesis for how Gas5 levels and therefore function is regulated. - Gas5 is stabilised by inhibition of protein synthesis suggesting it may normally be a target for nonsense mediated decay (NMD). mTOR regulates 5' TOP genes (which includes Gas5) promoting translation, whereas mTOR inhibition inhibits translation. This could allow mTOR to inhibit Gas5 by promoting Gas5 NMD.
This suggests that since Gas5 is known to be functional at the RNA level, any Gas5 translation may be a regulatory to control Gas5 levels and not necessarily to produce a functional protein.
COOLAIR: cold induced long antisense intragenic RNA ((Swiezewski 2009)).

Multiple spliced, polyadenylated isoforms. Short version ~400bp, long version ~750 bp ((Swiezewski 2009)).
Transcription initiates just 3' of the FLC polyA site. Some isoforms terminate just beyond the start of the FLC gene (antisense transcription covers the entire FLC gene) ((Swiezewski 2009)).

Antisense transcription over much of FLC locus. Generally shows a positive correlation with FLC transcripts, except upon cold treatment (vernalization) ((Swiezewski 2009)).
Antisense transcripts show a transient accumulation upon cold treatment with a peak after 10-14 days ((Swiezewski 2009), (Heo 2010)), before declining with further prolonged cold or when plants returned to warmth. Transcription of FLC decreases during cold treatment ((Swiezewski 2009)).

COOLAIR suggested to function in early cold induced silencing of FLC transcription ((Swiezewski 2009)).
COOLAIR promoter could silence some reporter genes. Suggests COOLAIR may function through transcriptional interference, although a function for the transcripts has not been tested ((Swiezewski 2009)).

COOLAIR short accession: GQ342259.1 COOLAIR long accession: GQ352646.1
COOLAIR is distinct from COLDAIR, which has been functionally characterized.

Spliced, two exon 661nt transcript.
Transcribed bidirectionally with CYP4A22-AS1.
LincRNA catalogue from deep RNA sequencing suggests variation in transcript length and also potential alternative splicing ((Cabili 2011)).
Expressed downstream of TAL1 and PDZK1IP1 on the opposite strand.
In-vitro translation showed no sign of protein product.
Expressed in Jurkat cells, but not in MCF7 cells (unlike CYP4A22-AS1).
PDZK1IP1-AS1 expression appears to stimulate CMPK1 gene expression (in Jurkat cells). A gene located over 150 kb 3â€™ of PDZK1IP1-AS1 on the same strand.

Longest identified isoform is 738bp with 4 exons. Deep sequencing has also identified two shorter isoforms ((Cabili 2011)).
Some exons overlap multiple SINEs
Transcript isoform(s) expressed in testis ((Cabili 2011)) and also reported in fetal brain ((Vandeweyer 2012)).

Transcript disrupted by a balanced translocation, 46,XY,t(2;6)(p15;p22.3), in a patient with West Syndrome (a form of infant epilepsy). Lack of effect on other nearby genes or presence of mutations in known West Syndrome disease genes leads to possible implication of BX118339 in the clinical phenotype ((Vandeweyer 2012)).
EBER: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)-encoded small RNA

Encoded by Epstein-Barr virus. EBER genes are separated by 161 base pairs ((Rosa 1981), (Lerner 1981)).
EBER1: 167nt, EBER2: 172nt. Show significant sequence similarity with each other. Heterogeneity resides at the 3' termini ((Rosa 1981), (Lerner 1981)). Highly structured, resulting in the formation of several stable stem-loops ((Glickman 1988)).
Transcribed by RNA polymerase III. Possess 5' pppA termini. Non-polyadenylated ((Rosa 1981), (Lerner 1981)).

Highly expressed during EBV latency in infection of many cell types and all associated human malignancies (EBERs are the most abundantly expressed RNAs during latency).
Nuclear localisation.

Bind to La autoantigen protein ((Rosa 1981), (Lerner 1981)) and PKR in vitro, and have been suggested to block PKR activity and confer resistance to Fas-mediated apoptosis of host cells ((Clarke 1991), (Sharp 1993), (Nanbo 2005)), although inhibition of PKR has not been observed in vivo ((Ruf 2005)).
EBER-1 interacts with RPL22 (ribosomal protein L22), which is known to interact with components of different viruses ((Dobbelstein 1995), (Fok 2006)). EBER-1 mediates stable relocalisation of L22 from nucleoli to nucleoplasm in EBV-infected cells, which is critical for EBER-dependent functions ((Houmani 2009)). Burkitt's lymphoma (BL) cells expressing mutated EBER-1 RNAs incapable of binding L22 have reduced capacity to enhance BL cell growth ((Houmani 2009)).
Role in the growth and maintenance of BL cell malignant phenotype ((Shimizu 1994), (Ruf 2000)). Also contribute to the growth of other B-cell lymphoma-, gastric carcinoma-, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma-derived cell lines ((Iwakiri 2003), (Iwakiri 2004), (Yamamoto 2000)).
Inhibit alpha interferon-induced apoptosis in latently infected B-cell lines. EBER RNAs induce the expression of interleukin (IL)-10 in BL cells ((Kitagawa 2000)), as well as insulin-like growth factor (IGF)-1 in gastric carcinoma and nasopharyngeal carcinoma cells, and IL-9 in T cells, which acts as an autocrine growth factor.
EBERs can be secreted from EBV-infected cells and can be detected in the sera of infected patients. RNAs are recognized by toll-like receptor (TLR)3, leading to induction of type-I IFNs and inflammatory cytokines ((Iwakiri 2009)), suggesting that activation of TLR3 signaling could lead to the pathogenesis of active EBV infectious diseases ((Iwakiri 2009), (Iwakiri 2010)).
Functionality of EBER1 and 2 does not appear to be redundant, as transforming capacity of EBER2-deleted virus is comparable to that of EBV lacking both EBERs, but that of EBER-1-deleted virus is as high as wild-type EBV, indicating that EBER1 does not play a critical role in EBV-induced B-cell growth transformation. ((Wu 2007))
The primary sequences of EBERs are strongly conserved among EBV strains ((Arrand 1989)).
Many similarities with adenovirus VAI and VAII RNAs ((Rosa 1981)), as well as other virus-encoded ncRNAs (eg. (Howe 1988)).
Progesterone receptor promoter antisense transcripts

Found several antisense transcripts which initiate in the progesterone receptor (PR) promoter region.
AT1 and AT3 were unspliced.
AT2-T47D and AT2-MCF7 were spliced with seven exons and transcribed over a 70kb region. AT2 isoforms initiated between the PR A and B start sites, had different (cell line specific) start sites but were otherwise identical.
AT2-T47D ~1.35kb. AT2-MCF7 ~1.5kb.

Expression identified in human breast cancer cell lines (MCF7 and T47D).
AT2 isoforms were the most highly expressed antisense transcripts.
AT2 isoforms could be detected in the nucleus.

All function characterisation was on the AT2 isoforms.
PR antisense transcripts act as a scaffold for other RNAs and proteins to bind, allowing them to regulate transcription of the progesterone receptor.
Different small RNAs targeted at PR antisense transcripts can activate or repress PR transcription. A PR antisense transcript was necessary for activating PR transcription via a small RNA.
PR antisense transcripts could associate with small RNAs, Argonaute proteins and hnRNP-k to bring about regulation of the PR protein coding gene.
Accessions: AT-1: FJ515871 AT-2-MCF7: FJ515872 AT-2-T47D: FJ515873

Intergenic, four-six exon transcript. LincRNA ((Guttman 2010)).
Alternative splicing and two transcriptional initiation sites ((Guttman 2010)).
Contains multiple repeat sequences.

Expressed in mouse embryonic stem cells (ESCs) ((Guttman 2010)).
RNA found to be highly unstable with a half-life <2 hr in N2A (neuroblastoma) cells ((Clark 2012)).

Involved in maintaining pluripotency in ESCs ((Guttman 2011)).
Knockdown in mECSs lead to down-regulation of Nanog, Oct4, Sox2, Klf4 and Zfp42 expression ((Guttman 2011)).
Found to interact with a number of chromatin binding proteins/complexes in mESCs including PRC1, PRC2 and JARID1C ((Guttman 2011)).

Sense intronic to the Phkb gene, close by to a putative recombination hotspot in mouse.
2.4kb unspliced transcript, has a TATA box and polyA signal so appears to be an independent polymerase II transcript transcribed from an intron.
Transcriptomes of Mrhl knockdown in mouse spermatogonia cell lines exhibited perturbation of cell adhesion, signalling and transcription. "host" gene Phkb was not affected. weighted gene coexpression network analysis (WGCNA) identified activation of Wnt signaling (confirmed by Western and TOP/FLASH/FOR FLASH) (Arun 2012). It participates in nuclear retention of p68, which, once relesed from Mrhl, is required for b-catenin nuclear translocation (Arun 2012).
Expressed in mouse testis, liver, kidney and spleen (by northern).
Some small blocks of sequence is conserved throughout mammals.

Transcription start and termination sites were not precisely mapped, but since primer extension did give a small region for initiation and a polyA signal was found near the 3' end the coordinates and sequence provided are close to correct.
878 bp long.
Expressed in dorsal root ganglion, but not in Schwann cells (Yu (2013)).
Down-regulation of this lncRNA promoted neurite outgrowth of dorsal root ganglion neurons (Yu (2013)).Â

~3.8 kb. Antisense to Dlx6 genes in the Dlx5/6 cluster. Evf1 and 2 are isoforms with alternative promoters expressed from ultraconserved enhancers. Different Evf-1 and Evf-2 transcripts result from alternative transcription initiation, alternative splicing of exon 3, and alternative polyadenylation. Therefore, Evf-1 and Evf-2 cDNA sequences have unique 5' and 3' ends, and share a 2561bp region of identity ((Feng 2006), (Kohtz 2004)).
A large (7.5-kb) non-polyadenylated form recognized by both Evf-1 and Evf-2 Northern blot probes is present in the total RNA fraction and absent from the poly(A) containing fraction. The Evf-2-specific probe also identifies a smaller (500-bp) transcript ((Feng 2006)).

Nuclear localisation ((Feng 2006), (Sone 2007)).
Similar expression pattern to Dlx6 and Dlx5 mRNAs. Developmentally regulated, expressed in the ventral forebrain. Detected in immature neurons as they exit the ventricular zone ((Feng 2006)).
Ectopic expression of Sonic hedgehog (Shh) induces the expression of Evf-2, Evf-1, Dlx-2, Dlx-5, and Dlx-6 in the dorsal telencephalon in vivo (mouse embryos) ((Feng 2006)).
Up-regulated in vitro during differentiation of neuronal progenitors to GABAergic neurons and during mouse embryonic stem cells differentiation ((Dinger 2008)) ((Mercer 2010)). Also found co-expressed in the first and second branchial arches of E10.5 mouse embryos ((Jeong 2008)).
Brain expression of Evf2 and Evf1 is dependent on Dlx1/2 function. Expression of Evf2 and Evf1 is also greatly reduced in Dlx5/6, and Dlx5 or Dlx6, knock-out mutants, indicating that they may be their direct or indirect regulatory targets ((Kohtz 2004), (Jeong 2008)). Evf1 and Evf2 were more down-regulated in Dlx5-/- than in Dlx6-/- mutants ((Jeong 2008)).

Evf-2 ncRNA and Dlx-2 proten display an intranuclear colocalization ((Feng 2006)).
The ultraconserved region* of Evf-2 binds and co-operates with Dlx-2 in vivo to increase the transcriptional activity of the Dlx-5/6 enhancer in a target and homeodomain-specific manner ((Feng 2006)). *The Evf-2 5' region is both necessary and sufficient for activity.
Evf2 recruitment of DLX2 and MECP2 controls the expression of targets Dlx5, Dlx6 and Gad1 through trans and cis-acting mechanisms in developing ventral forebrain. Evf2 function is also required for proper gene regulation and formation of hippocampal GABA-dependent neuronal circuitry in mouse adult brain ((Bond 2009)).
MECP2 transcriptional repression ofÂ Evf2Â and Dlx5, but not Dlx6, occurs through antagonism of DLX1/2 in E13.5 MGE (Kohtz 2014).
Evf2 prevents site-specific CpG DNA methylation of Dlx5/6ei in trans, without altering Dlx5/6 expression (Kohtz 2014).
Evf2 inhibits enhancer DNA methylation, effectively modulating competition between the DLX1/2 activator and MECP2 repressor (Kohtz 2014).

Evf-2 is transcribed from (and contains in its first exon) a vertebrate ultraconserved element. Analysis of transcripts by isolation from a cDNA library (rat), RTâ€“PCR (zebrafish and chicken), or expressed sequence tag (EST) databases (human and mouse) showed that transcription of the ultraconserved element associated with Evf-2 (enhancer ei) is conserved in vertebrates ((Feng 2006)).
Evf-1 and Evf-2 exhibit a high degree (86%â€“93%) of conservation between rat and mouse sequences in their 5' and 3' regions, and a compilation of transcripts found in human, rat, mouse, zebrafish, and chicken shows that only transcription from exon 2 is conserved ((Feng 2006)).

Evf-2 is proposed to belong to a class of transcription regulating, ultraconserved ncRNAs (trucRNAs), and may be part of a broader Dlx gene/antisense RNA regulatory network ((Feng 2006), (Dinger 2008)).
Khps1a : Sphk1a antisense transcript

1290 nt*; originates from the CpG island and overlaps a "tissue-dependent differentially methylated region" (T-DMR) of Sphk1. Single-exon, 5'-capped and 3'-polyadenylated, it spans the region -2095 to -3384 in relation to the commonly used +1 translation start site for Sphk1 subtypes, which covers the entire region of the T-DMR (-3233 to -3023) and the alternative first exons of both Sphk1a and -c ((Imamura 2004)).
*Northern blot with probes for Khps1 also indicates the presence of transcripts with different sizes (600-20,000nt).

Expression of Khps1 is detected in many tissues, with high levels in the kidney and only weakly expressed in the liver and brain. Expression was detected in the cytoplasm of primary cell culture from rat fetuses, as well as nuclei in some cells, indicating that Khps1 is exported to the cytoplasm ((Imamura 2004)).
Similar to Sphk1, the expression of Khps1 is also detected from only one allele (demonstrating that it is also imprinted), and Khps1 and Sphk1 show mutually exclusive expression in individual cells ((Imamura 2004)).
Identified as a PROMPT (promoter upstream transcript) which are degraded by the exosome and generally highly unstable ((Preker 2008)).

Regulates DNA methylation in the T-DMR of Sphk1 promoter ((Imamura 2004); (Preker 2008)). In vitro over-expression of two fragments of Khps1 in NRK cells cause demethylation of CG sites of the T-DMR, but which is accompanied of DNA methylation at three CC(A/T)GG sites ((Imamura 2004)).

Rat Khps1a exhibits 88.7% and 56.2% nucleotide sequence identity with corresponding DNA sequences in the genome databases at NCBI for human and mouse (Accession Nos. NT_1010641 and NT_039521), respectively ((Imamura 2004)).
ESTs overlapping Sphk1 T-DMR CpG island in mouse, homologous to the CpG island of rat Sphk1, are described (mouse EST AA796730 shows 87% similarity with the CpG island of rat Sphk1). Human transcripts in the region were also detected by RT-PCR in HEK293 and HeLa cells ((Imamura 2004)).

There are possible open reading frames in Khps1a, in which the maximal size is 306 bp, but no recognizable amino acid motifs or domains in the possible proteins were found, and three possible start codons in the rat Khps1a aligned with different codons in the corresponding human genomic DNA sequences ((Imamura 2004)).

Short interspersed element (SINE) repeat present in more than 10^5 copies in the mouse genome ((Kramerov 1979))
Repeat is ~180nuc long ((Krayev 1982)) but expressed B2 RNAs vary from ~0.2-0.6kb ((Kramerov 1982),(Fornace 1986)).
The 5' of B2 SINE is derived from a tRNA ((Lawrence 1985), (Daniels 1985)) while the 3' contains an A rich sequence ((Krayev 1982)).
Transcribed by RNA polymerase III ((Krayev 1982), (Singh 1985)).

Expression highly induced upon viral infection ((Singh 1985)), heat shock ((Fornace 1986)) and differentially regulated during development ((Bachvarova 1988)).
Also shows higher expression in some tumour cells ((Kramerov 1982)).
Found in the nucleus ((Espinoza 2004)) and the cytoplasm ((Kramerov 1982)).

B2 SINE RNA is a specific inhibitor of RNA polymerase II ((Allen 2004)).
During heat shock B2 RNA associated with RNA polymerase II and repressed its action. Nb: Only saw association of B2 RNA with RNA polymerase II after heat shock. ((Allen 2004)).
Represses transcription by stably binding an RNA docking site on the core polymerase II complex and blocking activity of the RNA polymerase preinitiation complex ((Espinoza 2004)). To achieve this B2 RNA disrupts polymerase DNA binding at the promoter, preventing the formation of an active closed complex around the DNA ((Yakovchuk 2009)).
51 nucleotide sequence from 3' half is sufficient for binding to and repressing RNA polymerase II ((Espinoza 2007)).
Rodents: mouse, rat, chinese hamster ((Krayev 1982))

Known that upon heat shock RNA polymerase II is transiently repressed.
In humans Alu repeat RNAs appear to play the role B2 RNA does in rodents upon heat shock. Alu and B2 elements have different origins but show convergent evolution functionally.
B2 sequence provided is 177nt sequence specified by Espinoza et al. 2004 as mouse B2 RNA gene (region 121488-121665 of Mus musculus chromosome 18, clone RP23-6p18, GenBank accession number AC020972).
highly expressed in ovary, cervix, testis, and thyroid (Halley 2014)

transient reduction of APOA1-AS expression is sufficient for initiating the transcriptional upregulation of APOA1,APOC3 &4but not 5 or QSK genes, indicating a specific genic region of influence. ChIP analysis of KD cells showed increased H4K4me, decreased H3K27me3, LSD1 and Suz12- and unchanged H3K9me3 of affected genes (Halley 2014)
Neural-specific expression (Li (2012)).
Participates in locomotor activity and climbing ability by positively regulating its neighboring gene CASK (Ca(2+)/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase) (Li (2012)).

Antisense transcript to Peg11/Rtl1. Peg11 is a retrotransposon-like protein coding gene ((Charlier 2001), (Byrne 2010)).
Reciprocal imprinting: antiPeg11 maternally expressed whereas Rtl1/Peg11 is paternally expressed. ((Charlier 2001), (Seitz 2003), (Hagan 2009)).
antiPeg11 contains 5 maternally expressed miRNAs (4 found in mammals, 1 specific to rodents, 1 specific to non-rodents) ((Seitz 2003), (Davis 2005)).
In humans these are mir-431, mir-433, mir-127, mir-432 and mir-136.

Peg11 is expressed in a number of tissues in mouse, while antiPeg11 expression is restricted mostly to embryos and adult brain. In brain it was expressed at a higher level than Peg11 ((Hagan 2009)).
antiPeg11 miRNAs have a similar expression profile to the full length transcript ((Davis 2005)).
High expression of antiRtl1 in sheep skeletal muscle ((Charlier 2001)).
Full length, unspliced, unprocessed, transcript was around ~5kb, with smaller (likely processed) species also present ((Hagan 2009)).

antiPeg11 binds the PRC2 chromatin modification complex ((Zhao 2010)).
antiPeg11 miRNAs target Rtl1 ((Davis 2005)).

Eutherian mammals ((Davis 2005), (Edwards 2008)).
Suggested that anti-rtl1 has evolved as part of the parental conflict hypothesis where the maternally expressed antisense gene inhibits the paternally expressed (fetal growth promoting) gene ((Davis 2005)).

No full length antiPeg11 cDNAs have been cloned but there is a partial clone from mouse EU434921.1 which is given in the UCSC browser link below. This sequence "Begins at the end of miR-431 precursor and ends at the beginning of miR-127 precursor" ((Hagan 2009)).
Like in mouse the exact nature of the transcript in other mammals is not known, human browser link below is to sequence defined by the microRNAs contained within antiPeg11, others are to Peg11.

Originate from the intergenic spacers (IGS) that separate rRNA genes ((Rungger 1979), (Morgan 1983)).
Like rRNA genes, spacers also contain polymerase I promoters and the ~2kb from the spacer promoter to the rRNA gene promoter is transcribed ((Kuhn 1987)). These long lncRNAs must be processed to create the a shorter ~150-300 nt RNA sequence(s), pRNAs, from just upstream of the rRNA promoter that bind TIP5 (the large subunit of the chromatin remodeling complex NoRC) ((Mayer 2006)).
In human cells transcription runs from ~1kb upstream of the rRNA transcriptional start site to over 200bp into the gene ((Shiao 2009)).

Nuclear localised ((Mayer 2006)).
Expression of IGS sequences is regulated by the cell cycle with expression up-regulated in mid-S phase. There are many rRNA repeats and only a subset these express IGS sequences ((Santoro 2009)).
Expression in human lung cancer cell lines was generally higher than in a non-transformed lung cell line, with a negative correlation between the intergenic nc-rRNA and the 45s rRNA precursor transcript ((Shiao 2009)). Investigation of intergenic nc-rRNA SNPs also identified one that correlated with lower expression of the intergenic nc-rRNA ((Shiao 2009)).

Required for the nucleolar localization of NoRC and epigenetic control of the rDNA locus ((Mayer 2006)).
Details: Conserved stem-loop structure binds to the TIP5 protein in the chromatin remodeling complex NoRC ((Mayer 2006), (Mayer 2008)). This binding is controlled by the acetylation state of TIP5, with IGS RNA binding the de-acetylated version TIP5 ((Zhou 2009)). Required for nucleolar localization of NoRC, recruitment of NoRC to chromatin, and subsequent addition of repressive histone modifications and DNA methylation at the rRNA gene promoter ((Mayer 2006)). Without IGS RNA, NoRC regulation is lost and rRNA expression is increased ((Mayer 2006)).
pRNAs processed by IGS sequences can function in-trans, suggesting they could silence the rRNA genes they originate from or other rRNA gene clusters ((Santoro 2009)).

Expressed IGS sequences are found in widely diverged species ie: Xenopus, Drosophila and mouse ((Rungger 1979), (Miller 1983), (Kuhn 1987)), but may not carry out the same function.
In mammals the functional IGS sequences are poorly conserved at the nucleotide level but fold into similar stem-loop secondary structures ((Mayer 2008)).
The actual rRNA gene loci that express IGS and pRNAs have not been catalogued.
NeST recruits transcription factors to the gene encoding IFN-Î³Â (Ifng) to induce transcription

[[
RNAs of unknown identity associate with prion protein PrP, and participate in the conversion of human cellular PrP to its altered infectious conformation.
]]

Antisense to the long isoform of HOXA3 and to the 3' end of HOXA4 ((Sessa 2006), (Sasaki 2007)).
Several spliced, overlapping, transcripts are present at this locus ((Sessa 2006), (Sasaki 2007)).

Various antisense transcripts show similar expression profiles to each other and to HOXA3 and HOXA4. Expressed in the lung, kidney and testis ((Sessa 2006), (Sasaki 2007)).
Expression can be induced by retinoic acid ((Sessa 2006)).
Shows collinear regulation of expression like HOX PTC genes ((Sessa 2006), (Sasaki 2007)).
Antisense transcripts to HoxA3 and HoxA4 also exist in mouse but unclear if they are homologous.
Example accession is: BC035889
Located at 20p11.23. Consists of two exons (Vu 2012).

Expressed in brain and lymphocytes, not in fibroblasts and adipocytes. Gene is disrupted by a breakpoint in Macrosomia, obesity, macrocephaly, and ocular abnormalities syndrome (MOMO syndrome). Not expressed in lymphocytes of MOMO patients (Vu 2012).
Could contribute to pathogenesis of MOMO syndrome. Hypothesised invlovement in hyperphagia and intellectual disability in MOMO syndrome (Vu 2012).
roX1: RNA on the X 1 roX2: RNA on the X 2
rox1 and 2 are two X-linked genes. The primary and secondary structures of roX RNAs, including splice variants, are important for their function.

RNAs are male-specific.
RNAs are retained in the nucleus.
Expression is developmentally regulated in Drosophila male embryos. roX1 is specifically expressed in males from mid-embryogenesis onward and roX2 from 6h of embryo development onward.

RNAs are responsible for dosage compensation (DC) in Drosophila melanogaster males, directing global (but gene specific) up-regulation of transcription from the single male X-chromosome. roX1 and roX2 are essential for DC, but are functionally redundant.
The precise mechanisms by which roX RNAs direct the Dosage Compensation Complex (DCC) to specific sites in the X-chromosome are still unknown. RNAs associate with Male-specific lethal (MSL) proteins (components of the multi-protein complex DCC), directing the DCC to hundreds of sites along the X chromosome to promote histone acetylation and gene-specific activation.
Mapping of roX2 binding sites along the X-chromosome showed they were coincident with the binding sites of MSL proteins, supporting the view roX2 is part of the chromatin bound complex of MSL proteins ((Simon 2011)).
N/A
UCSC coordinates given below are to roX1 and roX2 which are found in separate locations.

Spliced, polyadenylated ~2.8kb transcript ((McGuinness 1996)).
Expressed from a highly conserved enhancer element downstream of Dlx1. Second exon overlaps exons and introns of Dlx1 in the antisense direction ((Dinger 2008)).

Dlx1as and Dlx1 were progressively more highly expressed during differentiation of embryonic stem cells ((Dinger 2008)).
Dlx1as and Dlx1 were both up-regulated during differentiation of neuronal progenitors to GABAergic neurons in vitro, but down-regulated during oligodendrocyte differentiation from the same progenitors ((Mercer 2010)).
Expressed in developing forebrain with highest expressive in the subventricular zone ((Liu 1998)).
Expressed in adult mouse brain, including in regions associated with neurogenesis (anterior subventricular zone, rostral migratory stream, and olfactory bulb) similar to the expression of Dlx1 and Dlx2 ((Dinger 2008)).

Exon one initiates from an enhancer highly conserved in therian mammals (found in oppossum as well as placental mammals). Second exon also overlaps highly conserved sequences but this is mostly Dlx1 exon regions.
Dlx1: distal-less homeobox 1. Transcription factor with an important role in brain development that is important role in specifying neuronal cell fate.
Kcnq1ot1: Kcnq1 opposite transcript 1 LIT1: long QT intronic transcript 1

91 kb, unspliced; imprinted (paternally expressed), it is transcribed from intron 10 of the maternally expressed Kncq1 (KvLQT1) gene from a CpG island that is the imprinting control region (IC2) ((Smilinich 1999)). This imprinted region contains at least eight genes that are expressed exclusively or preferentially from the maternal allele ((Kanduri 2011)).

Nuclear localised.
Expressed in most human tissues.
Mouse RNA found to be highly unstable with a half-life <2 hr in N2A (neuroblastoma) cells ((Clark 2012))

Summary: Kcnq1ot1 has a role in the organization of a tissue/lineage-specific nuclear domain involved in epigenetic silencing of the Kcnq1 imprinting control region.
Genes imprinted by kcnq1ot1 include Kcnq1, Cdkn1c, Slc22a18 and Phlda2, which are ubiquitously imprinted and Cd81, Osbpl5, Tssc4, Tspan32 and Ascl2, which are only imprinted in placenta (reviewed in (Kanduri 2011). An expansion of the Kncq1ot1 imprinted domain to include splice variants of Th and Ins2 was recently described ((Jones 2011)).
Kcnq1ot1 silences genes by coating chromatin and recruiting repressive chromatin remodeling complexes such as G9a, PRC1 and PRC2 ((Terranova 2008), (Pandey 2008), (Umlauf 2004), (Zhao 2010)) .
Kcnq1ot1 transcript has a modular structure, the silencing element (that mediates the epigenetic silencing and directs the imprinted locus to a heterochromatin environment in the perinucleolar region) appears to be a short <1kb conserved sequence near the 5' of the transcript ((Mohammad 2008)).
Kcnq1ot1 forms a silenced subdomain ((Terranova 2008))((Redrup 2009)) commonly localised to the perinucleolar region during S phase ((Mohammad 2008)). The silenced subdomain may be important to the maintenance of transcriptional repression.
Kcnq1ot1 interacts with Dnmt1 and recruits it to somatically acquired differentially methylated regions (DMRs) of imprinted genes ((Mohammad 2010)).
In vivo knockout study shows that paternal inheritance of a deletion encompassing an 890-bp (Delta890) silencing domain downstream of the Kcnq1ot1 promoter leads reduced interaction with DNMT1 and to selective incomplete relaxation of the imprinting of imprinted genes in a tissue-specific manner ((Mohammad 2010)).
Delta890 showed altered DNA methylation at somatically acquired DMRs but not in histone modifications of the ubiquitously imprinted genes. Thus, it has been proposed that the ubiquitous and placental-specific imprinting of genes within the Kcnq1 domain might be mediated by distinct mechanisms, and Kcnq1ot1 RNA might mediate the silencing of ubiquitously imprinted genes by maintaining allele-specific methylation through its interactions with Dnmt1 ((Mohammad 2010)).

Patches of highly conserved repeats in 5' side of transcript, which contains the silencing domain ((Mohammad 2008)). Promoter control elements are highly conserved between mouse and humans, including CCAAT elements that are targets of NF-Y regulation ((Pandey 2004)), as well as the position of CpG islands in the imprinting control region ((Paulsen 2004)).

(Syndromes and diseases associated, eg Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrom, and cancers (see references list): Associated with multiple balanced chromosomal rearrangements in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS) and an additional break-point in embryonal rhabdoid tumours; in particular, aberrant methylation of the CpG island associated with Kcnq1ot1 promoter is strongly associated with cancer risk and specific birth defects in BWS ((Smilinich 1999))).
For review on Kcnq1ot1 mechanism of action see ((Kanduri 2011)).
IGF2AS: Insulin-like growth factor 2 antisense PEG8: Paternally expressed gene 8
