Spliced transcript from bidirectional promoter with Igf2. Overlaps some Igf2 isoforms in antisense direction (mouse and human).
~4.8kb mouse transcript, four exons. Multiple splice isoforms in human, 2 or 3 exons, ~2 or ~2.8kb. Most homology is towards 3' of transcripts ((Okutsu 2000)).

Imprinted, expressed from paternal allele ((Okutsu 2000)). Igf2as generally retains imprinting in tumours even when Igf2 becomes bi-allelically expressed ((Vu 2003)).
Ubiquitously, but lowly, expressed in human adult and fetal tissues. 2 exon (has retained intron) isoform was specific to adult liver ((Vu 2003)).
Like Igf2, Igf2as showed highly up-regulated expression in Wilms tumour samples compared to neighbouring normal kidney tissue.
SNP polymorphisms in Igf2as associate with increased muscle damage (strength loss and soreness) after eccentric exercise, as do SNPs found in IGF2 ((Devaney 2007)).

Human Igf2as contains a predicted ORF, however this is not present in mouse ((Okutsu 2000)).
Also expressed and imprinted in pig ((Bischoff 2009)).
2795bp RNA transcribed from the 8q24 region of the human genome ((Croce (2014))). c-Myc binds to E-Box element on promoter, increasing promoter activity and expression ((Fang (2013))).

Overexpressed in all stages of colorectal cancer (CRC) from early tumorgenesis to late metastasis ((Gure (2012)), (Yavin (2014)), (Nissan (2013)), (Fang (2013))). Overexpressed in prostate cancer tissues ((Croce (2014))).

Expression results in increased cell proliferation and migration ((Fang (2013)), (Croce (2014))). siRNA knockdown results in decreased proliferation of colon derived cells and an increased population in the G1 phase, suggesting CCAT1 induces cell proliferation by inhibiting G1 arrest ((Croce (2014))). Expression patterns suggest role in CRC tumor pathogenesis ((Croce (2014))).
Annotation in Progress

Ubiquitously expressed in humans. From part of Snurf-Snrpn domain that shows ubiquitous human expression ((Vitali 2009))
Host transcript for multiple snoRNA genes.
Mouse RNA stability was close to median for lncRNAs, with a half-life of 3.2 hr in N2A (neuroblastoma) cells ((Clark 2012)).
VA I and II: virus-associated RNA I and II.

Human adenovirus encoded.
Transcribed by RNA polymerase III. Genes are separated in the adenovirus genome by a spacer of about 98 nt.
Highly structured RNAs of 160nt (VAI) and 163nt (VAII), with heterogeneous 3' ends and containing tightly structured stems.

Cytoplasmic localisation.
Expressed at very high levels during viral replication. VAII is expressed at 20-fold lower levels compared to that of VAI.

Important role for viral replication in infected cells (upon VAI deletion, adenovirus replication is impaired in most cells).
Thought to block PKR activity, avoiding phosphorylation of eIF-2alpha and inhibition of viral mRNA translation ((Thimmappaya 1982)). PKR-binding secondary structure domain can adopt different conformations, which are functionally non-equivalent and exist in a mixed population ((Wahid 2009)).
Recently, it has been shown that VA1 has an important role in suppressing the RNAi response in infected cells during viral replication ((Andersson 2005), (McKenna 2006), (Sano 2006), (Xu 2007)). Processed by Dicer into small RNAs that are incorporated into RISC (RNA-induced silencing complex). Approximately 80% of Ago2-containing RISC immunopurified from late-infected cells are associated with VA RNA-derived small RNAs (mivaRNAs), processed from the 3' strand of the terminal stems of the VA RNAs ((Xu 2007)). Nevertheless, VAII seems to be the preferred substrate for Dicer, accounting for approximately 60% of all small RNAs loaded in RISC ((Xu 2007)).
A deletion study shows that VAI may perform the role of bi-functional RNA by being processed by Dicer at the terminal stem to saturate the RNAi system, while generating a shortened VAI RNA that remains active to inhibit PKR. An RNA mutant that lacked the entire terminal stem was still able to bind PKR and inhibit its activity ((Wahid 2008)).
A fraction of the VAII-derived mivaRNAs are associated with polyribosomes, indicating a possible role in regulating translation of cellular mRNAs ((Xu 2007)).
N/A
[[Similar mechanism of action of EBER1 and 2 encoded by the Epstein-Barr virus ((McKenna 2006)), and other viral or endogenous lncRNAs.]]
Heterogeneous sizes, up to >1.4 kb; transcribed from tandem arrays of repetitive Satellite III (SatIII) DNA in pericentromeric heterochromatin.
Induced by heat shock and a range of stresses, such as heavy metals treatment, UV-C, oxidative and hyper-osmotic stress.
Can nucleate the formation of nuclear stress bodies, recruiting transcription factors and RNA processing factors (HSF1, SAF-B and SF2/ASF) to these sites ((Shevtsov 2011)).
N/A
Genebank accessions for various RNAs: AY845690 - AY845709
Expressed in all tissues, most abundant in brain (Talkowski (2012)).
Implicated in brain development (Talkowski (2012)).
Ftx is located upstream of Xist
Ftx is upregulated in female ES cells and partially avoids X-inactivation (Chureau 2010).
Mutations in Ftx leads to changes of expression in the X-inactivation center and decreases Xist levels (Chureau 2010).
Ftx shows conserved exons between mouse, human and cow (Chureau 2010).
DutA: Development-specific but UnTranslatable RNA A
~1.3 kb, transcribed by RNAP II, and exported to the cytoplasm ((Yoshida 1994)).

"Developmentally regulated" during Dictyostelium discoideum multicellular organization: induced during aggregation and exhibits a distinct expression pattern during stalk formation, ceasing with the onset of culmination ((Yoshida 1994)) ((Kumimoto 1995)) ((Maeda 2003)). dutA expression is not affected by cAMP signaling but requires protein kinase A (PKA) signaling ((Kumimoto 1996)).
A Serial Analysis of Gene Expression (SAGE) study indicates that dutA is the most abundant polyadenylated RNA in the Dictyostelium transcriptome, expressed at a level almost twice that of the next highest gene ((Whitney 2010)).
A microarray analysis of D. discoideum cells infected with Legionella pneumophila indicated down-regulation of dutA mRNA, suggesting a possible function of dutA in hostâ€“pathogen interaction ((Farbrother 2006)).

The function of dutA remains unclear. Disruption of dutA showed no morphological phenotype under normal conditions of growth and development ((Yoshida 1994)), which may be due to functional redundancy.
However, over-expression of dutA segments suppresses mutations in the signaling component Dd-STATa (the functional homolog of metazoan STAT transcriptional factors), rescuing stalk formation that is impaired in the mutants and indicating an inhibitory role of dutA in culmination. It also restores expression of target genes and tyrosine phosphorylation, indicating that dutA acts upstream of Dd-STATa in the signal transduction pathway and has an important role in Dictyostelium multicellular development switch ((Shimada 2007)).
Contains some peculiar sequence motifs.
Part of retained intron (between 4 and 5 exon) of the host O-linked N-acetylglucosamine transferase (Ferdin 2013).
Overexpressed in epithelial cancer cell lines such as colorectal HCT-116 and breast MCF-7. Located in nucleus.

HINCUT is transcribed from T-UCRs (transcribed, ultraconserved regions). Under hypoxic conditions transcription factor HIF transcribes O-linked N-acetylglucosamine transferase as well as HINCUT as its retained intron. HINCUT supports cell proliferation under hypoxic conditions and may be critical for optimal O-GlcNAcylation of proteins. Downregulation of HINCUT led to a significant decrease in the global O-GlcNAcylation rate, an effect similar to treatment with OGT-siRNA (Ferdin 2013).
Highly conserved between human, mouse and rat. LncRNA derives from "transcribed-ultraconserved regions" (T-UCRs).
Under regulaton by HIF (hypoxia induced factor). Has enhancer activity both under hypoxic and normoxic conditions (Ferdin 2013).
~5.5kb transcript originating from the 3'UTR of E2F4. Antisense to E2F4.

Localised to the nucleus and the cytoplasm although it is mainly cytoplasmic.
Expression identified in HCT116 colorectal carcinoma cells.
Expression is driven by Wnt signalling with beta-catenin and TCF/Lef binding to the E2F4 3'UTR to upregulate E2F4 antisense transcription.

Expression of E2F4 antisense lead to a decrease in E2F4 protein levels and reduced binding of E2F4 to its target gene promoters. This effect did not occur with, and could be blocked by, an E2F4 3'UTR sense construct.
Disruption of Wnt signalling is very common in colorectal cancer and it was hypothesised that induction of E2F4 antisense by Wnt signaling may contribute to carcinogenesis by reducing levels of the E2F4 cell cycle repressor.

E2F4 acts in cell cycle controls where it is thought to act as a repressor of proliferation.
Neither the sequence nor exact coordinates of E2F4 antisense are available.

L1 LINE (non-LTR retroelement).
Intergenic, although several spliced ESTs cover locus and L1PA16 is in an intron of these ESTs.
Size of full length transcript unknown.
Found to be expressed in tumour cell lines but not in fibroblasts ((Li 2009)).

Fragment from L1PA16 found to bind hPSF protein and release it from GAGE6 proto-oncogene regulatory DNA in-vitro and in-vivo ((Li 2009)).
L1PA16 expression caused increased colony formation in culture and a small increase in tumour formation in mice ((Li 2009)).
Suggests L1PA16 has oncogenic activity by repressing hPSF tumour suppressor activity ((Li 2009)).
Only described in humans to date
2106 bp, 3 exons.
Expressed in muscle cells (Eun (2013)).

noncoding repressor of NFAT (NRON)
~2.7 kb. Composed of three exons, which can be alternatively spliced to yield transcripts ranging in size from 0.8 to 3.7 kb.

Expressed in relatively low levels. Present in mouse embryos and enriched in cells derived from human and mouse placenta, muscle, and lymphoid tissues such as the spleen, thymus and lymph nodes, with differential expression of isoforms.

Identified in a shRNA knock down screening for conserved long noncoding RNAs that modulate the activity of nuclear factor of activated T cells (NFAT).
Knockdown of human or mouse NRON sequences in human embryonic kidney (HEK) 293 cells or mouse 3T3 and Jurkat cell lines resulted in significantly increased NFAT activity.
Knockdown of NRON increases NFAT transcription factor activity by specifically affecting NFAT nuclear trafficking. This effect is observed on the activity of multiple NFAT family members (NFATc1, NFATc2, NFATc3, and NFATc4).
Using an RNA-protein affinity purification strategy with part of NRON sequence, 11 proteins were reported to putatively bind NRON. These included: calmodulin-binding protein (IQGAP1), a nuclear transport factor (KPNB1), the structural subunit of a phosphatase (PPP2R1A), a component of the proteasome (PSMD11) and an RNA helicase (DDX3X); as well as three members of the importin-beta superfamily, factors which mediate the nucleocytoplasmic transport of cargoes such as NFAT. Direct interaction was demonstrated with importin-beta 1 (KPNB1).
In summary, having a repressive effect on NFAT signaling, NRON is proposed to regulate NFAT's subcellular localization as an RNA component of a protein complex that acts to represses NFAT activity. It has presumed implications in immune response and developmental processes regulated by NFAT.

NRON contains blocks of sequence which are highly conserved back to chicken. In particular, it contains two large regions of 300 to 400 bases regions of near-perfect sequence conservation between rodents and primates.
PWR1: promoting Watson RNA1

~1.2kb capped, polyadenylated, single exon transcript.
PWR1 expressed in FLO11 regulatory region.
Expressed on opposite strand to FLO11. Starts within a region covered by a second lncRNA ICR1, transcribed in antisense direction to ICR1 and terminates around the area of ICR1 initiation.

Expression of ICR1 and PWR1 is inversely correlated.
ICR1 expression requires the Sfl1 transcription factor known to repress FLO11 and is repressed by the Flo8 transcription factor and the Rpd3L histone deacetylase (HDAC).
PWR1 expression requires Rpd3L HDAC and Flo8 and is repressed by Sfl1.

PWR1 regulates expression of the FLO11/MUC1 gene in cis, in conjunction with a second lncRNA ICR1.
Expression of ICR1 represses expression of FLO11, probably by promoter occlusion.
Expression of ICR1 is repressed by PWR1 (again probably by promoter occlusion in cis), allowing expression of FLO11, so the regulatory circuit depends on whether PWR1 is expressed or repressed.
ICR1 is lowly expressed constitutively and competition between Flo8 and Sfl1 transcription factors determines which ncRNA is expressed and therefore if FLO11 is on or off.

FLO11/ MUC1 - cell surface glycoprotein that controls cell-cell adhesion and shows variegated expression in a clonal population of yeast cells (ie: expressed at high levels in some cells, silenced in others).
Sequence of PWR1 is found on chromosome IX from coordinates 395996 to 396936. See http://www.yeastgenome.org/cgi-bin/locus.fpl?sgdid=S000132614
TUG1: taurine up-regulated gene 1 ((Young 2005)).
Multiple Tug1 isoforms, with a main 6.7kb transcript in mouse. Spliced ((Young 2005)).

Expressed in the developing retina and brain ((Young 2005)).
Expressed in adult tissues with highest expression in cortex ((Young 2005)).
Expression levels are elevated in the caudate nucleus of patients suffering from the trinucleotide repeat neurodegenerative condition, Huntington's disease ((Johnson 2011)).
Localises to both the nucleus and cytoplasm ((Khalil 2009)).
Transcript was classified as unstable with a half-life >4 hr in human Hela cells ((Tani 2012)). Similar results were found in human B cells and mouse 3T3 cells ((Friedel 2009), (Clark 2012)).

Required for the proper formation of photoreceptors in the developing rodent retina ((Young 2005)).
Downregulation in developing retina leads to decreased retinal transcription factor expression and increased apoptosis ((Young 2005)).
TUG1 expression appears to be activated by p53 upon DNA damage, ((Guttman 2009)) with many p53 binding sites in the Tug1 promoter ((Khalil 2009)). Tug1 associates with PRC2 (polycomb repressive complex 2) and represses a number of cell cycle genes ((Khalil 2009)).

Mammals - identified in mouse, rat, cow, dog and human ((Young 2005)).
Present in two locations in rat, with one an apparent processed pseudogene.
Nb: Mouse NRED accession is specific to one of two Tug1 isoforms.
Steroid receptor RNA Activator

Bifunctional gene, active as an RNA and encodes a conserved protein SRAP (reviewed in (Leygue 2007)).
SRA has a large number of isoforms, most of which share a central core region. Only some isoforms are also able to encode the SRAP protein, and differential splicing may be one mechanism of generating coding and noncoding isoforms of SRA ((Hube 2006)) (reviewed in (Leygue 2007)).
A number of functional motifs, with predicted secondary structures, are required for SRA RNA function ((Lanz 2002)).

Expressed in a wide range of tissues, some isoforms appear to have tissue specific expression ((Lanz 1999), (Lanz 2003)).
Up-regulated in tumours of steroid hormone responsive tissues ie: breast, uterus and ovary compared to matched normal tissue ((Murphy 2000), (Lanz 2003)).
Found in the nucleus and the cytoplasm ((Lanz 2003), (Zhao 2006)).

Forms ribonucleoprotein complexes with a number of nuclear receptors (including many steroid hormone receptors) generally acting to stimulate transcriptional activation ((Lanz 1999), (Leygue 2007)).
Interacts either directly or through a complex with a number of other co-activator and repressor proteins, such as SRC-1, Sharp, SLIRP and p68 and p72 RNA helicases. SRA has been suggested to act as a scaffold for these complexes (reviewed in (Leygue 2007)).
Transgenic expression of SRA in vivo caused hyperplasia and morphological abnormalities in steroid hormone responsive tissues. Hyperplasia was accompanied by higher apoptosis however and expression of SRA did not lead to tumourigenesis ((Lanz 2003)).
Associated with cardiomyopathy in humans, a role in heart development was validated in zebrafish but it's unclear if SRAP or SRA or both is responsible ((Friedrichs 2008)).
SRA activity is regulated by pseudouridylation ((Zhao 2004), (Zhao 2006)).

SRA ncRNA conserved in mammals ((Leygue 2007)).
SRAP Protein is conserved in chordata ((Chooniedass-Kothari 2004)).

Some isoforms of SRA encode a conserved protein product SRAP, which is also expressed in normal tissues and breast cancer ((Emberley 2003), (Chooniedass-Kothari 2004), (Chooniedass-Kothari 2005)).
Studies show SRAP can also regulate the activity of nuclear receptors and bind to promoter regions regulated by nuclear receptors, suggesting functional similarities between SRA RNA and SRAP ((Chooniedass-Kothari 2010), (Chooniedass-Kothari 2010)).
(Leygue 2007) provides a useful review of the literature.

Bidirectional transcript with Zfp148.
Several splice isoforms. LincRNA ((Guttman 2010)).
Sequence can contain a number of repeat elements.
Expressed in mouse embryonic stem cells (ESCs) ((Guttman 2010)).

Involved in maintaining pluripotency in ESCs ((Guttman 2011)).
Knockdown in mECSs lead to down-regulation of Nanog, Oct4, Sox2, Klf4 and Zfp42 expression ((Guttman 2011)).
Found to interact with chromatin binding protein/complexes in mouse embryonic stem cells including JARID1C and ESET ((Guttman 2011)).
No evidence for expressed orthologue in human

Multiple ncRNAs transcribed from the promoter region of the cyclin D (CCND1) gene.
Transcripts of ~200nuc, ~330nuc and longer from both strands found within 2kb of the CCND1 transcription start site.

Expression induced by DNA damage signals.
Transcripts highly enriched in chromatin.
Transcripts expressed from PROMPT (promoter upstream transcripts) regions, PROMPT transcripts are degraded by the exosome and generally highly unstable ((Preker 2008)).

Regulates gene expression of cyclin D1.
ncRNAs have free ssRNA region plus RNA:DNA duplex region to tether them to the CCND1 locus.
Interaction of ncRNA ssRNA region with RNA-binding protein TLS (translocated in liposarcoma) promotes allosteric modification of the protein, leading to inhibition of CREB-binding protein and histone acetyltransferase activities to repress cyclin D1.
Promoter associated RNAs that can regulate expression of their associated protein coding gene by acting as a guide for a generic protein transcriptional regulator.
Transcripts are not exactly defined so Browser link below is to the 2kb upstream of the CCND1 transcription start site.

RNA estimated at ~1.9kb. anti-NOS2A has homology to the NOS2A protein coding gene (NOS2: Nitric oxide synthase 2 enzyme), only a small part ~100-nt is antisense to NOS2A. Homology stretches from intron14/exon15 to exon19/intron19. Formed by partial duplication of NOS2A followed by an inversion of part of the duplicated sequence to form a ~4kb locus in human.
PolyA- RNA. Intronless (NOS2A introns now part of the anti-NOS2A exon).
Expressed from a hypothesized internal promoter.

Expressed in brain cancer.
Expressed in hESCs (at a higher level than NOS2A) but down-regulated ~7 fold in neurospheres, while NOS2A showed a reciprocal expression pattern.
Reciprocal regulation with NOS2A could suggest a regulatory role for the antisense transcript but this has yet to be tested.
Found in primates but not in rodents.

Nb: Precise genomic location and sequence of anti-NOS2A was not provided by Korneev et al. Anti-NOS2A was identified as belonging to contig AC053481 and homologous sequence within this contig (including evidence of an invesrsion) can be found at ~chr17:57,692,139-57,696,081 in HG18, but this does not exactly define the transcript identified by Korneev et al.
bft: bereft

Two alternatively spliced ~3.5kb and ~6.5kb isoforms ((Hardiman 2002)).
Another longer extended isoform that is a precursor transcript for miR-263a has also been identified ((Graveley 2010)).

Expressed in external sensory organs of the embryonic peripheral nervous system. Bristles in Drosophila are sensory organs and bereft is expressed in structural support cells during bristle formation.
Shows a punctate and possibly peri-nuclear localization

Required for bristle morphogenesis in external sensory organs.
Appears to act downstream of cut and tramtrack
NCBI seq accession for two bft transcripts are: NR_001644.1 and NR_001643.1

Two overlapping antisense RNAs from intron 1 of the human ribosomal protein 14 (Rps14) gene, identified by RNase Protection Assay (RPA).
RPA expression analysis using both cell extracts and cell-free transcription system indicates full-length sizes of 250 and 280 nt, respectively. Transcripts terminate at the same nucleotide, therefore alpha-250 overlaps alpha-280 along its whole length.
Transcription of both RNAs is resistant to high concentrations of RNAPII inhibitor alpha-amanitin.

Ubiquitously expressed in the human tissues and cell lines examined.
Alpha-250 was almost exclusively cytoplasmic. Alpha- 280 was mostly in the nucleus.

Regulates RPS14 transcription.
Each lncRNA can interact with the Rps14 gene loci to stimulate its expression in-trans.
Each lncRNA is transcribed through a known enhancer with putative transcription factor binding abilities, suggesting the 'enhancer' may be the transcribed RNA, which could be recruiting transcription factors to the Rps14 gene.
781nt, possibly mitochondrial-derived transcript ((Dorn 2014)).

Downregulated early after myocardial infaction, upregulated in later stages. Circulating levels elevated in patients with chronic heart failure and levels at inclusion associated with risk of cardiovascular death ((Kumarswamy 2014)).
Expression levels can predict future cardiac remodelling in patients after myocardial infarction ((Kumarswamy 2014)).
LUST: LUCA-15-specific transcript.

~1.4 - 2.4 kb. Intronic, unspliced and transcribed antisense to the putative tumour suppressor gene RBM5/LUCA-15/H37, spanning introns 6 to 4 ((Rintala-Maki 2009)).
Contains SINE elements.
Originally cloned from an human bone marrow library ((Sutherland 2000)), this transcript is abundant in skeletal and cardiac muscle (as detected by Northern blot) ((Rintala-Maki 2009)).

*Transfection of Jurkat T cells with a 326 bp fragment of LUST (originally termed Je2) suppresses CD95-mediated apoptosis ((Sutherland 2000)).
*Ectopic over-expression of LUST affects splicing of RBM5: it correlates with elevated expression of the full-length RBM5+5+6 splice variant, and with reduced expression of the truncated RBM5+5+6t isoform, which is cytotoxic ((Rintala-Maki 2009)).

it is transcribed from intronic regions at the opposite strand in the tumour-suppressor RASSF1A [Ras association (RalGDS/AF-6) domain family member 1 isoform A] 3p21.3 gene locus in several human cell lines (Beckedorff 2013).

ANRASSF1 expression was higher in prostate and breast tumour cell lines compared with immortalized non-tumour lines, while the opposite pattern was found for the RASSF1A tumour suppressor gene (Beckedorff 2013).

ANRASSF1 is tethered to its transcriptional site forming an RNA/DNA hybrid, binds to PRC2, and recruits this complex only to the RASSF1A promoter, increasing H3K27me3 repressive histone mark. Interestingly, no ANRASSF1 effect on histone marks was detected either on the promoter of the RASSF1C isoform or on the promoters of four other genes in the tumour suppressor gene cluster at the 3p21.3 locus (Beckedorff 2013). ANRASSF1 overexpression decreases RASSF1A expression levels and increases the cell proliferation rate, whereas its silencing causes opposite effects (Beckedorff 2013).
Transcribed from the opposite strand to GDNF. Gene consists of 4 exons, and is alternatively spliced. One of the 3 isoforms encodes a protein of 104aa ((Airavaara 2011)).
Highly expressed in kidney, ovary and testis. More highly expressed in the cerebellum and nucleus accumbens relative to other brain areas ((Airavaara 2011)).
Exons 2 , 3 and 4 splicing acceptor and donor sites are shared across mammals ((Airavaara 2011)).

Gene involved in the cellular response to a number of stressors.
754 nt ((Hollander 1996)).

Induced by DNA damage ((Hollander 1996)), lipotoxic-stress ((Brookheart 2009)), non-lipid oxidative stress (ie hydrogen peroxide exposure) ((Crawford 1996), (Crawford 1996)), serum starvation ((Hollander 1996), (Crawford 1996)) and heat shock ((Crawford 1996)).

Regulation of lipid-induced oxidative and ER stress ((Brookheart 2009)).
Causes growth arrest and cell death ((Hollander 1996), (Brookheart 2009)).
Found in cytoplasm associated with active ribosomes ((Crawford 1996)), however all attempts at in-vitro and in-vivo translation have failed to express any peptides from the short ORFs found in the sequence ((Crawford 1996), (Hollander 1996), (Brookheart 2009)). Suggests ribosomal association could be regulatory, though translation of gadd7 can't be completely ruled out.
Induction by hydrogen peroxide required calcium ((Crawford 1996)).
Identified in hamster.
497bp long, 3 exons.
Expressed in human pluripotent cells (Vallot (2013)).
Coats the active X chromosome (Vallot (2013)).
Not expressed in mice (Vallot (2013)). The LTR that corresponds to the 5' end of XACT is conserved in chimpanzees but not macaques or more distally related species (Vallot (2013)).

253nt transcript with four exons and three introns. Sequence analysis indicated that LincRNA-EPS is a 2531-nt transcript with four exons and three introns .The 5'end cap structure, as indicated by the 5'RLM-RACE, and the 3' end poly(A) tail, as implied by the 3'RACE, indicate that LincRNA-EPS is a PolII transcript.
Increased during mouse erythrogenesis, has a predominantly nuclear localisation. Enriched in hematopoietic organs, such as spleen, bone marrow, and fetal liver cells (Hu 2011)

shRNA inhibits proliferation of erythroid cells during their terminal differentiation, associated with increased apoptosis. OE increases S-phase profression but does not force terminal differentiation. Functions in part via repression of PYCARD (Hu 2011)

~1.1kb sense transcript from first intron of FLC
5â€™ capped, but not generally polyadenylated
RNA polymerase II transcript
Transcriptional start site within vernalization response element (VRE), which is required for proper vernalization dependant repression of FLC and appears to act as the promoter for COLDAIR.

Transcriptional start site within vernalization response element (VRE), which is required for proper vernalization dependant repression of FLC and appears to act as the promoter for COLDAIR.
Expression specifically and transiently induced during vernalization / cold exposure with a peak at around day 20 and return to baseline levels by day 30. Nb: this expression pattern is similar to COOLAIR, but up to 10 days delayed.
COLDAIR transcription may be shut off in negative feedback loop, where it shuts off transcription within the FLC gene including its own.

COLDAIR is required for stable repression of FLC after vernalization and a lack of COLDAIR lead to late flowering after vernalization.
COLDAIR binds PRC2 complex protein CURLY LEAF (CLF), with maximal interaction after 20 days of vernalization / cold exposure.
COLDAIR is required to recruit PRC2 to the FLC locus allowing deposition of the repressive H3K27me3 chromatin mark.
COLDAIR did not impact the expression of other genes that repress flowering.

Epigenetic represssion of FLOWERING LOCUS C (FLC) is required for Arabodopsis flowering in spring.
Polycomb repressive complex 2 is required for FLC repression.
COLDAIR is distinct from COOLAIR, which does not appear to interact with PRC2.
~0.5kb. Unspliced, polyadenylated. Alternative polyadenylation may give rise to different isoforms of ~510 and ~440 nt (excluding polyA tail).

Mainly cytoplasmic but when bound to Mei2p becomes mainly nuclear localised in the Mei2p nuclear granule/ dot structure.
Expression of meiRNA is induced by nitrogen starvation in Schizosaccharomyces pombe, which causes a switch from the mitotic cell cycle to meiosis that is dependent on mei2.

meiRNA specifically binds (both in-vivo and in-vitro) and is required for nuclear localisation of Mei2, which is an RNA-binding protein essential for premeiotic RNA synthesis and meiosis. Mei2p relocalises to nuclear granules/dot structures after binding to meiRNA, resulting in a cell switch from mitosis to meiosis.
Overexpression of meiRNA suppresses a temperature-sensitive defect of mei2+.
Mei2-meiRNA complex functions specifically at Meiosis I, and loss of function of meiRNA blocks meiosis, but not premeiotic DNA synthesis.

Mei2 may interact with other regulatory RNAs. A Mei2 defective in RNA binding cannot promote meiosis, and causes premeiotic DNA synthesis inhibition. In addition, the cytoplasmic function of Mei2, which is independent of meiRNA, is also abrogated in the RNA-binding mutant.
THURIL expression measured by qpcr in Huma tissues; THRIL expression was clearly lower during the acute phase of KAWASAKI disease when TNFa levels were elevated

we propose a model in which hnRNPL and linc1992 form an RNP complex that regulates basal and stimulated transcription of TNFa by binding to the TNFa promoter. In activated cells, high levels of TNFa secretion initiate a negative feedback loop in which linc1992 and, in turn, TNFa expression is down-regulatedstable and transient knockdown of linc1992 strongly suppressed TNFa and IL-6 induction Overexpression of linc1992 significantly up-regulated basal TNFa mRNA levels linc1992â€“hnRNPL complex binding at the promoter is required to maintain basal transcription of TNFa confirmed by ChIRP). in cells with stable knockdown of linc1992 and following stimulation with PAM, mRNA levels of TNFa increased but protein levels didnâ€™t. TNFa mRNA expression was elevated as early as 1 h after addition of exogenous TNFa and that this observation was mirrored by a decrease in Linc1992 expression, confirming the negative feedback regulation of linc1992 by TNFa
Paupar is located on the antisense strand upstream of Pax6. It is contained in the first intron of Pax6os1

Paupar has the highest expression in Brain tissue but it is also expressed in other tissues such as colon, small intestine and stomach (Vance 2014). Paupar shows coexpression with Pax6, and both Paupar and Pax 6 are upregulated during neuronal differentiation (Vance 2014). Paupar is found in the chromatin fraction (Vance 2014).

Paupar is a chromatin associated transcripts which regulates genes inolved in cell cycle control (Vance 2014). Knockdown of Paupar leads to accumulation of cells in S and G2 phase of the cell cycle (Vance 2014). Knockdown also leads to increase neurite outgrowth and neuronal differentiation (Vance 2014). Paupar works in trans to modulate regulators of transcription (Vance 2014).
Paupar has certain regions that are conserved in Vertebrates (Vance 2014).
Messenger RNA that encodes the p53 protein, but also has a role as regulatory RNA that interacts with Mdm2 protein, controlling its function and p53 gene expression.
N/A
"p53 mRNA region that interacts with the Mdm2 RING domain also encodes the amino acids which bind the N-terminus of Mdm2 protein"
N/A

p53 is a key tumour suppressor gene which "responds to diverse cellular stresses to regulate target genes that induce cell cycle arrest, apoptosis, senescence, DNA repair, or changes in metabolism". MDM2 is an important regulator of p53, with binding of MDM2 protein to p53 protein promoting p53 degradation.

ref.id: responds to diverse cellular stresses to regulate target genes that induce cell cycle arrest, apoptosis, senescence, DNA repair, or changes in metabolism

annotation.annotation:
Neat1: Nuclear enriched abundant transcript 1. Short isoform - Neat1 v1. Long isoform - Neat1 v2
Multiple endocrine neoplasia 1 (MEN1). Short isoform - MEN epsilon. Long isoform - MEN beta.
VINC: Virus-inducible ncRNA

Two isoforms: ~3.7 (NEAT1 v1/ MEN epsilon) and ~23 kb (NEAT1 v2/ MEN beta) transcribed from the MEN1 locus ((Guru 1997), (Saha 2006), (Hutchinson 2007), (Sunwoo 2008)).
Intergenic, single exon transcript. One transcriptional start site, long isoform is a continuation of the short isoform ((Hutchinson 2007)).

Expressed in a wide range of human and mouse tissues ((Peyman 1998), (Saha 2006), (Hutchinson 2007), (Sunwoo 2008)). Although expression of the long isoform (Neat1 v2/ Men beta) is much lower than Neat1 v1/ Men epsilon in many tissues ((Nakagawa 2011)).
Up-regulation of Neat1 (and subsequent formation of/increase in paraspeckles) may be a general feature of differentiation. Neat1 is up-regulated upon human ESC differentiation ((Chen 2009)), muscle differentiation ((Sunwoo 2008)) and in-vitro neuronal differentiation ((Mercer 2010)).
Up-regulated upon infection of mice with Japanese encephalitis virus or Rabies virus ((Saha 2006)).
Expressed in the nucleus accumbens of normal human brains and upregulated in this brain region in heroin abusers ((Michelhaugh 2010)). In addition, expression levels are elevated in the caudate nucleus of patients suffering from the neurodegenerative condition, Huntington's disease ((Johnson 2011)).
Localised to paraspeckles within the nucleus ((Hutchinson 2007), (Sunwoo 2008)).
Mouse Neat1 found to be highly unstable (half-life <2 hr) in N2A (neuroblastoma) and 3T3 cells, although low stability did not prevent paraspeckle formation ((Friedel 2009), (Clark 2012)), while human NEAT1 appears to be more stable ((Friedel 2009), (Sasaki 2009), (Sunwoo 2008)). The two Neat1 isoforms also have differing stability, with the long (v2/Men beta) isoform more stable than than the shorter (v1/Men epsilon) isoform in N2A and 3T3 cells ((Clark 2012)).

Transcription of Neat1 is essential for the assembly, maintenance and structural integrity of paraspeckles ((Clemson 2009), (Sasaki 2009), (Sunwoo 2008), (Mao 2010)).
Newly transcribed Neat1 RNA nucleates the formation of paraspeckles at its transcription site, recruiting paraspeckle proteins. Continued expression is required to maintain paraspeckles, identifying the dynamic nature of this nuclear body ((Mao 2010)). Literature currently provides conflicting evidence about whether Neat1 v1 is sufficient for the formation of paraspeckles, or if this requires full length Neat1 v2 ((Sasaki 2009), ((Shevtsov 2011)). In vivo however, significant expression of Neat1 v2 appears to be required for cells to form more than 1 or 2 paraspeckles ((Nakagawa 2011)).
Neat1 appears to constrain the size and mediate the cylindrical geometry of paraspeckles. Neat1 short and the identical 5' end of Neat1 long plus the 3' of Neat1 long all localise to the periphery of paraspeckles, while the central region of Neat1 long is found in the interior of the nuclear body ((Souquere 2010)).
Interacts with paraspeckles proteins PSPC1, PSF/SFPQ and NONO/P54NRB either directly or in a complex ((Clemson 2009), (Sasaki 2009), (Sunwoo 2008)).
Interaction of short isoform with p54 requires protein interaction regions near the 5' and 3' of the transcript ((Murthy 2010)).
Neat1 knockout lead to loss of paraspeckles, however mice were viable and fertile with normal morphology and populations of differentiated cells in one Neat1 v1 and v2 expressing tissue tested ((Nakagawa 2011)).
Neat1 has also been reported to interact with a number of chromatin binding protein/complexes in mouse embryonic stem cells including PRC1, PRC2, JARID1B, ESET and SUV39H1, with the general pattern being interaction with repressors of gene expression ((Guttman 2011))
Placental mammals. Dog Neat1 is found in several genomic locations, version that is found near single dog Malat1 gene is given below ((Hutchinson 2007)).

A conserved tRNA like sequence at the 3' end is cleaved off and processed to generate a short tRNA-like ncRNA from the long (Men beta) transcript, similar to Malat1 ((Sunwoo 2008)).
The last ~500bp of the short (Men epsilon) isoform has been shown to be expressed in trophoblast cells with a function potentially independent from the Neat1 transcript. This transcript, TncRNA has its own entry.
ncRAN consists of two isorforms.

Expression of ncRNA increases in bladder carcinoma progression, which applies to both isoforms (Zhu 2010). nCRNA is also upregulated in invasive bladder cancer cell lines compared to superficial tumour cells (Zhu 2010).

Overexpression of both isoforms of ncRAN leads to increased cell migration and invasion while knockdown of ncRAN increases the amount of apoptotic cells by itself as well as after chemotherapy treatment (Zhu 2010).
contain long inverted repeats (316nt #1 and 545nt #2)

expressed in normal proliferating cells but downregulated in cancer cells ((Villegas 2007), (Burzio 2009)) The E2 oncogene from HPV16/18 induces down-regulation of the ASncmtRNAs Detectable in Urine ((Rivas 2012))

The transcript exits the organelle and localizes to the cytoplasm and the nucleus, where it can be found associated with chromatin and nucleoli ((Landerer 2011)). KD decreases proliferation in cancer cells(PMID: 25100722 ) Provides a putative source of microRNAs regulating survivin expression ((Vidaurre 2014))
SRG1: SER3 regulatory gene 1

Three transcripts: ~400 and 500bp transcripts, start upstream of the SER3 protein coding gene and cover SER3 promoter. Differ in 3' end with longer form also covering the beginning of the SER3 coding sequence. Polyadenylated ((Martens 2004), (Thompson 2006)). ~1.9kb transcript, begins at same position but runs to the end of the SER3 gene ((Martens 2004), (Thompson 2006)).
Could identity TATA-binding protein and RNA polymerase II binding to drive SRG1 expression ((Martens 2004)).

SRG1 is expressed under growth conditions where SER3 is not expressed ((Martens 2004)).
SRG1 expression is regulated by serine levels ((Martens 2005)).
Despite being identified as cryptic unstable transcripts (CUTs) ((Davis 2006)), SRG1 transcripts were predominately degraded in the cytoplasm not the nuclear exosome. ((Thompson 2006)).

SRG1 inhibits transcription of SER3 by transcriptional interference, as the process of SRG1 transcription through the SER3 promoter prevents transcription factor binding to this locus ((Martens 2004)). SRG1 transcription does not appear to be sufficient for repression with proper chromatin remodeling also required ((Davis 2006)).
SER3 is an enzyme involved in serine biosynthesis, whose expression is regulated by the level of serine. Serine level controlled the expression of SRG1, with SRG1 transcribed when serine is present and repressed when it is not. This regulation depended on Cha4, a serine dependent regulator, which binds the SRG1 promoter. When serine is high Cha4 appears to recruit the SAGA and Swi/Snf complexes to SRG1 promoter to activate SRG1 expression and repress SER3 ((Martens 2005)).
SRG1 promoter/ TATA element is conserved in multiple yeast species ((Martens 2004)).

~2.4kb
Appears to be antisense. Covers PHO5 gene region and promoter.

Expressed during high phosphate conditions when PHO5 is repressed.
Transcript degraded by the exosome and accumulates in exosome mutants.

LncRNA transcription involved in remodeling the PHO5 promoter and activation of the gene.
Loss of ncRNA transcription delayed nucleosome eviction and RNA polymerase II recruitment to the PHO5 promoter, showing it was necessary for proper activation.
Note: shows that transcription which generates short lived/ exosome degraded transcripts can be functionally relevant. Although it not known if the transcript itself is functional.
The PHO5 gene encodes a protein involved in phosphate metabolism that is repressed under high phosphate conditions and activated under phosphate starvation.

LincRNA enriched in ESC (embryonic stem cells) and iPSCS (induced pluripotent stem cells) compared to the fibroblast and CD34 cells the iPSCs were derived from.
Also more highly expressed in iPSCs than ESCs.
Locus is a binding site for pluripotency transcription factors Oct4, Sox2 and Nanog. Knockdown of Oct4 or differentiation of stem cells caused a modest down-regulation of lincRNA-VLDLR expression. Suggesting expression is controlled by these transcription factors.
Reported to have a syntenic correlate expressed in mouse ESCs.

The chromosomal region given in Loewer et al (2010) is for histone modifications and does not identify the precise transcript expressed in stem cells. Furthermore their qPCR primers do not correspond to exonic regions from the known EST CD247089 within this locus, so no transcript sequence can be given.
lincRNA-VLDLR location from histone modifications is: hg19 chr9:2,207,775-2,298,675
NTT: noncoding transcript in T cells.

17kb, polyadenylated, but not spliced.
Sense intronic to Phosphodiesterase 7B, also covers one exon.
Contains a number of repeats, mostly near the 3 end.

Expressed in activated, but not resting, CD4+ T cells. Also found in stimulated peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) and CD8+ T cells.
Localisation is predominately nuclear.
Shows a similar expression pattern to the interferon-gamma receptor gene, found ~1Mb away, which may suggest a co-regulation of the two transcripts in immune cell activation/development.
Has short regions of conserved sequence.

Phosphodiesterase 7B is a cAMP-specific phosphodiesterase, a member of the cyclic nucleotide phosphodiesterase family. Involved in cAMP and cGMP signaling.
Sequence given is from genomic DNA, which corresponded to results from RT-PCR and RACE.
Downregulated in nasopharyngeal cancer

NAG7 promotes human nasopharyngeal carcinoma invasion through inhibition of estrogen receptor alpha and up-regulation of JNK2/AP-1/MMP1 pathways (Huang 2009). OE inhibits overproliferation of NPC cell by delaying the progression of G1 into S in cell cycle and inducing cell apoptosis (Tan 2002). Increased expression is associated with improved patient outcome (Zhang 2013).
~40 kb; antisense to Xist noncoding RNA gene. (*Annotation in progress)
N/A

Epigenetically silences Xist expression by inhibiting RepA recruitment of polycomb complexes to maintain the active X chromosome in females ((Zhao 2008)).
Interacts with PRC2 complex ((Zhao 2008), (Guil 2012)).
N/A
N/A
CHRF is a single exon transcript that is located within the first intron of Dcc on the same strand.
The expression of CHRF Is about one third of miR-489, which it regulates, in heart, and it is also widely expressed in different tissues (Wang 2014).

Knockdown of endogenous CHRF leads to elevated levels of miR-489 in cardiomyocytes (Wang 2014). Luciferase assays utilising a miR-489 target shows decreased activity after CHRF knockdown while overexpression increased the activity suggesting that CHRF regulates miR-489 by binding it and functioning as a sponge (Wang 2014).
The miR-489 binding site in CHRF is conserved across eutherians (Wang 2014).
Apis noncoding RNA-1
Several splice isoforms. Main isoform is a 6-7kb transcript.

Expressed in brain cortex (not ubiquitously expressed). Also differentially expressed between queens, drones and workers: detected in sex organs in queens and drones and in the hypopharyngeal glands and oenocytes of worker bees.
Localises to punctate foci in nucleus. Did not co-localise with the Ks-1 nuclear lncRNA.

Also present in another honey bee species: Apis cerana. Sequence was highly conserved but putative ORFs were not.
At time of study, AncR-1 sequence did not show homology to sequences from any other organisms
Nucleotide accessions of different isoforms: AB125322.1, AB125323.1, AB125324.1
Encoded by Herpesvirus saimiri, acts as a target mimic to miR-27, directing its degradation and manipulating host T cell gene expression. Similar to mechanism in murine cytomegalovirus.
Located in the intron of Lrrc4c

Knockdown of AK139328 attenuates the increase of cytokines (IP-10 and MCP-1 after ischemia treatment in liver and decreases plasma alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) (Chen 2013). Knockdown reduced cleaved caspace3 in liver while IKba levels were increased in the cytoplasm and decreased nuclear levels of NF-kappaB (Chen 2013).

LncRNA transcripts from promoter of fbp1+ gene.
Three transcripts A to C. Expressed in sense direction. Unspliced.
Transcript A initiates furthest upstream from fbp1+ start site, B and C initiate progressively closer to fbp1+.
Although they are transcribed into fbp1+, A-C do not necessarily cover the whole coding sequence and no detectable protein was produced.

Transiently expressed upon glucose starvation before fbp1+ is switched on.
A shows very low constitutive expression and is expressed up to 20 min after glucose starvation. B expressed from 10-60 min, C from 20-60 min.
NB: fbp1+ switches on after 60 min.

Transcription of ncRNAs was required for opening of chromatin and activation of fbp1+ transcription.
Progressive movement of transcription from 5' to 3' towards the fbp1+ start site correlates with chromatin remodeling to open up DNA and RNA polymerase II movement.
Termination of upstream transcription prevented chromatin remodeling and fbp1+ induction, showing the necessity of the noncoding cascade in activating transcription.
Unknown if lncRNAs themselves are carrying out a function.
Identified in fission yeast: Schizosaccharomyces pombe

Multiple 2-4 exon isoforms with variation in splicing and TSSs.
Isoforms between 380 nt and 1.3kb
Intergenic between ROCK2 and E2F6
In-vitro translation showed no sign of protein product.
Expressed in HeLa cells.
LINC00570 expression appears to stimulate ROCK2 gene expression (in HeLa cells).
lncRNA-HEIH is polyadenylated, but the transcript of lncRNA-HEIH is located in both the nucleus and cytoplasm of HCC cells

Knockdown of lncRNA-HEIH decreases cell proliferation and PCNA (proliferating cell nuclear antigen) in HepG2 and Huh7 cell lines while overexpression had the opposite effect (Yang 2011). Knockdown of lncRNA-HEIH decreased the number of cell in G2-phase (Yang 2011). Growth of xenografts tumours were impaired after lncRNA-HEIH knockdown while the growth increased with overexpression (Yang 2011). lncRNA-HEIH interacts with EZH2, a subunit of PRC2 (Yang 2011).
H19 imprinting control region (ICR) noncoding RNAs

Nuclear localised sense and antisense transcripts were expressed from the ICR. Transcripts came from both maternal and paternal alleles ((Drewell 2002), (Schoenfelder 2007)).
Berteaux 08 also reported bi-allelic expression from the ICR region ((Berteaux 2008)).
Mouse and human ((Schoenfelder 2007), (Berteaux 2008)).
Sequence and precise genome location of the transcripts have not been defined.
Brain Cytoplasmic RNA 1
152 nt; evolved from a tRNA Ala ((DeChiara 1987)).

Expressed by a specific subset of neurons in the central and peripheral nervous system; localises to dendrites ((Tiedge 1991)), or both axons and dendrites ((Muslimov 2002), (Centonze 2007)) in different subsets of neurons and in a developmentally regulated manner.
Decreased expression in brains of mice that suffer chronic epileptic seizures (GitaÃ­ (2011)).
Also expressed in germ cells ((Muslimov 2002)).
Dendritic localisation mediated by an extended stem loop element ((Rozhdestvensky 2001)) in 5' 62 nucleotides ((Muslimov 1997)), containing two targeting codes a stem bulge motif that specifies nuclear export and a GA kink-turn (KT) motif that binds heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein A2 and mediates transport to the distal ends of dendrites ((Muslimov 2006)).

Summary: Functions to regulate localised translation at dendrites, controlling neuron excitability and place learning. Lack of BC1 causes a susceptibility to epileptic seizures.
Binds eIF4A, eIF4B and PABP to repress translation initiation by blocking assembly of the 48S initiation complex ((Wang 2002), (Muddashetty 2002), (Wang 2005), (Kondrashov 2005), (Lin 2008)).
Translational repression is mediated by its 3' domain and A rich region ((Muddashetty 2002), (Wang 2005), (Kondrashov 2005)).
Inhibits eukaryotic initiation factor 4A helicase by uncoupling ATPase activity from helicase/ duplex unwinding activity ((Lin 2008)).
By regulating localised translation BC1 can control neuron excitability; ie: by regulating dopamine receptor levels and dopamine signalling in the striatum ((Centonze 2007)) ie: inhibiting translation activation from metabotropic glutamate receptor (mGluR) signalling ((Zhong 2009)).
Knock-out of BC1 in mouse affected exploratory behaviour and anxiety, leading to higher mortality in field experiments ((Skryabin 2003), (Lewejohann 2004)).
Brain phenotypes of BC1 knockout mice include neuronal hyperexcitability triggered by mGluR signaling or GABAa receptor stimulation which stimulates protein translation BC1 would act to repress ((Zhong 2009), (Zhong 2010)). Epileptogenic susceptibility (epileptic activity and convulsive seizures) upon auditory stimulation ((Zhong 2009), (Zhong 2010)) and defects in place learning ((Zhong 2010)).
The combination of BC1 and fragile X mental retardation protein (FMRP) knockouts causes neuronal excitability, epileptogenesis, and place learning deficits of increased severity than individual knockouts suggesting BC1 and FMRP act independently to repress translation ((Zhong 2010)).

Evolved from a tRNA Ala ((DeChiara 1987)).
Rodent specific ((Martignetti 1993)).
BC1, BC200 and G22 likely form a family of independently exapted repetitive elements which have evolved to carry out similar functions in different mammalian species ((Muddashetty 2002), (Khanam 2006), (Lin 2008)).

597 nucleotides, unspliced. Sequence from full-length cDNA clone GSLTSIL78ZH02 is 645 bp-long.
Npc536 transcript is antisense to the AT1G67930 mRNA (encoding a Golgi-transport complex related protein) ((Ben Amor 2008)).

npc536 has a large dynamic range of expression across a wide range of tissues and hormonal, biotic, or abiotic treatments.
Up-regulated in roots and leaves of Arabidopsis thaliana plants submitted to stress by phosphate starvation and salt (NaCl) stress ((Ben Amor 2008)).

Transformed plants over-expressing npc536 showed heightened root growth under salt stress conditions, with increased primary root growth and secondary root length.
No phenotype could be observed in mutants that carry T-DNA insertions within npc536.
In response to certain abiotic stresses such as drought or cold treatment, the root expression of these two genes (AT1G67930 and npc536) tends to be anti-correlated (Pearson correlation coefficient of -0.636 and -0.983, respectively). However, accumulation of the AT1G67930 transcript was not significantly modified in plants over-expressing npc536 or in npc536 mutants ((Ben Amor 2008)).
Annotated as AT1G67920 hypothetical protein, Gene ID: 843120, in Genbank, and contains a small ORF conserved in rice ((Ben Amor 2008)). The 'hypothetical protein' is 67 aa.
LINoCR: LPS Inducible NonCoding RNA

Antisense RNA from the lysozyme regulatory region.
Promoter is -1.9kb hormone response element. Transcript extends several hundred nucleotides from a -2.120bp start site through the -2.4kb CTCF binding site to the -2.7kb enhancer.

Transient pulse of LINoCR expression after LPS treatment of macrophages. This expression correlates with upregulation of the lysozyme gene and eviction of the CTCF repressor and positioning of a nucleosome over the CTCF binding site.
Fast decrease in RNA levels suggested a half-life of 45min or less.

LINoCR expression was necessary for chromatin remodeling to switch the lysozyme regulatory region into an active confirmation.
CTCF protein acts to repress transcription of the lysozyme gene.
Repression of LINoCR expression prevented eviction of CTCF from the -2.4kb element as well as histone modifications of this site and positioning of a nucelosome over the CTCF binding site. This demonstrated that LINoCR expression was necessary for CTCF eviction.
Whether the LINoCR transcript has a function or if it is simply the act of transcription which is necessary is unknown.
Identified in chicken.
ICR1: interfering Crick RNA 1

~3.15kb capped and polyadenylated single exon transcript.
Expressed in FLO11 regulatory region.
ICR1 has variable start and termination sites. Begins between ~3.2 and 3.4kb upstream of FLO11, runs towards FLO11 in sense direction, some transcripts stop before FLO11 while others can overlap the 5' of the PTC gene.
A second 1.2kb lncRNA PWR1 is expressed antisense to ICR1.

Expression of ICR1 and PWR1 is inversely correlated.
ICR1 expression requires the Sfl1 transcription factor, which is known to repress FLO11, and is repressed by the Flo8 transcription factor and the Rpd3L HDAC protein.
PWR1 expression requires Rpd3L and Flo8 and is repressed by Sfl1.

ICR1 regulates expression of the FLO11/MUC1 gene in cis, in conjunction with a second lncRNA PWR1.
Expression of ICR1 represses expression of FLO11, probably by promoter occlusion.
Expression of ICR1 is repressed by PWR1 (again probably by promoter occlusion in-cis), allowing expression of FLO11, so the regulatory circuit depends on whether PWR1 is expressed or repressed.
ICR1 is lowly expressed constitutively and competition between Flo8 and Sfl1 transcription factors determines which ncRNA is expressed and therefore if FLO11 is on or off.

FLO11/ MUC1 - cell surface glycoprotein that controls cell-cell adhesion and shows variegated expression in a clonal population of yeast cells (ie: expressed at high levels in some cells, silenced in others).
Sequence of ICR1 on chromosome IX from coordinates 397079 to 393881 available from http://www.yeastgenome.org/cgi-bin/locus.fpl?sgdid=S000132612
shRNA depleton in a beta cell line did not cause significant changes in glucose-stimulated insulin secretion but consistently reduced GLIS3 mRNA levels (MorAn 2012)

Xrn1-sensitive unstable transcript (XUT) antisense to TIR1 gene.
5' of transcript begins in intergenic region downstream of TIR1 with 3' end overlapping TIR1 in antisense direction.
Up-regulated by Xrn1 knockout. Hence degraded by cytoplasmic Xrn1 degradation pathway.

TIR1 is down-regulated upon Xrn1 inactivation. Interrupting TIR1axut expression restored most of TIR1 expression suggesting TIR1axut silences TIR1. Therefore antisense XUTs can repress the transcripts they overlap.
Full TIR1axut repression requires Set1 activity and appears to be antagonised by H3K4me3.
Nb: Currently unclear exactly how silencing is mediated by TIR1axut.

Intergenic, 3-5 exon transcript. LincRNA ((Guttman 2010)).
Alternative splicing and three transcription start sites generate a number of isoforms ((Guttman 2010)).
Contains multiple repeat sequences.
~25kb downstream of Magi1 coding gene on same strand.
Expressed in mouse embryonic stem cells (ESCs) ((Guttman 2010)).

Involved in maintaining pluripotency in ESCs ((Guttman 2011)).
Knockdown in mECSs lead to down-regulation of Nanog, Oct4, Sox2, Klf4 and Zfp42 expression as well as changes to ESC morphology ((Guttman 2011)).
No evidence for expressed orthologue in human

Four noncoding RNAs from the RAY1/ST7 gene locus. Complex gene locus with a large number of coding and noncoding isoforms.
ST7OT1 & 2 are antisense to ST7. ST7OT3 & 4 are on the sense strand.
ST7OT1 - ~2kb unspliced antisense transcript that initiates in intron 1 of ST7, covers the first exon and terminates in the ST7 promoter region. Polyadenylated. Nb: it also overlaps exon 1 of ST7OT4.
ST7OT2 - Spliced antisense transcripts. Multiple isoforms that share either some 5' or some 3' exons. Isoforms are between 900-1300 bp, with 4-6 exons and polyadenlyated.
ST7OT3 - Spliced ~1kb transcript. Begins in intron 10 of ST7, shares exons 11-13 and sometimes 14 & 15 with ST7 plus has a number of unique exons. Some exons may also act as a alternative 3' end for ST7.
ST7OT4 - Multiple spliced transcripts within the long first intron of ST7. However, Refseq ST7OT4 transcript may be protein coding. Transcription begins just ~200bp downstream from the end of first ST7 exon.

ST7OT1 - abundantly expressed in testis, also expressed in cerebellum, skeletal muscle, uterus, cerebellum, spinal cord, fetal brain, and prostate.
ST7OT2 - testis, fetal brain, cerebellum, mammary gland, fibroblasts.
ST7OT3 - expression only detected in cerebellum.
ST7OT4 - no expression detected.

ST7OT1 - some conserved sequence with mouse, most of this is where ST7OT1 overlaps the first exon of ST7 however.
ST7OT2 - 3' end of some isoforms shows some conservation with mouse.
ST7OT3 - some conserved sequence, most of this is shared exons with ST7 though.
ST7OT4 - sequence not conserved with mouse.
ST7OT1 - NCBI Gene ID: 93653 ST7OT2 - NCBI Gene ID: 93654 ST7OT3 - NCBI Gene ID: 93655 ST7OT4 - NCBI Gene ID: 338069
Located in the 8q24 gene desert. Contains multiple SNPs.
Expressed in the myelomonocytic lineage ((Yin 2006))

Retinoic acid dependant modulator of myeloid differentiation. Role in cell poliferation, differentiation and apoptosis ((Yin 2006)). Contains multiple SNPs,which have been associated with nonsyndromic cleft lip ((Birnbaum 2009)), and various cancers ((Tomlinson 2007), (Ghoussaini 2008)), in particular glioma ((Shete 2009), (Schoemaker 2010), (Simon 2010), (Wang 2011), (Lasho 2011) , (Li 2012), (Enciso-Mora 2013)).

Spliced transcript localized ~181kb from the Enc1 gene ((Guttman 2009)).
mRNAs and ESTs suggest several transcripts or isoforms are present at this locus, which is currently not well defined.
Expressed in embryonic stem cells and down-regulated upon retinoic acid induced differentiation ((Ivanova 2006)).
Regulates cell cycle or viability in embryonic stem cells but not self-renewal ((Ivanova 2006)).
NRED accession ID is for another putative isoform and covers a splice junction not contained in the identified lincENC1 sequence. While the browser link is for Mm.219358/Gm2373.

At4: member of a family of RNAs induced by phosphate (Pi) starvation in plants that have a region of complementarity to miR-399 and short non-conserved ORFs ((Burleigh 1999), (Shin 2006), (Franco-Zorrilla 2007)).
Other family members in Arabidopsis are At4-1, At4-2, At4-3 and IPS1 ((Shin 2006), (Franco-Zorrilla 2007)).
At4 is ~750nuc ((Burleigh 1999)).

Expression of At4 family members is induced upon Pi starvation ((Burleigh 1999), (Franco-Zorrilla 2007)).
At4 is expressed in roots ((Burleigh 1999)) and shoots (MartÃ­n (2000)).
Hormonal signaling by cytokinins and abscisic acid repressed At4 expression in the roots (MartÃ­n (2000), (Shin 2006)).

Loss of At4 lead to increased shoot Pi content and an increase in the shoot:root Pi ratio under low Pi conditions suggesting At4 affects Pi distribution and plant growth ((Shin 2006)).
Competing endogenous RNA (ceRNA). At4 has complementarity to miR-399, but contains a central mismatch loop. Over-expression of At4 lead to a decrease in shoot Pi content suggesting that, like IPS1, At4 inhibits miR-399 through target mimicry thereby allowing activity of PHO2 ((Franco-Zorrilla 2007)).
At4 and IPS1 appear to be functionally redundant as overexpression of one gave same phenotypic change as overexpression of both ((Franco-Zorrilla 2007)).

At4 and IPS1 are paralogs in Arabidopsis.
At4 only shares homology with other family members (ie: At4-1 and At4-2, Mt4 in Medicago truncatula and Mt4-like in Glycine max) in the miR-399 complementarity region ((Burleigh 1999), (Shin 2006)).
Accession for other family members: At4-1: AY536062; At4-2: AY334555; At4-3: AI995459
SUT719: Stable Uncharacterized Transcript 719

Antisense to SUR7 coding gene. SUT719 comes from a bidirectional promoter with GAL80 where they share regulatory signals. The 3' end of SUT719 extends through and beyond the SUR7 transcription start site.

SUT719 and SUR7 are both expressed in standard galactose media. Upon stimulation with alpha-factor pheromone SUR7 is switched off while SUT719 continues to be expressed.
SUT719 expression is regulated by Gal4 (as is the expression of GAL80, which shares a bidirectional promoter with SUT719).

SUT719 is required for complete switching off of SUR7 expression (disruption of SUT719 expression allows SUR7 expression after stimulation with alpha-factor pheromone when it would normally not be expressed).
SUT719 acts to fine tune gene expression by impacting the on/off threshold of SUR7. When SUR7 is expressed at low levels it is inhibited by SUT719, but high level SUR7 gene expression is not affected by SUT719.

Regulation of GAL80 gene expression also affects SUT719, as they both come from a bidirectional promoter. In turn, SUT719 can regulate the expression of SUR7. This demonstrates a model whereby neighbouring coding genes regulate each other via ncRNA expression/ regulation and also a mechanism for spreading a regulatory signal (ie: that imposed on GAL80) along a chromosome.
Located at 1q24.2.

Differentially expressed in cisplatin resistant non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) (Wang 2013). siRNA knockdown results in decreased apoptosis induced by cisplatin in the Human lung adenocarcinoma cell line A549 (Wang 2013).

May confer cisplatin resistance in NSCLC. siRNA kockdown resulted in a decrease of naked cuticle 2 (NKD2) expression and increase in B-catenin protein levels. As NKD2 can negatively regulate the Wnt signalling pathway, LINC00970 appears to function by targeting the Wnt/B-catenin signalling pathway (Wang 2013).

Three Xrn1-sensitive unstable transcript (XUTs) upstream from SUC2 gene.
SUC2uxut1 (~2.3kb) in sense direction SUC2uxut2 (~1.2kb) and SUC2uxut3 (~1kb) in antisense direction overlapping SUC2uxut1.

Up-regulated in Xrn1 (5'-3' cytoplasmic exonuclease) knockout but unchanged in TRAMP nuclear degradation pathway knockout. Hence degraded by Xrn1 cytoplasmic pathway.
SUC2uxut1 reversibly upregulated by lithium.
Rubie is located upstream of Bmp4.

Rubie is expression in embryonic and postnatal inner ear. Expression is observed in the three sensory crisae, and it displays similar expression pattern to its downstream protein coding gene Bmp4 (Roberts 2012).
Although the funciton of Rubie remains unknown, Rubie is mutated in Epistatic circler mice (which causes circling behaviour) derived from SWR/J and C57L/J mice (Roberts 2012).

Three exon transcript. Contains miR-206 in second intron and miR-133b in third and final exon. Has binding sites for miR-135 in exon2 and miR-133 in exon 3. This structure is conserved in mouse and humans.
Shows evidence of alternative splicing of exon 2 in mouse. This alternative isoform no longer contains the miR-135 binding sites. Functional characterization was on the standard isoform containing the miRNA recognition sequences.
PolyA+

Expression induced during myoblast differentiation but absent in proliferating myoblasts in mouse and humans.
In mouse tissues expression was restricted to certain skeletal muscles where it was found only in "newly regenerating fibres". Expression is found more widely found amongst skeletal muscle of mutant mice which do not express dystrophin.
Conversely in myoblasts from humans with Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD), there was little linc-MD1 expression and MYOG and MHC expression was also reduced.
Predominately cytoplasmic.
Promoter regions near the linc-MD1 and miR-206 TSSs contain conserved CANNTG (E-box) sequences, and are bound by the muscle transcription factor MyoD. During myoblast differentiation and in muscles where linc-MD1 is expressed these promoter regions (plus others) form long distance chromatin interactions.

Competing endogenous RNA (ceRNA). Binds miR-135 and miR-133 and inhibits their repressive action, including on MEF2C and MAML1, two transcription factors required for proper muscle differentiation.
linc-MD1 required for normal up-regulation of MYOG, MHC and MCK genes during myoblast differentiation.
Nb: These linc-MD1 effects were also observed when linc-MD1 was mutated so miR-133b could not be released from the sequence, showing this effect was due to the lincRNA transcript.
Exon 1 and the region of exon 3 containing miR-133b is conserved in mammals and also back to chicken. Exon 2 conserved in mammals.

Expression of miR-206 and miR-133b is specific to muscle tissue. miR-133b expression profile closely corresponds to that of linc-MD1.
Sequence provided is only partial length, it was reported that the transcript 3' ends are 1060 and 1450 nt further downstream.

The murine mmu-lnc-31 transcript was identified through a transcriptome analysis performed during in vitro myoblast differentiation of cultured C2C12 cells. This transcript originates from a genomic region at chr4:88555804-88587945 and contains pre-miR-31 sequences inside the third exon. (Ballarino 2014)

mmu-lnc-31 expression is high in proliferating C2C12 cells and strongly downregulated upon differentiation. In mdx muscles, where more proliferating myoblasts are present due to the intense regenerative process, lnc-31 accumulates at high levels. (Ballarino 2014)
lnc-31 controls the maintenance of myoblast proliferation in both murine and human myoblasts. (Ballarino 2014)

A transcript overlapping miR-31 originates from the synthenic human HG31 genomic region at Chromosome 9p21.3 (Augoff 2012). However, compared to mouse where miR-31 maps inside the third exon of mmu-lnc-31, human miR-31 originates from the first intron of the HG31 primary transcript. Analogous to the murine transcript, hsa-lnc-31 RNA is also abundant in proliferating human myoblasts and is down-regulated upon differentiation into myotubes. (Ballarino 2014)
This annotation was contributed by Monica Ballarino - Corresponding Email : monica.ballarino@uniroma1.it . lncRNAdb greatly appreciate the author's contribution.

Spliced two exon transcript.
Multiple splice variants, ~550- ~750 nt in length, second exon varies.
Expressed bidirectionally with KDM5B.
In-vitro translation showed no sign of protein product.
Expressed in HeLa, K562 and GM12878 cells, plus a number of human tissues.
KDM5B-AS1 expression appears to stimulate KLHL12 gene expression (in HeLa cells). A gene located ~80kb from KDM5B-AS1 on the opposite strand.
Present in chr6q27 region, which is frequently involved in chromosomal rearrangements and associated with a wide range of human cancers and, thus, postulated to harbor tumor-suppressor genes.

Antisense RNA overlaps the 1st, 6th and 7th intron of the candidate tumor suppressor gene RPS6KA2 (so far reported as a tumor suppressor gene for sporadic epithelial ovarian carcinoma). Sense and antisense RNAs are detected in fetal brain RNA, but they show inverse expression in several breast cancer cell lines compared to normal breast tissue, with RPS6KA2 down-regulated in cancer and the antisense up-regulated. Antisense RNA is reported to map in two different genomic regions, and also to contain a potential ORF, potentially representing the FAM103A1 pseudogene.
Pair are proposed to be reciprocally regulated, and antisense RPS6KA2 is hypothesized to regulate RPS6KA2 expression in cancer. Over-expression of the antisense RNA in BT20 cells (a breast cancer cell line model) was associated with a decrease in the intracellular levels of the sense transcript, whereas knock-down of RPS6KA2 sense by RNAi in the BT20 cell line caused an increase in the level of RPS6KA2 antisense.
Microarray data also showed that RPS6KA2 and its antisense RNA have a negative expression correlation (with a high confidence (p=0.0092) in 42 out of 59 patients (71%)).
Spinocerebellar ataxia 8 (SCA8) RNA KLHL1AS: kelch-like 1 (Drosophila) antisense ATXN8OS: ataxin 8 opposite strand
~1.5kb spliced transcript. Antisense to the KLHL1 gene (homolog of the Drosophila KELCH gene) in a bidirectional transcriptional orientation (overlapping in the first exon).
N/A

Ectopic expression in Drosophila induces late-onset, progressive neurodegeneration in the retina.
Predicted gene product underpinning the triplet repeat expansion-induced neurodegenerative disease Spinocerebellar Ataxia 8.
Associates with the RNA binding protein staufen.
KLHL1AS promoter is conserved between human and mouse. However, the mouse gene is not spliced.

Derived from VL30 mouse virus-like retrotransposons ((Keshet 1980)).
Transcripts of various sizes are detected by Northern blot, including a major band of ~5kb, but also bands of ~9 and ~11kb, depending on the tissue analysed ((Harrigan 1989), (Keshet 1980)).

VL30 RNAs are found ubiquitously in adult mice tissues ((Harrigan 1989)). VL30-1 RNA (a member of the VL30 family) is expressed 5- to 8-fold higher in mouse tumor lines than in mouse fibroblast or myoblast lines ((Wang 2009)), and is induced by pituitary hormones in steroidogenic cells ((Song 2004)).
Identified in the developing mouse periventricular germinal zones. It is also expressed extensively in the developing mouse CNS. Enriched in undifferentiated neurospheres derived from cortex in bFGF (basic fibroblast growth factor) and TGFa (transforming growth factor alpha), as well as from striatum in bFGF, compared to differentiated cortical neurospheres derived in bFGF. Also found expressed in both Embryonic Stem (ES) cells and Hematopoietic Stem Cells (HSC) ((Easterday 2003)).

VL30-1 binds and regulates the PSF (PTB-associated splicing factor) protein, which contains 2 RNA-binding domains (RBDs), forming a PSF-RNA complex ((Wang 2009)).
VL30 RNA regulates steroidogenesis, and possibly other physiological processes, by forming a complex with PSF in mice ((Song 2004)).
Ectopic expression of VL30-1 RNA in a human tumor cell promoted metastasis ((Song 2002)), and in mice over-expression of VL30-1 RNA promoted cell proliferation in culture and tumorigenesis in-vivo ((Wang 2009)).
VL30-1 RNA is tumor-promoting whereas PSF is a tumor-suppressor agent, and the molar ratio of PSF protein and VL30-1 RNA regulates proto-oncogene transcription, cell proliferation, and tumorigenesis. VL30-1 RNA binds and releases PSF from a proto-oncogene and activates transcription of target genes ((Song 2005)). For example, in mice VL30-1 RNA has been shown to bind and release PSF from the proto-oncogene Rab23, activating its transcription in-trans ((Wang 2009)). (Although VL30 RNAs are not present in the human genome, a similar regulatory mechanism functions in human cells, in which different RNA fragments bind PSF ((Li 2009)).)
VL30 is enriched in multiple stem cell populations and may have roles in determining "stemness", or stem cell function ((Easterday 2003)).
VL30 mouse virus-like retro-elements comprise a family of sequences, 5 to 6 kb in length and containing long terminal repeats, with 100 to 200 copies dispersed throughout the genome ((Keshet 1982)).

MUNC, first known as DDR(eRNA), was using genome-wide binding profile (Polllm ChIP, MyoD Chip and DNase1 sensitivity). MUNC was first described as RNA transcribed from extragenic enchaner regions of MYOD1 (Mousavi 2013) .MUNC is encoded 5 kb upstream of the transcription start site of MyoD, a myogenic transcription factor gene (Mueller 2014) . Although MUNC overlaps with the DRR enhancer, our results suggest that MUNC is not a classic cis-acting enhancer RNA (e-RNA) acting exclusively by stimulating the neighboring MyoD gene but more like a promyogenic lncRNA that acts directly or indirectly on multiple promoters to increase myogenic gene expression (Mueller 2014)

MUNC is specifically expressed in skeletal muscle, exists as an unspliced and spliced isoform (Mueller 2014). Upregulated more than ten-fold in myotubes versus myoblasts (Mueller 2014) .
Small interfering RNA (siRNA) of MUNC reduced myoblast differentiation and specifically reduced the association of MyoD to the DRR enhancer and myogenin promoter but not to another MyoD-dependent enhancer (Mueller 2014)
Stable overexpression of MUNC from a heterologous promoter increased endogenous MyoD, Myogenin, and Myh3 (myosin heavy chain, [MHC] gene) mRNAs but not the cognate proteins, suggesting that MUNC can act in trans to promote gene expression but that this activity does not require an induction of MyoD protein. MUNC also stimulates the transcription of other genes that are not recognized as MyoD-inducible genes. Knockdown of MUNC in vivo impaired murine muscle regeneration, implicating MUNC in primary satellite cell differentiation in the animal. We also discovered a human MUNC that is induced during differentiation of myoblasts and whose knockdown decreases differentiation, suggesting an evolutionarily conserved role of MUNC lncRNA in myogenesis (Mueller 2014)

Overexpression and knock out experiment suggest that MUNC is involved in murine muscle regeneration and differentiation of myoblasts (Mueller 2014).
MUNC depletion resulted in reduced chromatin accessibility and Pol II residency at MYOD1 and MYOG loci, respectively (Mousavi 2013)
MUNC-like transcript is preserved in humans and that it may be equally important for differentiation. (Mueller 2014)
Sequences and splice variants were confirmed by RACE PCR (Mueller 2014).
KD sensitises Jurkat cells to Par-4 mediated apoptosis via allowing increased Par4-THAP1 interaction ((Zhang 2013))
ORFs do not contain any othologous features nor kosak sequences. Sequence is not translated in vitro/in vivo
lncUSMuycn is located upstream of MYCN and it is part of the 130kb amplicon present in 20-30% of neuroblastomas. It consists of 3 exons
lncUSMycn is coamplified with MYCN in 88/341 Neuroblastoma tissues. Expression levels are at the lowest during the G0 phase and highest during G1/S and S phases (Liu 2014).

Knocking down lncUSMycn in the MYCN amplified cell line BEC2 reulted in reduced expression of MYCN mRNA as well as reduced protein levels while overexpression of lncUSMycn in the non MYCN amplified cell line SK-N-AS resulted in increased expression of MYCN mRNA and protein levels (Liu 2014). Knocking down LncUSMycn in MYCN amplified cells reduces cell viability (Liu 2014). LncUSMycn binds to the NonO protein which together binds MYCN mRNA and upregulates its expression which in turn increases the neroblastoma cell proliferation (Liu 2014).
High expression of lncUSMycn and NonO is associated with poor patient prognoses in cancer (neuroblastoma) (Liu 2014).
Bsr (brain specific repetitive) RNA

LncRNA from the Dlk1-Dio3 imprinted region ((Komine 1999), (Royo 2007)).
Similar to Rian locus in mouse and humans with a lncRNA containing intronic snoRNAs, except the Bsr locus contains a ~100kb rat specific sequence containing 86 0.9kb tandem repeats ((Royo 2007), (Komine 1999)). Bsr appears to have evolved through a massive duplication based expansion of some snoRNAs present in the ancestral locus ((Royo 2007)).
Tandem repeats in the Bsr locus consist of an intron containing the RBII-36 snoRNA and a Bsr lncRNA exon ((CavaillA 2001), (Royo 2007)).
Multiple products are detected from the Bsr locus consisting of varying numbers of the 0.9kb tandem repeat from which the ~75 bp snoRNA is spliced out ((Komine 1999), (CavaillA 2001)).

Imprinted: Maternally expressed ((Royo 2007)). Like snoRD115-HG and snoRD116-HG, one Bsr allele can show evidence of less compacted chromatin, this is almost always the transcribed allele ((Vitali 2009)).
Bsr is expressed predominantly in the CNS both during development and in adults ((Komine 1999)) as is the RBII-36 snoRNA cluster ((CavaillA 2001)).
Nuclear localisation ((Komine 1999)). Mature, spliced Bsr was not localised to the nucleolus, unlike most mature RBII-36 ((CavaillA 2001), (Royo 2007)). Bsr was present as mutiple small foci in the interchromatin space, often found on periphery of SC35 speckles but not found in SC35 speckles or paraspeckles ((Royo 2007)). Did not co-localise with rat snoRD115-HG or snoRD116-HG, two other nuclear retained snoRNA containing lncRNAs ((Vitali 2009)).
Upon cellular stress a portion of Bsr relocates to the cytoplasm where it associates with stress granules ((Royo 2007)).

Bsr and Rian/MEG8/Irm are not highly conserved between species ((CavaillA 2002)). However, some Rian exons show good homology to Bsr and while many snoRNAs are specific to one species others are homologous ((Hatada 2001), (CavaillA 2002)).
UCSC browser link is from mapping of mouse Rian/Meg8 onto rat and may not be precisely representative of full length Bsr, the sequence for which is not available.

Comparing human, mouse and rat: All contain ncRNA gene(s) with intronic snoRNAs at this locus. The snoRNAs vary between species, but there are some homologous snoRNAs between each suggesting an evolutionary history with species specific snoRNA addition and duplication ((CavaillA 2002)). The expression profiles of Bsr, Rian/Irm/MEG8 and the snoRNAs they contain are similar between rat, human and mouse.
Differential expression during mouse testis maturation (Nolasco (2012)).
Tbca13 mRNA levels are post-transcriptionally regulated by the sense and natural antisense Tbca16 mRNA levels.
alncRNA-EC7 is marked by histone marks associated with enchancers.
Knockdown of alcnRNA-EC7 decreases the expression of Band 3 (Alvarez-Dominguez 2013)

Spliced two exon transcript of ~550 nt in length (Ã˜rom (2010)).
~2kb downstream from 3â€™ of Extracellular Matrix Protein 1 (ECM1), however a H3K4me3 peak at the TSS provides good evidence it is an independent transcript (Ã˜rom (2010)).
In-vitro translation showed no sign of a protein product (Ã˜rom (2010)).

ECM1 and LINC00568 are both upregulated during differentiation of primary human keratinocytes with TPA (Ã˜rom (2010)).
LINC00568 identified as enriched in K562 and HepG2 nuclear fractions ((Derrien 2012)).
LncRNA stimulates ECM1 gene expression (in HEK293 cells) (Ã˜rom (2010)).

Intergenic, 2 exon transcript in mouse, with HeK4me3 chromtain mark at 5' ((Chodroff 2010)).
Human ortholog is linc-POLR3G-8 ((Cabili 2011)). Human ortholog has a number of splice isoforms with 3 or more exons.

Expressed in specific regions of embryonic and post-natal mouse brain (see Chodroff for details) including the rostal migratory stream at P3 with a â€œpotential association with inhibitory GABAergic neuronsâ€� ((Chodroff 2010)).
Expressed in opossum and chicken embryonic brains showing spatio-temporal conservation of expression ((Chodroff 2010)).

Highly conserved for a lincRNA 36.7% mouse transcript overlaps phastCons elements ((Chodroff 2010)).
Conserved in mammals and back to frog, although mouse exon 2 is not conserved in all orthologs ((Chodroff 2010)).
Opossum ortholog [GenBank:GU951678]. Frog and chicken ([GenBank: CX847574.1 and CR35248.1] respectively ((Chodroff 2010)).

Mouse transcript contains Evofold-predicted RNA secondary structure ((Chodroff 2010)).
LncRNA transcripts in human from bidirectional promoter with TMEM161B (over 50kb upstream from linc-POLR3G-8 start site) can also share exons 2 and/or 3. See BC047059.
Northern identifies a transcript of around 6kb.
Identified in mouse embyonic stem cells (mESCs).
Binds PRC2 chromatin modifying complex, while the sense Malat1/Neat2 transcript does not.

As the transcript itself is not defined no accurate ucsc browser link is possible, although it's putative length combined with the PCR primers and northern probe utilized by Zhao 2010 suggest a significant overlap with Malat1.

Has similar structural characteristics in different vertebrate species. Spliced transcript with long (4-8kb) terminal exon which contains a number of conserved sequences.
Zebrafish: ~4.5kb, 3 exons with long terminal exon. Terminal exon contain several DNA transposons. Convergent transcription with oip5.
Human: ~8.8kb transcript has positional synteny, generally 3 or 4 exons, full length transcript has a long terminal exon.
Mouse: ~8.2kb, transcript has positional synteny, 3 exons, full length transcript has a long terminal exon.

Expressed in zebrafish nervous system. Brain and notochord at 24 hours post fertilization (hpf), expression at 72 hpf also includes zebrafish spinal cord.
