Mouse and human homolgoues are widely expressed in adult and developing tissues and cell lines including the brain (ENCODE, Gascoigne et al).
RNA stability half-life of mouse homologue was 3-4 hr in neuroblastoma cells, close to lncRNA median ((Clark 2012)).

Required for normal embronyic development in Zebrafish. Morpholinos to decrease transcript level or block conserved (miR-7 recognition) site had neural development defects and short tails. - Lack of functional cyrano caused small heads and eyes, â€œdefect in neural tube opening, loss of NeuroD-positive cells in the retina and tectum and enlarged nasal placodesâ€�.
Defects could be recused by mature zebrafish cyrano transcript as well as the human and mouse orthologues.
Conserved site was necessary but not sufficient to explain cyrano function in zebrafish.

Long terminal exon shows a number of conserved sequences within tetrapods. One ~300nt highly conserved sequence contains a 67 nt sequence conserved between tetrapods and zebrafish, a 26nt subregion of which is almost perfectly conserved in vertebrates and is hypothesised to be a miR-7 binding site.
Tmevpg1: Theiler's murine encephalomyelitis virus persistence candidate gene 1

Found within the Tmevpg3 genetic locus which controls Theiler's virus persistance/ load ((Vigneau 2001)).
Promoter contains binding sites for E2A and the Ets family of transcription factors. Suggesting regulation by transcription factors involved in the immune system ((Vigneau 2001)).
Spliced with 5 or 6 exons depending on isoform/ species ((Vigneau 2001)).

In resistant mice Tmevpg1 is constitutively expressed in CD4+ and CD8+immune cells in the spleen and thymus and upon infection, by immune cells infiltrating into the CNS, however no Tmevpg1 expression was seen in susceptible mice ((Vigneau 2001), (Vigneau 2003)).
Found in peripheral blood lymphocytes in humans with expression in NK+ cells, CD4+ and CD8+ T-lymphocytes ((Vigneau 2001), (Vigneau 2003)).
In both mouse and humans Tmevpg1 was down-regulated upon immune cell activation with a reciprocal up-regulation in interferon gamma (Ifng) expression ((Vigneau 2003)).
It has been speculated there may be a regulatory regulationship between Tmevpg1 and Ifng to explain their reciprocal expression ((Vigneau 2003)).

Present in mouse and human. Sequence conservation is limited to the promoter, first exons and its splice site, otherwise the transcripts are poorly conserved and can contain repeat elements ((Vigneau 2001)).

The Tmevpg3 genetic locus was found to control persistence of Theiler's virus in the central nervous system, along with the H-2D gene, this QTL locus was found to be near but exclude the interferon gamma (Ifng) gene ((Bihl 1999)).

Three CARMEN isoforms have been annotated - CARMEN1, CARMEN2, and CARMEN3
Found to be a human super enhancer-associated long noncoding RNA controlling cardiac specification differentiation and homeostasis (Ounzain 2015).
Found upstream of MIR-143 and -145 which are two important developmental miRNAs implicated in cardiac precursor specification and differentiation []. This region was shown to harbor a cardiac SRF/NKX2.5-bound enhancer required for cardiac-specific expression of miR-143 and -145 during cardiac development (Xu 2009)
CARMEN is found in a locus encompassed a cardiac super enhancer (Ounzain 2015)
ChIP-analysis demonstrates that these transcripts mapped to a highly active cardiac enhancer (P300) in both fetal and adult human hearts (Ounzain 2015)

CARMEN1, CARMEN2 and CARMEN3, are found to be at relatively high levels and significantly induced in differentiating fetal cardiac precursor cells (Ounzain 2015)
Expression of CARMEN observed to be negatively correlated to expression of cardiac-specific miR-143 and -145 in differentiating fetal cardiac precursor cells (Ounzain 2015).
In a murine model which uses mouse embryonic stem cells to recapitulates embryonic cardiac development in vitro, Carmen was found to be induced between the cardiac mesoderm and cardiac precursor stages with maximal expression occurring in cardiac precursor. The expression of CARMEN in differentiated cardiomyocytes of the murine model was comparable to the expression in differentiated cardiomyocytes derived from adult mouse heart. The role of CARMEN in cardiac differentiation was also observed in P19CL6 cells (Ounzain 2015)
Carmen expression correlated with enhancer activity high H3K27Ac occupancy levels during cardiac differentiation with maximal enhancer activity occurred between the MES and CPC stages (Ounzain 2015)
Carmen was significantly upregulated post myocardial infarction ( Fig. 8A), supporting a role for Carmen in adult heart homeostasis and cardiac remodeling (Ounzain 2015).
Deregulated expression CARMEN has also been shown in two human heart pathologies, idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) and aortic stenosis (AOS) (Ounzain 2015). Expression of all three human CARMEN isoforms. CARMEN3 was significantly upregulated in both DCM and AOS whereas CARMEN1 and 2 were only induced in AOS patients (Ounzain 2015)
CARMEN3 expression was markedly higher in post mortem atrium and ventricle heart tissues. CARMEN3. Hypertensive patients demonstrated increased expression of CARM in atria while levels in ventricles was not significantly different (Ounzain 2015)

Relative high expression level in fetal cardiac precursor cells suggest the role of CARMEN in cardiac specification and differentiation (Ounzain 2015)
Cardiogenesis differentiation in P19CL6 cells was blocked when cells are transfected with shRNAi targeting CARMEN. Knockdown of CARMEN expression also resulted in silencing some known cardiogenic regulator including Braveheart (bvht) lncRNA and Mesp1. Consequently, their downstream cardiac TFs Gata4 and Islet1, and the CM-specific genes Myl2, Myh6 were severely inhibited Oct4, Nanog and Emoes expression was also affected by CARMEN knockdown (Ounzain 2015).
In human fetal CPC, antisense-GapmeRs known down of CARMEN resulted in ablation gene expression of cardiac transcription factors and differentiation markers, including GATA4, NKX2.5, TBX5, MYH6, MYH7, and TNNI (Ounzain 2015). CARMEN depletion was associated with decreased expression of the smooth muscle cell marker, MYH11 (Ounzain 2015).. Importantly, CARMEN depletion was not associated with decreased expression of miR-143 and -145, further supporting the notion that CARMEN isoforms are not the precursor transcripts for these miRNAs (Ounzain 2015).. Consequently, CARMEN silencing impaired the capacity of human CPCs to produce differentiated cardiomyocytes., CARMEN-depleted cells were also co-transfected with MIR-143 and MIR-145 mimics were not able to restore cardiogenic differentiation induced by CARMEN knockdown (Ounzain 2015).
Thr cis-acting function of CARMEN was exhibited by the use of a firefly luciferase reporter gene under the control of a basal SV40 promoter inserted downstream of the CARMEN expression cassette (Ounzain 2015).
CARMEN was detected in RNA immunoprecipitation (RIP) assays with antibodies specific to EZH2 and SUZ12, suggesting that Carmen may have trans-repressive roles during cardiac differentiation (Ounzain 2015).

A long noncoding RNA, (AK087736), is transcribed from the orthologous region of the mouse genome, which we designate as the mouse ortholog (Ounzain 2015).
The promoter region is highly conserved, supporting an important role in the regulation of transcription at this locus (Ounzain 2015)
3693bp, 3 exons.
Controls human epidermal differentiation, with TINCR-deficient epidermis lacking terminal differentiation ultrastructure, including keratohyalin granules and intact lamellar bodies (Kretz (2012)).

Regulates epidermal differentiation genes involved in barrier formation. TINCR-STAU1 complex seems to mediate stabilization of differentiation mRNAs, such as KRT80 (Kretz (2012)). Required for somatic tissue differentiation, which occurs through lncRNA binding to differentiation mRNAs to ensure their expression (Kretz (2012)).

Spliced, up to 4 exons, ~920 nt transcript ((A rom 2010)).
Loci covers ~ 80kb and is antisense to CYP4A22 and CYP4Z1 ((A rom 2010)).
Transcribed bidirectionally with PDZK1IP1-AS1, downstream from TAL1 and PDZK1IP1 on same strand ((A rom 2010)).
In-vitro translation showed no sign of protein product ((A rom 2010)).

Expressed and functionally characterized in MCF7 cells ((A rom 2010)).
CYP4A22-AS1 identified as enriched in K562, HelaS3 and HepG2 nuclear fractions ((Derrien 2012)).
CYP4A22-AS1 expression stimulates TAL1 gene expression (in MCF7 cells) ((A rom 2010)).
Expression of lncRNA-DQ786227 was high and changed during the transformation of brioncial cells using benzo(a)pyrene (Gao 2013).

Silencing of lncRNA-DQ786227 expression in malignant transformed BEAS-2B cells led to inhibition of cell proliferation and colony formation, and increased apoptosis (Gao 2013). LncRNA-DQ786227 dramatically promoted the ability of BEAS-2B-T cells to form colonies in vitro and develop tumors in nude mice. (Gao 2013)
snaR: small NF90-associated RNAs

~117nt. RNA polymerase III transcripts. Highly structured. snaR genes shares sequence identity with Alu RNA and two potential piRNAs. Cloned snaR sequences have a run of adenines in the 3' end followed by a run of thymidines (which presumably constitute the PolIII termination site) ((Parrott 2007)).
snaR-A and snaR-B were originally identified associated to the Nuclear factor 90 (NF90) (a double-stranded RNA-binding protein implicated in multiple cellular functions) by in vivo cross-linking followed by immunoprecipitation.RNA species immunoprecipitated with NF90 were ~80-120 nt long ((Parrott 2007)). Several related RNAs of ~104 nt were originally cloned and identified, with snaR-A being the major component, and snaR-B representing the minor subset. snaR-A and snaR-B are ~90% identical in sequence. Human genomic sequences corresponding to snaR-A and snaR-B have occasional mismatches (suggested to be possibly due to C-to-U editing of the RNA).
snaR genes occur in multiple copies (accumulated by segmental duplication) arranged in two inverted regions of tandem repeats on human chromosome 19. Additional snaR gene copies are present, with two of them adjacent to genes encoding the beta chain of chorionic gonadotropin:
In total, 28 snaR genes have been identified in the human genome, including 14 genes for snaR-A and 2 genes for snaR-B. snaR genes identified by sequence analysis include 5 snaR-C genes and additional genes (snaR-D, -E, -F, -G1, -G2, -H, -I, -12 and -21) ((Parrott 2007)). snaR-D to -G include 5 unique genes on chromosome 19 as well as single copies (snaR-2 and -3) on chromosomes 2 and 3. snaR-G1 and -G2 are located in a gene-rich 2.1 Mb genomic fragment between the two clusters, lying within the promoter region of two genes encoding the beta polypeptide of chorionic gonadotropin (CG-beta) ((Parrott 2007)).

Predominantly cytoplasmic, unstable (half-life of ~15 min in HeLa cells), expressed in diverse cell lines and human tissues. The different snaR genes have different expression levels and profiles, and, among more than 20 adult human tissues analysed, snaR transcripts are found particularly abundant in testis, with low levels detected in brain, placenta and some other organs. ((Parrott 2007), (Parrott 2010)).
Highly abundant in some cells, with snaR-A estimated in ~70,000 copies in a HEK293T cell ((Parrott 2007)).
snaR-A and snaR-G2 are differentially expressed in discrete regions of the human brain and other tissues, such as testis ((Parrott 2010)). snaR-A was expression n testis was ~100-fold higher than in term placenta, lung and adipose tissue, and in brain its levels were ~10% of the testis level in three of four segments of pituitary gland, with substantial expression also observed in other brain regions (such as hypothalamus, globus pallidus and thalamus) ((Parrott 2010)). snaR-G2 levels in adult brain were ~55% of that in testis (highest in caudate/accumbens/putamen and globus pallidus), and several tissues displayed 5-15% of testis levels. Fetal brain contained much less snaR-G2 than adult brain (~3% of testis level), suggestive of developmental regulation. ((Parrott 2010))
snaR-A is up-regulated in transformed and immortalized human cells (Parrott et al. 2010).

Functions of snaR transcripts have not been identified yet.
snaR transcripts interact with NF90's double-stranded RNA-binding motifs (dsRBMs) ((Parrott 2007)), and snaR-A is also found stably bound to ribosomes in HeLa cells (Parrott et al. 2010).
Suggested to be involved in tissue- and species-specific regulation of cell growth and translation ((Parrott 2007), (Parrott 2009), (Parrott 2010)).

snaR genes are present exclusively in African Great Apes and some are unique to humans. Human snaR-A has orthologs in chimpanzee but not rhesus macaque or mouse. Chimpanzee has fewer snaR genes than humans (10 instead of 28). snaRs appear to have undergone accelerated evolution (snaR genes display a lower degree of homology within the gene than in their flanking sequence) and differential expansion in the great apes. ((Parrott 2007), Parrott et al. 2010). There are ~17 nt changes between human snaR-A (121nt) and snaR-C (119nt) species (~14% difference), compared to an average substitution rate of ~3.7?nt per 120nt (~3% difference) outside of the snaR locus ((Parrott 2010)).
The single snaR gene on chimpanzee chromosome 2a is 94% identical with its ortholog on human chromosome 2, and two genes on chimpanzee chromosome 19 are orthologous with snaR-G1 (a unique gene on human chromosome 19). The position of these snaR genes relative to the primate-specific CG-beta genes is conserved. ((Parrott 2007))

*Two families of snaR-related genetic elements were identified in primates: CAS (catarrhine ancestor of snaR), limited to Old World Monkeys and apes; and ASR (Alu/snaR-related), present in all monkeys and apes. These two classes appear to have spread by retrotransposition. It has been proposed that snaR genes evolved through a series of internal deletions and expansions from the left monomer of the primate-specific Alu SINE family via ASR and CAS ((Parrott 2010)).
*Short RNAs of ~26-34 nt can be detected after long exposure of Northern blots with snaR probes ((Parrott 2007)).
*Other RNAs are also found associated with NF90, including viral RNAs, such as the VAI and VAII noncoding RNAs from human adenoviruses ((Liao 1998)).
Single exon transcript intronic to NPTN. Found in both the cytoplasm and nucleus ((Ma 2014)).

Downregulated in hepatocellular carcinomas (HCCs), squamous-cell lung carcinoma, colon carcinoma compared to adjacent normal tissue ((Yang 2013)) in hepatitis B related HCC ((Yang 2011)) and in gall bladder cancer (GBC) ((Ma 2014)). Downregulation under hypoxic conditions may be by hypoxia induced HDAC3 ((Yang 2013)). Expression of NPTN-IT1 is a predictor of metastasis and death in GBC ((Ma 2014)). Ectopic expression suppresses GBC tumor growth ((Ma 2014)).

Inhibits metastasis of HCC, colorectal cells ((Yang 2013)) and GBC cells ((Ma 2014)). Decreases cell proliferation in GBC cells by inducing G0/G1 arrest and apoptosis ((Ma 2014)). Can bind to the NF90 protein, downregulating its abundance via the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway ((Yang 2013)). Decreases HIF1-? and CDC42 mRNA stability ((Yang 2013)).
Six transcripts
Upregulated in prostate cancer (Takayama (2013))

Located in antisense region of C-terminal binding protein 1 (CTBP1), which is a corepressor for androgen receptor. Directly represses CTBP1 expression by recruiting transcriptional repressor PSF with histone deacetylase. Promotes cell cycle progression. (Takayama (2013))
Localized in the nucleus. (Takayama (2013))
Prostate-specific transcript 1 (PCGEM1)
1603 nt, 3 exons.

Prostate tissue-specific and prostate cancer-associated (Srikantan 2000). Cholesterols upregulate the expression of PCGEM1 even in androgen-insensitive prostate cancer cell lines while phytosterols reverse this effect (Ifere 2009). PCGEM1 overexpression in LNCaP and in NIH3T3 cells promotes cell proliferation and a dramatic increase in colony formation, suggesting a biological role of PCGEM1 in cell growth regulation (Petrovics 2004). Low specificity as a biomarker for prostate cancer (14%) (Bialkowska-Hobrzanska 2006).
Over-expression leads to inhibition of apoptosis induced by doxorubicin (Fu 2006).
GWAS association with schizophrenia. PCGEM1 polymorphisms may contribute to PCa risk in Chinese men (Xue 2013)

Transcribed RNAs contain monomers if not multimers of a 171bp repeat but actual length of transcripts were not defined.
Alpha-satellite RNA comes from the centromeric repeats of many chromosomes.

Regulates the assembly of the centromeric kinetochore.
At interphase alpha-centromeric RNA is localised to the nucleolus. It is able to bind multiple centromeric proteins (CENPC1 and INCENP), which it sequesters in this subdomain.
CENPC1, a core kinetochore protein, appears to bind directly to alpha-satellite RNA.
Upon mitosis alpha-centromeric RNA re-localises to chromosomal centromeres, allowing localisation of CENPC1, INCENP and survivin (an INCENP-interacting protein) to the metaphase centromere and assembly of the kinetochore.
The regulated localisation of alpha-centromeric RNA hence regulates the activity of centromeric proteins and assembly of the kinetochore.

CENPC1 (centromere protein C 1) INCENP (inner centromere protein antigens 135/155kDa)
Centromeric sequences from a number of chromosomes were investigated, the UCSC browser location given below is just one example of a sequence that could have been detected.

First described in literature in a experiment, describing the Spatiotemporal co-expression of intergenic lncRNA and transcription factor genes during the development of the mouse central nervous system (Ponjavic 2009) Located with proximity to transcription factor gene Pou3f3. Total of 3.5-kb in length (50 kb downstream of Pou3f3 within the flank of an extended genomic region) (Chalei 2014). CNS-expressed, monoexonic, intergenic lncRNA and transcribed in sense orientation relative to Pou3f3 (Chalei 2014). Dali is known as linc-Brn1a and linc-Brn1b in mus musclus
Pervasive transcription in neuronal lineages (Ramos 2013). Based on RNAseq data, linc-Brn1b expression is spatio-temporally restricted in the developing cerebal cortex (Es derived) .

Genomic deletion of the linc-Brn1b locus resulted in significant (?50%) down-regulation of the upstream Pou3f3 gene, and linc-Brn1b-/- mice exhibited abnormalities of cortical lamination and barrel cortex organization (Sauvageau 2014) . Dali is required for the normal differentiation of neural cells in culture (Chalei 2014) . modulating the expression of its neighbouring Pou3f3 gene, as well as by interacting with the POU3F3 protein, and by directly binding and regulating the expression of genes involved in the neuronal differentiation programme in trans. (Chalei 2014) . Dali associates with the DNMT1 DNA methyltransferase and reduction of Dali levels increases DNA methylation at a subset of Dali-bound and -regulated promoters in trans (Chalei 2014)
Dali is known as linc-Brn1a and linc-Brn1b in mus musclus

linc-Brn1b knockout in mice results in downregulation of BRN1 gene ( downstream of lincBrn1b) in mice) (Sauvageau 2014). Knockdown of Dali, results in downregulation of AK011913, a transcript expressed downstream of Pou3f3 (Chalei 2014). CHART Seq of Dail revealed 1427 focal Dali-assoicated regions genome-wide, 9 of which were validated by CHART-pPCR (Chalei 2014) in N2A Cells . Dali binding sites were typically limited to less than 1 kb in length with even distribution across the genome with the exception of depletion on the X chromsome , indicative of x-link inactivation in female N2A cells (Chalei 2014)
Xenopus laevis short interspersed repeat transcripts

Family of lncRNAs. Contain varying numbers of ~80bp tandem repeats flanked by unique sequence ((Spohr 1981)).
Xlsirts localisation mediated by a 137bp repeat thought to fold into multiple stem loops ((Allen 2003)).
Localises to the vegetal pole cytoskeleton in Xenopus oocytes. ((Kloc 1993), (Kloc 2005)).

Necessary for the structure and integrity of the vegetal pole cytoskeleton ((Kloc 2005)) as well as the proper anchoring and localization of germ plasm islands and yolk platelets to the vegetal pole ((Kloc 2007)).
Degradation of Xlsirts caused the 3D structure of the cytokeratin cytoskeleton to collapse ((Kloc 2005)).
Suggested to be integrated into the cytoskeleton holding subunits together or promoting subunit assembly ((Kloc 2005)).

Bidirectional transcript from the CDKN1A promoter.
1.5kb single exon.
Sequence runs antisense through a processed LAP3 pseudogene and contains a SINE.

One of five lncRNAs surrounding the transcription start site of the cell cycle gene CDKN1A that, along with the CDKN1A protein coding gene, were induced in human fetal lung fibroblasts upon DNA damage by doxorubicin.
Induced up to 40 fold upon DNA damage peaking 16 h after doxorubicin treatment, a much greater response than shown by CDKN1A.
Expression of PANDA and CDKN1A were positively regulated by p53. CDKN1A did not induce PANDA.

P53 effector gene, acts in response to DNA damage to limit apoptosis while CDKN1A induces cell cycle arrest.
Loss of PANDA leads to the apoptosis of doxorubicin treated cells.
Loss of PANDA affected the expression of many genes during the DNA damage response. Upregulated genes were enriched for those involved in apoptosis, including the apoptotic activators APAF1, BIK, FAS and LRDD. Leading to apoptosis of doxorubicin treated cells.
Cell death genes downstream of p53 are known to have NF-YA binding sites. PANDA RNA interacts with the transcription factor NF-YA and attenuates its occupany of target gene promoters.
Syntenic sequence appear to be present in apes and old world monkeys (the Catarrhini).

Downregulated in hepatocellular carcinomas, colorectal cancers, and squamous-cell lung carcinomas (Yang (2013)). Hypoxia-induced histone deacetylase 3 repressed lncRNA-LET by reducing the histone acetylation-mediated modulation of the lncRNA-LET promoter region (Yang (2013)).
Stabilizes nuclear factor 90 protein, which leads to hypoxia-induced cancer cell invasion (Yang (2013)).
overlaps with the 3 untranslated region (3 UTR) of the human interleukin-7 receptor a-subunit gene (IL7R) gene (Cui 2014)

induced early (4 hr) by cellular exposure to LPS. Induced by TLR3 & 4 but not 3. Appears to be controlled by different mechanism than "host" gene IL7R. lnc-IL7R induction by TLR2/4 activation is a general phenomenon in human inflammatory cells Predominatnt nuclear expression.(Cui 2014)

OE has no effect on LPS-induced expression of proinflammatory cytokines, such as TNF-a, IL-8, and IL-6. KD experiments indicate that lnc-IL7R functions as a negative regulator of PSinduced expression of E-selectin, VCAM-1, IL-6, and IL-8. KD of lnc-IL7R results in increased reduction of f H3K27me3 at the E-selectin and VCAM-1(but not IL8) promoters in LPS-treated cells (Cui 2014)
Huc: H19 upstream conserved

Huc 1 & 2 are ~400bp conserved DNA elements separated by 1.4kb found ~10kb 5' of the H19 gene and the H19 ICR.
Both Huc 1 & 2 are transcribed producing individual transcripts which do not appear to join or overlap.

Huc1 and 2 were bi-allelically expressed as individual transcripts in same orientation as H19.
Expressed in a range of tissues in mid-gestation embryos, with only partial overlap to H19. No sign of antisense transcription as reported by (Berteaux 2008) at this locus.

Huc1 & 2 acted as strong mesodermal enhancers in a transgenic enhancer assay. Likely drive mesodermal expression of H19.
Contribution of expressed RNAs to Huc enhancer function is unknown.
Mice and humans.
Sequence and precise genome location of the transcripts have not been defined.
JADRR is induced after DNA damage in an ataxia-telangiectasia mutated (ATM)-dependent manner (Wan 2013) .
higher levels of lncRNA-JADE were observed in human breast tumours in comparison with normal breast tissues (Wan 2013) .

LncRNA-JADE transcriptionally activates Jade1, a key component in the HBO1 (human acetylase binding to ORC1) histone acetylationcomplex. Consequently, lncRNA-JADE induces histone H4 acetylation in the DDR;Knockdown of lncRNA-JADE significantly inhibited breast tumour growth in vivo (Wan 2013)
~4.5kb antisense TGF beta 3 RNA

Expressed during heart development.
Showed slightly higher expression in AV, when epithelial to mesenchymal transformation is initiated compared to the quiesent cells in the ventricle. By contrast TGF beta3 PTC was ~5x more highly expressed.
Antisense transcript showed increasing expression over timepoints that correlated with the loss of ability for AV cells to undergo transformation, whereas TGF beta3 PTC peaked and declined during the transformation window.

Heart valve formation during heart development requires an epithelial to mesenchymal transformation of cells in the atrioventricular (AV) canal.
Sequence and precise genome location of the transcript has not been defined.
IPS1: Induced by phosphate starvation 1

IPS1 is a member of a family of RNAs induced by phosphate starvation in plants that have short non-conserved ORFs ((Liu 1997), (Burleigh 1997), (Burleigh 1999), MartÃ­n (2000), (Shin 2006)) and a region of complementarity to miR-399 ((Franco-Zorrilla 2007)).
RNA of ~540 nuc (MartÃ­n (2000)).

Expression induced upon phosphate starvation and accumulates into the roots and shoots (MartÃ­n (2000)).
Hormonal signaling by cytokinins repressed IPS1 expression in the roots (MartÃ­n (2000)).

IPS1 has complementarity to miR-399, but contains a mismatch loop that renders it uncleavable when miR-399 binds. Since target cleavage is the usual plant miRNA pathway the non-cleavable nature of IPS1 acts to sequester the miRNA ((Franco-Zorrilla 2007)).
Competing endogenous RNA (ceRNA). IPS1 carries out target mimicry to sequester miR-399 and attenuate its effects allowing increased expression of miR-399 targets including PHO2 ((Franco-Zorrilla 2007)).

IPS1 family members have been identified in a number of plant species ((Liu 1997), (Burleigh 1997), (Burleigh 1999), MartÃ­n (2000), (Shin 2006), (Franco-Zorrilla 2007)).
However apart from At4 and IPS1 homology between family members is generally limited to the miR-399 binding site ((Burleigh 1999), (Shin 2006)).

Other family members include At4, At4-1, At4-2 and At4-3 in Arabidopsis thaliana ((Burleigh 1999), (Shin 2006) (Franco-Zorrilla 2007)), TPS11 in tomato ((Liu 1997)), Mt4 in Barrel Clover and Alfalfa ((Burleigh 1997)), Mt4-like in Soybean ((Burleigh 1999)).
Kenyon cell/smalltype preferential gene-1
~17.5 kb, intronless transcript ((Sawata 2002)).

Expressed in honey bee brain, preferentially expressed in the small-type Kenyon cell neurons of the Mushroom bodies ((Sawata 2002)).
Localised exclusively in nuclei. Forms punctate nuclear foci which vary in number from 1-50 per nuclei ((Sawata 2002)). Ks-1 did not co-localise with a second nuclear lncRNA AncR-1 ((Sawata 2004)).
Also present in another honey bee species: Apis cerana. Sequence was highly conserved but putative ORFs were not ((Sawata 2002)).
1.8 kb, cis-antisense to the pre-spore gene psvA, initiated from a promoter located within the translated region of the psvA gene.
Exhibits a temporal expression inverse to psvA during development.

Excess transcription of antisense RNA in vegetative cells and after disaggregation suggests its involvement in the control of psvA RNA levels. This has been suggested to operate at the control of mRNA stability, given that inhibition of RNA synthesis during disaggregation prevented destabilization of the psvA mRNA.
~1 and 1.6 kb isoforms identified.

Developmentally regulated ((Ginger 2006)). Expressed in alveolar structures of the mammary gland and induced by pregnancy and hormonal stimulation ((Ginger 2001)). Also present in testis, liver and heart. Different isoforms show a tissue-specific distribution. Isoforms localise in distinct foci predominantly in the cytoplasm or nucleus depending on stage of cell cycle ((Ginger 2006)). mPINCÂ is enriched in luminal and alveolar progenitors.Â mPINCÂ levels increase throughout pregnancy and then decline in early lactation, when alveolar cells undergo terminal differentiation, overexpression of mPINC in HC11 cells blocks lactogenic differentiation, while knockdown of mPINC enhances differentiation (Shore 2012)
siRNA knock-down experiments indicate that PINC RNA performs dual roles in cell survival and regulation of cell-cycle progression ((Ginger 2006)).

PINC identified in rodents. Other mammals contains several conserved sequence blocks ((Ginger 2006)). However, it is unclear if a PINC homologue exists in these species, for example the syntenic human locus is antisense to the 3' of DIRC3 and no sense RNAs have been identified which contain the conserved sequence blocks.
Hoxd3as: homeobox D3 antisense Hoxd3os: homeobox D3 opposite strand transcription unit

Spliced antisense transcript. Northern identified transcripts of 2.8 and 1.5kb.
Partial cDNA clone started 3' of Hoxd3, contained homeobox in antisense direction and continued into the Hoxd3 intron.

Antisense transcript only found in a subset of tissues expressing Hoxd3.
Expressed in 12.5 day embryo liver along with sense Hoxd3 and in adult CNS tissue.
Sequence and precise genome location of the transcripts have not been defined.
GHET1 is up-regulated in gastric carcinoma tissues

GHET1 is associated with poor prognosisGHET1 promotes the proliferation of gastric carcinoma cells in vitro in a c-Myc dependent manner GHET1 up-regulates c-Myc by increasing c-Myc mRNA stability GHET1 associates with IGF2BP1 and enhances the physical interaction between c-Myc mRNA and IGF2BP1 protein GHET1 promotes xenograft tumor growth in nude mice

Two exon, 600 nt transcript
Around 50 kb 3â€™ from SNAI1 on the opposite strand.
In-vitro translation showed no sign of protein product.
Expressed in A549 cells.

LncRNA regulates gene expression through SNAI1 dependant and independent mechanisms.
Stimulates SNAI1 gene expression (in A549 cells) and like SNAI1 is required for cell migration.
Stimulates Aurora-kinase A (AURKA) expression, a gene found ~6 megabases from LOC100887755 on chr20. SNAI1 does not appear to regulate AURKA and so LOC100887755 appears to regulate AURKA by a SNAI1 independent mechanism.

2.6kb, four exons.
Most of the sequence is composed of LINE, SINE and LTR elements.

LincRNA enriched in ESC (embryonic stem cells) and iPSCS (induced pluripotent stem cells) compared to the fibroblast and CD34 cells the iPSCs were derived from.
Also more highly expressed in iPSCs than ESCs.
Locus is a binding site for pluripotency transcription factors Oct4, Sox2 and Nanog. Knockdown of Oct4 or differentiation of stem cells caused down-regulation of lincRNA-RoR expression. Suggesting expression is controlled by these transcription factors.

Functions to promote reprogramming of differentiated cells to iPSCs. - Knockdown decreased the number of iPSC colonies formed without affecting cell number. While over-expression increased the number of iPSC colonies formed.
Functions in maintenance of ESCs and iPSCs. - Knockdown lead to modest increase in apoptosis and activation of p53 pathways.
No syntenic correlate expressed in mouse ESCs. Some exons appear to be transcribed from human specific repeat sequences. While others appear limited to certain primates.

~3.1kb, spliced, 2 exon transcript.
Starts ~15kb upstream and on the opposite strand to p21 (Cdkn1a) gene in mouse.

Transcriptional target of p53. P53 binds to the lincRNA-p21 promoter and up-regulates expression upon DNA damage and in various tumour cell lines.
Enriched in nucleus.
Complete length and structure of human lincRNA-p21 not defined, but it too appears to be regulated by p53.
Mouse RNA was stable with a half-life of 6.2 hr in in N2A (neuroblastoma) cells, well above the median lncRNA half-life ((Clark 2012)).

LincRNA-p21 acts to repress many genes transcriptionally regulated by p53.
LincRNA-p21 gene repression is mediated (at least in part) by lincRNA binding to heterogeneous nuclear ribonucleoprotein K (hnRNP-K) through its 5' end. hnRNP-K associates with the promoters of many genes repressed by lincRNA-p21 in a lincRNA-p21 dependent manner.
LincRNA-p21 is necessary for p53-dependent apoptotic induction, but not cell cycle arrest.
At least some sequences within lincRNA-p21 are well conserved in mammals.
Nb: Cdkn1a (p21) cell cycle regulator is also a p53 target gene.
MSUR1: mutant SOD1(G93A)-up-regulated RNA 1

~1.7kb transcript consisting of the first 1700nuc of 18s rRNA followed by 31bp of non rRNA sequence. 3' sequence contains a polyA signal and the transcript is polyadenylated.
Length and identity of transcript was confirmed by RT-PCR and northern blotting with a 3' probe.

Expressed in a broad range of tissues.
Up-regulated in the spinal cord of SOD1 mutant mice prior to onset of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) type symptoms.

In cell culture, mutations in SOD1 cause cell death, MSUR1 protect cells in a dose dependent manner and acts to decrease levels of hydroxl radicals and the oxidation of cellular proteins.
MSUR1 didn't affect the level of SOD1 protein, instead acting to reduce cellular oxidative stress. The mechanism of MSUR1 action is unknown.

Mutations in superoxide dismutase (SOD1) are linked to amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) a fatal neurodegenerative condition. A mouse SOD1 mutant replicates this condition.
Genomic position of MSUR1 transcript not known.
Emx2os: Emx2 opposite strand transcript.

5 kb. Spliced, bi-directional to Emx2, with a 271 nucleotide head-to-head antisense overlap. Riboprobe Northern blot indicates the existence of three additional Emx2os splicing isoforms differentially detected in the murine urogenital system, with sizes of 6.0, 2,3 and 1,8 kb, which are supported by cDNA evidence ((Noonan 2003)).

EMX2 and EMX2OS and their murine orthologs have similar profiles and extensively coincident cellular expression patterns in the endometrium. Expressed in the uterus, abundant in normal postmenopausal endometrium, reduced in premenopausal endometrium ((Noonan 2003)).
Emx2os is expressed in the developing mouse CNS. Examination of expression at E10.5, E12.5, E14.5 and E18.5 showed, similar to Emx2, that its levels reduce progressively from E10.5 to E18.5. At E12.5, it is detected in a number of CNS structures also expressing Emx2 mRNA, such as the pallium and basal ganglia, mammillary recess of the hypothalamus, optic tectum, olfactory placode and otic vesicle. Emx2os is found in the developing telencephalon in periventricular proliferative layers and the cortical plate ((Spigoni 2010)).
However, the sense/antisense pair may also show mutually exclusive patterns, such as within the cortex. Emx2os is detected in periventricular precursors that also express Emx2, but peaks in newly born post-mitotic neurons, which do not express Emx2, whereas Emx2 is expressed Cajal-Retzius neurons lying in the marginal zone, which do not express the antisense RNA ((Spigoni 2010)).
In human brain, expression has been detected in normal nucleus accumbens ((Michelhaugh 2010)).

EMX2OS is suggested to regulate EMX2 expression ((Noonan 2003)), which may involve distinct regulatory mechanisms in different cell types ((Spigoni 2010)).
In vitro knock-down experiments indicate that Emx2os contributes to post-transcriptional down-regulation of its sense partner in cortical precursors and their neuronal progenies, possibly by a Dicer1-dependent process ((Spigoni 2010)).
However, ectopic expression of a 5' fragment (OS1-179+) of Emx2os in neural precursors of the rhombo-spinal tract stimulates expression of Emx2, indicating a complex regulatory mechanism, perhaps at transcriptional level. In addition, Emx2 knock-out results in a strong reduction of Emx2os transcript levels, indicating a possible reciprocal regulatory loop ((Spigoni 2010)).
Association of Emx2os and Emx2 is conserved between mouse and humans, but no sequence conservation was found ((Noonan 2003)).
EMX2OS lies in the minimal interval with allelic loss in endometrial tumors and is a candidate endometrial cancer tumor suppressor ((Noonan 2003)).
ARA is located in an intron from PAK3. It is a ~5kb single exon transcript.
Adriamycin treatment of cells leads to upregulation of ARA expression (Jiang 2013).

Knockdown of ARA leads to decreased cell proliferation in the Adriamycin resistant cell lines MCF-7 and HepG2 (Jiang 2013). ARA knockdown induces apoptosis and increases G2/M phase arrest. Moreover, knockdown decreases cell migration (Jiang 2013).

The entire Vax2os locus spans ~19 kb on mouse genomic DNA and contains a sequence domain, of ~130 bases, localized within the Vax2os1 isoform, which is highly conserved across all mammalian genomes, including the rat, human, and other primates . This fragment represents the longest sequence conservation signature within the whole Vax2os transcriptional unit.
Vax2os1 is a retina-specific lncRNA whose expression is restricted to the mouse ventral retina

spatiotemporal misexpression of Vax2os1 determines cell cycle alterations in photoreceptor progenitor cells. In particular, the overexpression of Vax2os1 in the developing early postnatal mouse retina causes an impaired cell cycle progression of photoreceptor progenitors toward their final committed fate and a consequent delay of their differentiation processes. At later developmental stages, this perturbation is accompanied by an increase of apoptotic events in the photoreceptor cell layer, in comparison with control retinas, without affecting the proper cell layering in the adult retina.Vax2os1 is involved in the control of cell cycle progression of photoreceptor progenitor cells in the ventral retina.
lncRNA-ATB is a 2 exon transcripts which strechtes over 80kb
Overexpression of TGF-beta leads to upregulation of lncRNA-ATB. Hepatocellular carcinoma has higher expression of lncRNA-ATB thant normal hepatic tissue.

lncRNA-ATB works as a ceRNA for the miR-200 familiy, and overexpression of lncRNA-ATB leads to upregulated levels of ZEB1 and ZEB2 which are regulted by miR-200s (Yuan 2014). Moreover, lncRNA-ATB induces mesenchymal morpholocal features, and promote cell invasion (Yuan 2014). lncRNA-ATB binds IL-11 and increases the stability of the mRNA which activates the IL-11/STAT signaling pathway (Yuan 2014).

Located at 4q35, near the D4Z4 repetitive sequence. Contains NDE and DBE. Contains a potential ORF longer than 100aa, however is found in the nucleus, is chromatin associated and acts in cis, implying that it is non-coding ((Cabianca 2012)).
Expressed in muscles of patients with facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy(FHSD). Not expressed in muscle of control subjects ((Cabianca 2012)).

Acts in cis. Coordinates de-repression of 4q35 genes by recruiting Ash1L, resulting in histone H3 lysine 36 dimethylation, chromatin remodelling, and transcription of the 4q35 genes ((Cabianca 2012)).
MIAT: myocardial infarction associated transcript ((Ishii 2006)). RNCR2: retinal noncoding RNA 2 ((Blackshaw 2004)).

Intergenic, ~9-10kb alternatively spliced transcript in mammals ((Ishii 2006), (Sone 2007)).
Contains tandem UACUAAC repeats, which match the conserved intron branch point sequence in Saccharomyces cerevisiae ((Tsuiji 2011)).

Expressed predominantly in the nervous system ((Ishii 2006), (Sone 2007), (Mercer 2008), (Tsuiji 2011)).
Shows dynamic regulation during retinal development ((Blackshaw 2004)), differentiation of neural stem cells into oligodendrocytes ((Mercer 2010)) and in mouse embryonic stem cell (mESC) differentiation ((Sheik Mohamed 2009))((Dinger 2008)).
Expressed in the nucleus accumbens of normal human brains and one of a few genes up-regulated in this brain region in both cocaine and heroin abusers ((Albertson 2006), (Michelhaugh 2010)).
Nuclear specific localisation to novel nuclear matrix subdomain ((Sone 2007)).
Gomafu is downregulated in post-mortem cortical gray matter from the superior temporal gyrus in schizophrenia ((Barry 2013)). Dysregulation of Gomafu leads to alternative splicing patterns that resemble those observed in schizophrenia for the archetypal schizophrenia-associated genes DISC1 and ERBB4 ((Barry 2013))

Gomafu can bind the splicing factor 1 (SF1) protein through its UACUAAC repeat sequences. This sequence is a much stronger intron branch point sequence than found in most mammalian introns. In-vitro Gomafu binding to SF1 can inhibit splicing and spliceosomal complex formation suggesting Gomafu can function to regulate splicing efficiency ((Tsuiji 2011)).
Regulates retinal cell fate specification ((Rapicavoli 2010)).
Variants confer susceptibility to myocardial infarction, possibly through altering the RNA's protein binding properties ((Ishii 2006)).
Probable target of transcription factor Oct4 in mESCs. Appears to maintain Oct4 expression in a feedback loop helping to maintain pluripotency ((Sheik Mohamed 2009)).

Well conserved in placental mammals, present in chicken and appears to be conserved back to amphibians ((Rapicavoli 2010), (Tsuiji 2011)).
Outside of mammals sequence conservation is low but the SF1 binding UACUAAC repeats are conserved ((Rapicavoli 2010), (Tsuiji 2011)).

Together with the noncoding RNA BC040587 and the tumor suppressor gene LSAMP (limbic system-associated membrane protein), LOC285194 is present in the focal region of chr3q13.31 (osteo3q13.31), which is the most altered region in osteosarcomas. These genes are proposed to be cooperatively acting tumor suppressors.
Recurrent focal copy-number changes and loss of heterozygosity (LOH), which usually involves loss of LOC285194 and BC040587 expression, implicate these ncRNAs in ostecosarcoma. Focal osteo3q13.31 CNAs and LOH are also common in cell lines from several other cancers (such as lung, autonomic and central nervous system, blood, endometrium, soft tissue, skin, gastrointestinal tract, urinary tract, and breast).
Depletion of LOC285194 by siRNA promoted proliferation of normal osteoblasts (with a mild increase in the G1 population) by cell-cycle transcripts (Cyclin D1, VEGF, and VEGFR1 up-regulation, and cyclin A2 and cyclin B1 suppression) as well as regulation of apoptotic genes (such as suppression of BCL2 and BimEL pro-apoptotic genes).
Genetic deletions of LOC285194 or BC040587 in tumor DNA were also associated with dramatic decrease in survival of osteosarcoma patients.
Pinci1: P. infestans non-coding infection-specific family

Analysis of a member (Pinci1-1) indicates a minimum size of 850 bases. Polyadenylated.
The described Pinci1 RNA family comprises more than 400 members with sequence homolgy (110 full-length and 297 single-domain homology), which are arranged in clusters of up to nine copies throughout the P. infestans genome.

Identified in a suppression subtractive hybridization (SSH) screen for exprressed sequences upregulated during Phytophthora infestans of potato.
Expression of members of five classes of Pinci1 transcripts was found markedly upregulated from 12 to 33h post-inoculation of potato with P. infestans, a period defining the biotrophic phase of the infection.
lnc-DC is located in the cytoplasm.
The expression of lnc-DC increases with differentiation from monocyte to dendric cell, and the highest expression if found in conventional Dendric cells (Wang 2014).

The transcription of lnc-DC in Dendric cells (DC) is associated with the transcription factor PU.1 that is involved in DC differentiation (Wang 2014). Knockdown of lnc-DC resulted in downregulation of DC associatted genes important for T cell activation while CD14, a mark for monocytes, was upregulated (Wang 2014). Knockdown impaired the cytokine production and the ability for T cell proliferation (Wang 2014). lnc-DC bind STAT3 in the cytoplasm and affects the phosphorylation by preventing dephosphorylation of Y705 by SHP1 (Wang 2014). The interaction between STAT3 and SHP1 is increased by lnc-DC knockdown and decrease by lnc-DC overexpression (Wang 2014).
RNCR1: Retinal noncoding RNA 1 Six3os: Six3 opposite strand transcript

Six3os is found head to head with the Six3 gene ((Blackshaw 2004)).
Six3os undergoes extensive alternative splicing, that, combined with alternative 5' start sites, creates 12 known Six3os isoforms ((Blackshaw 2004), (Alfano 2005), (Geng 2006)).
Isoforms are up to ~7kb in length ((Geng 2006)).

Human and mouse Six3os transcripts both show expression restricted to retina and brain ((Alfano 2005)).
Shows dynamic expression during mouse retinal development with an expression pattern generally concordant with, by sometimes more restricted than, Six3 ((Blackshaw 2004), (Alfano 2005), (Geng 2006)).
Expression was not altered in Six3 null embryos ((Geng 2006)).
Found in mouse and humans ((Alfano 2005)).

The Six3 protein coding gene is an essential transcription factor involved in the development of the visual system.
One Six3os isoform has a potential ORF, however homology searching does not identify similarity to any other proteins suggesting it may not be a real ORF.
